applist.name: Poly Bridge 3
applist.detailed_description:
Poly Bridge 3 is a puzzle game where building bridges is key. Get vehicles to their destination by testing your engineering and problem solving skills. Suspension bridges, draw-bridges, multi-level bridges, crazy almost-bridges, bridges, bridges, bridges!

Campaign

Explore the new Open World Campaign with a dozen worlds and 100+ new levels. Jumps, Hydraulics, ‘Normal’ Bridges, and more giving you hours of gameplay to enjoy! Take a flying leap in Vaulting Towers or flex those hydraulic muscles in Bifrost Bend!

Sandbox

Let your engineering creativity flow with no restrictions in Sandbox mode, allowing you to push your bridge building skills to the limit. Challenge your friends and the community by designing intricate levels and publish them online for everyone to enjoy.

Community

Explore virtually infinite content and challenges designed by the community in the Steam Workshop. See what bridge designs other players come up with and show off your own in the Gallery. Challenge yourself and others by competing for the top spots in the cut-throat leaderboards and histograms.


Custom Physics

Our custom physics engine gives total control, reliability, and accuracy to your bridges. Sleep easy at night knowing your bridges will perform consistently every time!

Customization

  • Mods
    Mods allow you to customize your game to suit your tastes. Modify the game’s settings, include new options, change vehicle or material defaults, translate your game with player supported language packs, and more!
  • Decorate
    Add visual flair to your level with a whole range of decor objects. Alongside generic items (traffic cone, rocks, hot air balloons, etc.), each new biome comes with a set of themed decorations as well. Paint a happy little scene, there are no limits here.
  • User Generated Content
    Create your own vehicles, boats, planes, decorations, and textured custom shapes to add to workshop levels. Let your imagination soar! Share them with the community and download things made by other players.

Loads of new features

  • Build Zones
    It’s time to think inside the box! You can only build within their borders, like a reverse boat or plane. Are you up to the challenge?
  • Pre-Built Materials
    Showing is much more effective than telling. Pre-Built materials can be included with a level on loading, giving you a helping hand or another obstacle to overcome. Work around them or incorporate them into your bridge designs.
  • New Material: Foundation
    Support long bridges with a strong foundation, or two! Expensive yet very effective at reducing stress in key positions.

reviews.review: Ah yes, once again... Hours of soothing guitar as my bridges collapse.
It's like Poly Bridge 2 but 3er
aliensrock
briudge

In my opinion the "Poly Bridge" series is one of the best bridge builders out there.

Poly Bridge 3 is no exception to this. It offers lots of options like a level editor, steam workshop support, leaderboards, etc.

The only thing i am missing right now, are the reinforced roads. But i can live with that.

So many new objects, possibilities and a really nice graphic style.

I am totally thrilled. :-)
YEP Bridge

Poly Bridge 2, but with improved graphics, more  detailed environments, additional UI functionality, better physics (the weight of objects is now based on their length instead of just nodes), a different selection of materials (there is no more reinforced road and there are now foundations you can build), steam workshop-integrated mod support, and more all with no regressions from the previous game.

Basically, Poly Bridge 2, but better.

Why does sheeps rank the difficulty ?

Everytime I try to count the difficulty of a level I fall asleep... please fix that
just buy it , best puzzle game series ever , 3 has really pretty graphics too

Just as fun as Poly Bridge 2 with a smoother difficulty curve, levels seem more creative too. The only new feature I've noticed are foundations which aren't needed in a lot of levels, and they seem to have removed reinforced road and adjustable springs? If anything it has less features than PB2 but its still a good game, would be perfect if these were re-added.

bridge game was great
bridge game 2 was great
bridge game 3 is great

if you like making bridges, you'll love this. If you like optimization, you'll love this. If you like seeing cars go sploosh, you'll love this. If you like puzzles, you'll love this because sometimes that's what it feels like when trying to make a bridge cheaper
make bridge.. many fun. break bridge.. no fun :(
bridge

Poly Bridge 3's soundtrack might even be better that its predecessors, where i would open the game mainly to listen to music. And hey, the improved building mechanics and scenery are pretty cool too, I guess.
very fun i like committing crimes
epic
Maybe I just haven't played the game long enough to uncover all the cool new features but this is almost exactly the same game as the last two Poly Bridge games

applist.name: Killer Frequency
applist.detailed_description:
The year is 1987, and as the clock strikes midnight in small-town Gallows Creek, USA, former big city radio DJ Forrest Nash is live on air in what will turn out to be the graveyard shift of a lifetime...

In this horror comedy, you must solve puzzles to save callers from being hunted down by a mysterious killer. Where every call is life and death, can you save the inhabitants of Gallows Creek?

Unique 1st person narrative:

Step into the shoes of a late-night radio talk-show host – new in town and fallen from grace. The Police Chief is dead… so the townsfolk turn to you for help, as apparently you, Forest Nash are the only person in town who can run a phone line.

Real-time decisions and puzzle solving:

Use branching dialogues to interact with a variety of eccentric small-town personalities including potential victims and suspects. Explore your surroundings, gather clues, make decisions, solve satisfying riddles, and try to help each of your callers survive the night.

Retro Slasher setting:

Jump back in time to 1987 with this slasher inspired puzzler – explore an authentically detailed radio station and interact with dozens of physics-based objects straight from a bygone era, including a working cassette and record player. With a fully voiced cast and a killer original soundtrack of 80's inspired tunes from rock classics to synthwave!

reviews.review:
Step 1: Buy the game
Step 2: Buy a case of beer
Step 3: Play the game, drink some beer, groove to the music, get sucked into the story.
Step 4: Great way to spend a Friday night.

If you are a fan of Firewatch, The Suicide of Rachel Foster, or any narrative game you can lose yourself in for an evening... Pick this up. Best $20 bucks I've spent on Steam in a long time. Playtime for me (an inquisitive player) was 6.2 hours.

Fun game, great execution of the idea. My only complaint is that the sound board never played a factor in any puzzles or sequences, Its funny to play crickets over a bad joke but unless your streaming to a audience It was a wasted feature. 
Really enjoyed the puzzles as if you werent paying attention you could easily fail. Completed in one sitting and got the best results first try.

-Game takes about several hours to beat, less if you know what you're doing. 
-Atmosphere is great, characters are *alright*, and most puzzles are somewhat challenging, if only sometimes due to poor explanations.
-Main complaint is that some parts of the game drag in what feels like unnecessary time padding, and the lack of variation. Deaths of most characters don't have an affect on much of the game, and there's only two endings which aren't exactly hard to get each and generally feel like a letdown.

Fun game, just not sure if it's worth the $25 price tag.
So this game has a VR version supposedly but the steam version is not able to be played in VR mode which doesn't make any sense to me.
Game is fun, story is good, the requirements aren't too much. My one nitpick is the fact that the characters only take a minute to mourn the loss of a person

As an autistic person who's special interest is slashers, I was ecstatic to see that the people who made this game put a lot of love and effort into creating a narrative that feels like a genuine and loving homage to the horror genre. I truly loved this game and I cannot wait to replay it (which I will be doing immediately). Thank you guys so much for this absolutely beautiful game.

Puzzles were a little too linear for most of them, and the resolution wasn't particularly satisfying, but I would recommend if you enjoy narrative walking sims. It oversells the investigation aspect a little bit, only one puzzle makes real use of the things like the cork board and assorted information. 

As a side note, make sure you come down to PONTY'S PIZZA WITH THEIR FRESH NEW DEALS TOMORROW

Having played only one play through so far, I have to recommend this game to anyone who loves 80s vibes, serial killers and the ability to hit keys on a soundboard at inappropriate times. Not only is it very immersive as a puzzle game, it hits all the sweet spots of horror without being too much. There's a very intricate mystery to solve, plenty of important choices - with sometimes startling consequences - and a really good chill to go up your spine. At the same time there's a lot of levity in the form of playing tunes, hoarding everything you can pick up at your desk and using a sound board to amuse yourself. 

The dialogue choices, along with the important puzzle choices, dictate tone and results in the game that feel true to their weight. You can be under pressure sometimes but nothing's too hard to solve. Just... make sure to examine your clues thoroughly so you don't end up answering a quiz with only half the data. Speaking from experience. #sorryscott

I'll be playing through at least 2+ more times for achievements, so the replay value is already astonishing. It took me about 6-7 hours for one play through and so that's the one thing I have to say about this game: it isn't short, and you don't feel short changed. It seems to have a lot to go through and is well worth the price!

In this game you play as Forrest Nash who moved to the small town of Gallows Creek after he left his job in Chicago. In a bizarre turn of events it turns out an old town legend known as "the whistling man" has began to kill again 20 years after his disappearance. The first victim is the towns sheriff, so her assistant needs to drive to the closest town for help. Sense all of the members of the police station are gone for the night you need to fill in for 911 and take in calls of desperate victims in need of help.

 It feels really fun playing as Forrest who's just trying to adapt to his new job and save callers from the town. All of the puzzles are unique and fun in there own way. I really enjoy the graphics as well, its like if borderlands was a horror franchise. The music to this game is outstanding and by far the best part of the whole game. It really feels like music that was made in the 80's. The dialogue is witty and fun, although a few jokes did fall flat for me. The game is decently scary thorough the whole game. When your not trying to save callers who are desperate for help, your exploring more creepy areas in the old radio station. The game is pretty long (taking me 5.2 hours to beat) and super small at only 2 gigabytes required for the whole game. I would give this game an 8.5/10 and if your looking for an entry to the horror franchise I absolutely 100% recommend this game. But if your a horror veteran looking for something extra spooky that will make you cry yourself to sleep, I would recommend something else. But if your looking to have a great time than this game is an excellent choice.
this game is to die for. JUST LIKE PONTYS PIZZA THE BEST AND ONLY PIZZA PLACE IN GALLOWS CREEK!!

Got a comedic timing wherein I cutoff an asshole politician and was asked to play an ad...
and the ad i put was coincidentally from the same asshole politician. 
I immediately stopped it and sighed.

I am laughing myself numb with making clown sound effects on the soundboard while people are calling in that they are dying.
I am also their only hope
Welcome to my world
Amazing!!! Love how unique this game is.

just finished entirely, i recommend anyone and everyone to buy killer frequency, either on sale or at it's regular pricing!
i say the game length mostly depends on whoever is playing, my first run lasted up to around 5 hours but it was incredibly worth it!!!
- it is meant to be replayed for different outcomes/achievements, and even though i did four runs, it still remains as a fun & interesting game each time.
- the 'puzzles' you deal with for the different callers are so fun to. i originally feared them going into it, but they're overall pretty fun to figure out.
- SAVING IS A MUUUUSSTTT. don't be like me and figure out how to do so until extremely late in the game haha..hahhh...haaaaa....
- the story as well is an incredible bonus and keeps you wondering until the very last second.

- my ONE complaint is that there's no skipping the dialogue, if you decide to go back and do another run be prepared for another couple of hours on there. i feel if they added a skip button /after/ you complete the game, mine and other's runs would be super sweet.

my overall score regardless, is a definite 10/10, would replay not just for achievements, but to try and get the same feel of my first run all over again :)

This game was really good! Took a couple of hours to get through once so it was good time for the price. This game def made me think hard a few times. The game was also funny at times and made me laugh a bit. Totally worth the buy.

I've been looking forward to this game since playing the original game jam version on game jolt 3 years ago and it didn't just meet my expectations, but it vastly exceeded them. Killer frequency EXCELS at crafting a tense, tight atmosphere where it really feels like every decision matters, and is overall an incredibly enjoyable game on every front. The main characters have a wonderful synergy and consistently interesting banter, the radio host idea is executed extremely well, and the game manages to be absolutely TERRIFYING in the moments you're given control outside of your radio booth. A good majority of the time I knew I wasn't in any real danger, but the excellent audio design made me feel completely terrified anyway. The game's only real flaws I've dealt with are the fact I had a caller die and had absolutely no idea it happened until the end of the game tally (And had no idea what I had done wrong in that encounter considering every other member of the group was alive) and that caller retention seemed to be very minor outside of a select few, however with how many branches the game's choice making has it's completely understandable. I played the game completely in one sitting and can't recommend it enough, and will definitely be playing again.

Now please put the soundtrack for sale because I really want to throw my money at it!!!

Had a lot of fun with this game, Well written with some funny dialogue. Don't get too hung up on being a radio DJ if you wanna run the mixing desk this is not really the game for that. This is more about a good story and plot and trying to work out the mystery. With some fun puzzles thrown in. This isn't a expensive game give it a shot

Excellent game. Intriguing, fun, leaves you a little on edge. Doesn't really do many jump scares. The soundtrack was great! (Fun songs on the DJ track). Only complaint is the cussing in the dialog which way overused GDs. Otherwise 10/10
Oh, he died... so, do you have any siblings?

This game rocks. Super suspenseful for a game where you basically never leave your tiny radio room, at least to start. It's quite similar to the classic horror game Do You Copy, but with a significantly expanded scope in all the best ways. Great voice acting and the dialogue gets everything that's happening on the phone lines perfectly, without sounding corny. The humor was overall good, and decently spread out, and best of all it knew when it was time to put the clown horn away because the story was getting too juicy to have another pizza break.

The one thing that's a bit irritating is that the first two calls are significantly more complicated to run through than the others, ESPECIALLY the second one which borders on Keep Talking And No One Explodes. Once you realize [spoiler]the game has only a few actual quick time events, and no matter what people say outside of those quick time events you have all the time in the world to figure out the puzzles,[/spoiler] the game gets much less nerve wracking. But that doesn't make it any less suspenseful. Super great stuff. Highly recommend, worth every penny.

applist.name: Red Dead Redemption 2
applist.detailed_description:
Ultimate Edition


The Red Dead Redemption 2: Ultimate Edition delivers all of the Story Mode content from the Special Edition plus additional content for online including Bonus Outfits for your online Character, Rank Bonuses, Black Chestnut Thoroughbred and free access to the Survivor Camp Theme.

Plus get free access to Additional Weapons in online.


About the Game

America, 1899.

Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang are outlaws on the run. With federal agents and the best bounty hunters in the nation massing on their heels, the gang must rob, steal and fight their way across the rugged heartland of America in order to survive. As deepening internal divisions threaten to tear the gang apart, Arthur must make a choice between his own ideals and loyalty to the gang who raised him.

Now featuring additional Story Mode content and a fully-featured Photo Mode, Red Dead Redemption 2 also includes free access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online, where players take on an array of roles to carve their own unique path on the frontier as they track wanted criminals as a Bounty Hunter, create a business as a Trader, unearth exotic treasures as a Collector or run an underground distillery as a Moonshiner and much more.

With all new graphical and technical enhancements for deeper immersion, Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC takes full advantage of the power of the PC to bring every corner of this massive, rich and detailed world to life including increased draw distances; higher quality global illumination and ambient occlusion for improved day and night lighting; improved reflections and deeper, higher resolution shadows at all distances; tessellated tree textures and improved grass and fur textures for added realism in every plant and animal.

Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC also offers HDR support, the ability to run high-end display setups with 4K resolution and beyond, multi-monitor configurations, widescreen configurations, faster frame rates and more.

applist.short_description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.

[h1][b]Vengeance Is An Idiot’s Game.[/b][/h1]
[b]Red Dead Redemption 2 is a true work of art.[/b] [list]
[*]This game takes you on a journey that is unlike any other, filled with amazing characters, an immersive open world, and an engrossing story that will keep you hooked until the very end.
The storyline is emotionally gripping and skillfully crafted, the themes of redemption and loyalty are deeply moving, and the writing is some of the best in any video game.
[*]Many different activities, dialogues and a friendly atmosphere made me spend all my time in the camp. And I like it! Every member of the Van der Linde gang feels like a real person with their own distinct personality and backstory. You'll grow to love them, hate them, and feel for them as the story progresses.[/list] [quote=Arthur Morgan][b]Vengeance Is An Idiot’s Game[/b][/quote] [list] [*]and the game drives home this point in a powerful way. The consequences of revenge are explored through the characters' actions and the outcomes that follow. The game shows that revenge only leads to more pain and suffering, and the only way to break the cycle is through forgiveness and redemption.
[*][b][u]RDR 2 is a game that you don't just play, but you live.[/u][/b] This is the best game of this generation. If you're a fan of open-world games, westerns, or just great storytelling, you owe it to yourself to play this game. It's an unforgettable experience that will stick with you long after the credits roll.[/list][hr][/hr]

Having previously played RDR I had a strong feeling I would enjoy the prequel just as much. I originally played RDR2 on Xbox when it launched in 2018. I fell in love with this game and it's characters straight away and spent hundreds of hours exploring everything its open world had to offer. This game is an absolute masterpiece and one of the best games I have ever played. The attention to detail in this game is incredible. I could spend hours wandering around the wilderness admiring it's atmosphere. The campaign is one of the best adventures I have ever experienced. The only bad thing about the story is the emptiness you feel as soon as it ends.

[b] Introduction [/b]
This is one of the games where I would just turn cinematic camera on and enjoy the immersion. [b][i] Do note that I don't usually write a review or make an essay out of it but this game deserve one!. [/i][/b] The game itself is very immersive probably one of the best I've experienced. The landscapes are awe-inspiring, from the rugged mountains to the rolling plains, each with its own distinct atmosphere and beauty. The attention to detail is staggering, with dynamic weather and realistic animal behavior breathing life into the surroundings. It's a world that basically begs players to explore.

[b] Development [/b]
The greatest thing R2D2 have to offer is the deeply engrossing character development of Arthur Morgan. As a member of the Van der Linde gang, Arthur is a complex protagonist with a troubled past and a conflicted moral compass. Through the course of the game, players witness his transformation from a loyal outlaw blindly following his leader to a man questioning his actions and searching for redemption. The writing and voice acting are exceptional, capturing the nuances of Arthur's personality and emotional growth.

[b] World Immersion[/b]
The open world is filled with diverse missions, side quests, and activities that complement the overarching story. Whether engaging in intense shootouts (as always~), doing heists, or simply exploring the wilderness, the gameplay remains consistently captivating. I have over 70+ hours now and I haven't even complete my first playthrough (due to exploring the map, side-activities and irl education/work). With all that, there are still things which I have yet too discover! Like who is Gavin??!

[b] TRY IT! [/b]
Whether you're drawn to the allure of the Wild West or simply appreciate a masterfully story driven game, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an absolute must-play. While writing this down I should also note that Arthur Morgan is hands down the best protagonist out there!<3

It's fun to be in the middle of the story and Rockstar just decides to ban your account because you have a dynamic IP address. Thanks! Can't even log into the browser to send a ticket, not even VPNs work. Best birthday gift ever!

[h3]Now THIS is how to tell a story.[/h3]
Red Dead Redemption 2 features the most gripping narrative I’ve ever seen in a video game. The epic journey of Dutch Van der Linde's gang of outlaws is full of so many jaw-dropping, cinematic, action-packed moments, but still stays believable as the protagonist Arthur Morgan slowly frees himself of his life-long gunslinger ideals. And every character in the Van der Linde gang’s saga feels remarkably human, thanks to fantastic writing and voice acting that perfectly complement this game’s stunning visuals, detailed animation and beautiful music.

All of these elements combine to make the world of Red Dead 2 come alive in a way that no other open world game does. The massive five-state map is incredibly dynamic, with missions, side quests and random events of equally high quality perfectly interwoven into an enchanting world that constantly changes with the flow of the main story. And there are so many little details throughout this game - from memorable NPCs to colorful customization options to fleshed-out minigames - that make the experience feel authentic.

Even though I absolutely loved the phenomenal story and atmospheric world of Red Dead 2, the gameplay mechanics can seem shallow when taken out of context. Granted, there’s nothing wrong with the core controls - the shootouts are fun even on controller thanks to the Deadeye time-slowdown ability, and riding around on a horse is simple but satisfying. However, responsive controls are sometimes de-emphasized in favor of handholding gameplay and "realism" in regard to difficulty and mission structure. Horses automatically steer themselves on rough terrain, animations make looting and crafting take longer, many missions include trailing sections so the player can get where they need to go… et cetera.

Usually, when a game prioritizes realism over immediate gameplay like this, there’s a weak link somewhere that breaks my immersion - such as bad voice acting, weak writing, faults in sound design or visuals, or spacing of content around the map. And this usually results in these “realistic” game mechanics becoming more tedious than they are immersive, distancing me from whatever atmosphere is trying to be established. But.. this isn’t the case with Red Dead Redemption 2.

[h3]Red Dead 2 might be the first game to [i]fully convince[/i] me of its own world's authenticity.[/h3]
The immaculately detailed world and unbelievably human characters of RDR2 breathe life into in-game tasks that I would normally consider boring, like trailing missions, herding animals and catching fish - making even these less inspired gameplay segments pretty damn fun. The gameplay mechanics aren’t untouchable on their own, but the sixty-hour-long story pretty much is, and it’s paired with an intricate portrayal of 1899 America that makes the narrative just as enthralling as some of the greatest movies and TV shows ever made. This commitment to realism and thorough storytelling makes even the slower paced segments of the game exciting, and the intense parts (like shootouts) more meaningful.

I’m already partway through my second playthrough now, and I’m having even more fun this time around trying to dissect the incredible character dynamics and details of the open world now that I’ve beaten the game already. The more I play Red Dead 2, the more fascinated I am with the spectacular story and cast of characters - and the few issues I originally had with the mechanics have become less and less noticeable in the grand scheme of RDR2’s monumental scope. Rockstar has created a true masterpiece here, and the gripping tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan is a story I’ll never forget. 10/10

after 6 months of trying to fix this game and get it to run, Ive decided to finally review it. I loved and enjoyed every second within the game, however getting it to run itself seems to be an issue. RDR2 undoubtedly stands as a masterpiece in the realm of open-world games, solidifying its place as a true GOAT contender. With its vast and immersive world, the game offers an unparalleled level of freedom and a staggering number of quests that cater to a wide range of player preferences and interests.

One of the most remarkable aspects of RDR2 is its sheer scope. The game presents players with a sprawling open world, meticulously crafted and teeming with life. From the bustling cities to the untamed wilderness, every inch of the game is bursting with breathtaking detail and realism. As you traverse the landscape, you'll encounter dynamic weather patterns, diverse wildlife, and a rich ecosystem that reacts organically to your actions. This level of attention to detail creates an immersive experience that draws players into the vibrant and authentic Old West setting.

Questing in RDR2 is a true delight. The game offers an impressive variety of missions, ensuring that players can find their niche and embark on a personal journey within the game's narrative. Whether you're drawn to intense shootouts and thrilling heists or prefer more peaceful pursuits like hunting or fishing, RDR2 caters to every playstyle. The quests are expertly crafted, with engaging storylines, memorable characters, and unexpected twists that keep you hooked from beginning to end. Each quest feels purposeful and contributes to the overall narrative, making the game feel cohesive and rewarding.

Beyond the main story quests, RDR2 provides an abundance of side activities and optional objectives, guaranteeing that players will always have something to discover or pursue. From challenging bounty hunts to stumbling upon hidden treasures, the game is brimming with content that encourages exploration and rewards curiosity. Additionally, the game features a dynamic honor system that responds to your choices and actions, allowing for different gameplay experiences and multiple story outcomes.

Furthermore, the level of detail in RDR2 extends beyond the quests themselves. The world feels alive, populated by a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique stories and motivations. Engaging in random encounters or interacting with the residents of the game world often leads to unexpected and memorable experiences. Whether it's engaging in a lively conversation in a saloon, stumbling upon a group of outlaws in the wilderness, or witnessing a dramatic event unfold before your eyes, RDR2 constantly surprises and immerses you in its living, breathing world.

In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an unparalleled free-world game that deserves its status as a GOAT. With its vast and immersive world, diverse range of quests, and meticulous attention to detail, the game sets a new standard for open-world experiences. RDR2 invites players to embark on a personal journey within its captivating narrative, ensuring that every player can find their own niche and create their own unforgettable adventures in the Old West.
Slow game to get into, but if you find patience, and you get past the slow animations, and the slow start, the game it's very good.

applist.name: Root
applist.detailed_description:
A game of woodland might and right.


Play the digital adaptation of the beloved tabletop board game. Root is a game of adventure and war where 2 to 4 players battle for control of a vast wilderness.

The nefarious Marquise de Cat has seized the great woodland, intent on harvesting its riches. Under her rule, the many creatures of the forest have banded together. This Alliance will seek to strengthen its resources and subvert the rule of Cats. In this effort, the Alliance may enlist the help of the wandering Vagabonds who are able to move through the more dangerous woodland paths. Though some may sympathize with the Alliance’s hopes and dreams, these wanderers are old enough to remember the great birds of prey who once controlled the woods.

Meanwhile, at the edge of the region, the proud, squabbling Eyrie have found a new commander who they hope will lead their faction to resume their ancient birthright.

The stage is set for a contest that will decide the fate of the great woodland. It is up to the players to decide which group will ultimately take root.



The most recent conquerors of the forest, the Marquise de Cat plays a game of engine building and logistics while policing the vast wilderness. By collecting Wood they are able to build Workshops, Sawmills, and Recruiters to help her score victory points. Marquise de Cat has the largest army in ROOT, but numbers alone won’t be enough to secure the forest...

The Marquise de Cat builds a mighty industrial war machine to subdue the forest. Each time the Marquise builds a Workshop, Sawmill, or Recruiter, you score victory points. The more of the same building she has on the map, the more points scored. However, to fuel ongoing construction, the Marquise must maintain and protect a strong, interconnected economy of Wood. While it may be tempting to overwhelm your opponents with sheer numbers, this leaves you at great risk of spreading yourself too thin and ultimately not being able to keep up.


The Eyrie Dynasties once ruled the wood, before the coming of the Cats. They must retake control by capturing territory and building Roosts before they collapse back into squabbling. The Eyrie are proud and bound to the decrees of their leaders. Each leader brings with them different specialties and advantages. The right leader at the right time could lead you to victory, but the wrong leader could cripple your chances of reclaiming the forest.

During the Evening, the Eyrie score victory points based on the number of roosts on the map. The greater their presence in the Woodlands, the greater their gains. However, the Eyrie are bound by their Decree, an ever-increasing set of mandated actions promised by their leader. Each turn, they must take all of the actions on their Decree, or else fall into turmoil.


The Woodland Alliance doesn’t take kindly to despots - old or new. Marquise, Eyrie, they’re all the same. Only through the will of the people can this wood be ruled! The Woodland Alliance are masters of guerrilla warfare, they begin slowly but can build into a late-game powerhouse - but only if they can manage to subvert the other would-be rulers along the way.

The Woodland Alliance works to gain the sympathy of the various creatures of the forest. Each time the Alliance places a sympathy token, they may score victory points. The more sympathy on the map they have, the more victory points they score. Gaining the sympathy of the people requires supporters. These supporters can also be put toward violent ends, inciting outright rebellion across the forest. When a revolt erupts, the Alliance will establish a base. Bases allow the Alliance to train officers, increasing their military strength and flexibility.


The Vagabond is an adventurer to some, a trader to others, and thief to more, and an all-around scoundrel. As the Vagabond, you will explore all over the map, beyond just it's clearings, into dense woods to find items and ruins. You can trade and lend aid to the warring factions of the forest to help you complete your own secret quests.

The Vagabond plays all sides of the conflict while going on quests to increase his renown throughout the wood. Each time the Vagabond improves their relationship with another faction, or removes a warrior belonging to a faction hostile toward them, the Vagabond scores victory points. You can also complete quests to score victory points. To move and act effectively the Vagabond must manage a pack of items, expand your selection by exploring the forest ruins and providing aid to other factions.

applist.short_description: Might makes right in the wild wood! The award-winning board game of asymmetrical woodland warfare comes to cross-platform digital play! Combine subtle strategy and bold daring to guide your forest faction to victory!

“Overall it’s everything I wish more war games were. It’s beautifully produced, has just the right amount of randomness with the card deck and dice—enough to keep you on your toes and have a contingency plan but not enough to negate your planning.”
Board Game Quest

“Root is a winner. This game will take a long time to get great at, but it is a very approachable heavy strategy game.”
Cardboard Reality

“If you like a good war game, if you like to think about the political implications of what everyone’s doing on the board, and if you think the ultimate asymmetrical battle between the woodland’s cutest creatures is something you cannot resist, I cannot recommend this game highly enough.”
Sprites + Dice

reviews.review:
I'm sorry, I just can't recommend this game. 
The mechanics are cool, the design is pretty sweet, even the music is good. But you will need to pay 40€ for all the content that the game proposes, and wait an hour for a game where the host will ragequit midgame or last second. The content that you will have without the dlc is too little, and the fact that people will not get punished for leaving the game makes the experience so hazardous. You have to bet that the next one hour long game will be funny, and that you are not wasting your time waiting 30 minutes for a match that will never ends. If all the content would be here for 20€, I would not complain. But the risk to not have fun is to pricy for my taste. Sorry.
An excellent digital adaption of the board game.

Awesome game. However, there are a lot of newbies ruining the game with rage quits. They should allow host to block specific players from entering their games, even though I understand that this game still not have many players at a single time to allow penalties.
Good fun, and even better with mates

applist.name: Going Medieval
applist.detailed_description:
EARLY ACCESS ROADMAP


About the Game

STAKE YOUR CLAIM


In the world of Going Medieval, dark age society is on its knees. At the end of the 14th century, 95% of the global population has perished due to rampant plague.

Eventually, survivors emerge from society’s ashes, and it’s now up to you to help them settle in a dangerous new land reclaimed by nature. Build your people a home, help shape their lives, and protect them from animals, bandits, and other dangers in a lawless post-calamity age.

BUILD YOUR FORTRESS


Design, build and expand your settlement from a small wooden hut into a colossal stone castle. With simple-to-use 3D terrain tools you can create the perfect stronghold, from winding underground caverns to sprawling multi-story forts.

DEFEND YOUR COLONY


This harsh new world is rife with external threats, but you can give your colonists the upper hand in battle by building impenetrable defences and traps. Research, craft and equip weapons and gear so that they can fight back against unrelenting waves of attackers.

PROTECT YOUR VILLAGERS


Your colonists have more than just raids to contend with. They need protection from starvation and the elements, so it’s essential to stock up on supplies and build shelter to keep them fed and warm. Maintain your villagers’ emotional states, as their moods are affected if their needs and wants aren’t met.

SHAPE YOUR STORY


Grow the population of your settlement by helping out strangers in dangerous situations, or by taking in like-minded travellers. Your villagers have personal histories and agendas, and you can get to know them by observing their behaviour and relationships with others.

reviews.review:
"Wait, this just looks like a clone of Rimworld! Does having just one more dimension even make it worth the money?" 

yea
Can never put it down once you pick it up, great game all around.

Long story short: the game is literally medieval Rimworld in 3D with map levels mechanic from Dwarf Fortress. 

Exactly the type of game I was looking for. Game is still in development and getting frequent updates but at the current state it is 100% playable. If you looking for colony builder in medieval setting - this is the game for you. Love it.
Very fun game. heavily recommend it. wish maps could be a little larger and that you could copy and paste buildings. other than that fun game

Typical Early Access problem: Good foundation, content bare, absolutely glacial pace of updates.

I played a few hours when I bought it and thought "wow I can't wait for this to get some updates"
Around 18 months passed before I played it again and there's only a few more boxes checked off on the roadmap. It's fun, but so shallow. I'll come back in another 18 months.

It has high potential, but at the moment, many semifinished systems killing the fun in my opinion:
First the good things: the idea of 3d building of a medieval settlement is really nice, and you become proud of your build (and sometimes even beautiful) structures. 
but now the sad part: :-(
the temp. system keeps only warmth in, not coldness. so you have to dig like a mole to the ground to keep your food fresh. But the cellar had to be with dirt walls and twig floor, because of the random set heat isolation factors:
Walls: dirt 0%, wood 60% , clay 93%,stone 70% and stonebricks 75%
Floors: dirt 0% (but pushes rotting), wood 94%, twigs 40%, stone 70% and stonebricks 90% 
Buildingactions: your settlers often fix themselves in a wall or digging all fields arround them and than starve on their created "Pile of idiocracy". I don´t wanna know how often they will burn themselves to ashes, when the feature gets implemented^^
terraforming: there often spawn some resources from digging through vains. and the settlers often dig from above. when the mats are spawning in the hole, and there is no path on the same ground lvl. Now you have to build a ramp or a pathway, to get the stuff away from there, because it blocks the filling of the hole. 
Tasks: the settlers have only a small amount of "task-categories". So "cooking" means foodmaking, butchering, fermentation, smoking. But often your dead animals rots to pieces and you have no food, because high chief Jolanda is running thrugh the whole map to pick up some berries to make wine^^

I was really sad after I realized, how often I had to fix stupid behavior of my settlers. 
But maybe, I just have to high expectations, because of my expierience of (modded) rimworld. I hope. the ultimate castle building/settlement simulator of my dreams will come true, when I test it aggain in a few months. I wish for the developers, which created a cool basement with enormous potential

applist.name: ONE PIECE ODYSSEY
applist.detailed_description:
Digital Deluxe Edition


The Deluxe Edition includes the Main Game, the Adventure Expansion Pack and the Deluxe Edition Bonus: Sniper King Outfit Set.

Includes:

  • Main Game
  • Additional Scenario: ONE PIECE Reunion of Memories
  • Adventure Expansion Pack Bonus 100,000 Berries
  • Deluxe Edition Bonus: Sniper King Outfit Set

*Expansion Pack content will be available after the main game has been cleared.
*Adventure Expansion Pack bonus 100,000 Berries will be available upon purchase.
*Other content including this product are also available. Take care to not make duplicate purchases.


About the Game

A new RPG from the hugely popular manga and anime series ONE PIECE, commemorating the 25th anniversary of the series!

The famed pirate, Monkey.D.Luffy, better known as Straw Hat Luffy, and his Straw Hat Crew, are sailing across the New World in search of the next island and the next adventure that awaits them.
But during their voyage they are caught in a storm and shipwrecked. They find themselves washed up on a lush tropical island surrounded by constantly raging storms...

Separated from his crew, Luffy sets off on a grand, new adventure to find his friends and escape the island!
Dangerous new enemies, terrifying forces of nature, and more await them!

Play as various members of the Straw Hat Crew in a classic RPG set in the world of the popular ONE PIECE anime!

*In addition to this product, ONE PIECE ODYSSEY Deluxe Edition and other digital content is also available. Take care to not make duplicate purchases.

reviews.review:
[b]Meme review:[/b] Nami-swan and Robin-chan are just too beautiful and even more so with the "proper" mods, you know which ones i'm talking about. 10/10 game, get it nao!

[b]Actual opinion:[/b] DO NOT BUY THIS GAME... unless you are a hardcore One Piece fan.


I can already feel the stares full of hatred from the other franchise fans, but listen here - as a Monkey D. Luffy "imaginary nakama" for over 20 years now - I can't in a good conscience rope an unsuspecting passersby into playing this game. I honestly was going to downvote the Odyssey, but then Nami-sama has told me that she won't do the "happines punch" anymore, so you should understand - my hands were tied and I just had to upvote the game as her faithful slave. But at least i will explain here what are the game's problems and why you should probably avoid it, unless you are a fan yourself.

First of all - the game does not explain NOTHING about it's setting to the player. From the very beginning the Odyssey expects you to know everything about the One Piece world, the Grand Line, the Luffy's crew composition, adventures and desires, about the devil fruits and their rules, about the world government and it's dirty secrets and many-many other things. Even though the game's story is tied to the world of memories, where Luffy and his friends will "re-live" some of their older adventures - those "arcs" are made with so many things cut off and unexplained, that a non-fan player will be as baffled about the stuff that happened there after finishing them, as he was before that. The game was made for the franchise fans first and foremost after all, so if you actually want to enjoy the plot there is only one advice i can give to you - read the manga  first (or watch the anime, but reading will be faster considering the lenght of the story).

Second. Okay, maybe you don't care about the story or plot at all, and just want a basic gameplay satisfaction? At it's core the Odyssey is a typical party-based and turn-based j-rpg. The combat system by itself is okay, i don't have any major complains about it. Rock-paper-scissors vulnerability types, very well animated moves and attacks, an ability to change the team composition mid-fight - good stuff. The problem is what you are doing between fights... You are running. Back and fourth. In circles. Visiting and re-visiting the same locations again and again, grinding money, resources and exp, doing side-quests that require you to... yeah re-visit the locations you have thoroughly explored already. It's very tiresome. I literally felt how my will to play the game has been sucked out (and not in a "good" way) by this soulless gamedesign during the playthrough. If it was not the One Piece world, but some generic fantasy setting with the characters that i have no attachment to - i 100% guarantee you, that i would have abandoned the game half-way through. And judging by the steam achievements - many players actually did, because only the 10% of the game owners actually finished it.

In my opinion confusing setting + tedious and boring gameplay are reasonable enough for the non-invested gamer to avoid the Odyssey. But what about the actual franchise fans?

Well, yeah, in that case there is no other choice but to play it. Graphics are quite impressive, especially the characters. It's like a real-life anime, bruh! Suuuper! But even in that case i do have a few smaller complains to file.

While the 3D models are really cool and the colors and environment are faithful to the original - the whole Odyssey world is just a dead and motionless decoration or stage backdrop if you will, there is no life in here. Take any good modern game now - there you will see a walking crowds, some simple events unfolding without the players interference, mechanisms moving, etc etc. Here? Everyone, aside from territory-patrolling enemies are just glued to the same spots, waiting for the player to come and interact. Nothing moves by it's own will, nothing lives. And it's really a shame because the world of One Piece is so vibrant, teeming with life and events! But not here, no. Welcome to the Madame Tussauds wax museum.

Character outfits is my another complain. If you bought the basic edition - you will have the same outfits for the whole game's lenght. The travelling outfits dlc can unlock the pre time-skip versions of costumes. But this is all. WTF? If you follow Oda's work for long enough - you shall know that for every story arc characters have some special costumes and new outfits to match the mood of events. I was totally expecting, that after completing the Arabasta, Dressrosa or any other memory world/arc player would unlock the corresponding outfits, after all we even have a special tent specifically for the costume change. F**k you and your expectations says Bandai Namco. Thank God we are the PC master race crowd and unlike the console plebs we can use the mods to solve this issue. But still it's a very disappointing decision from the developer.

And while we are on the topic of mods, there are 3 main ones that i have to recommend you to install, to make your overall expirience with the game better:
1 better/alternative costumes for characters. this is self explanatory.
2 jiggle physics. YES. THIS. IS. MANDATORY. you will not regret it.
3 run speed increase. with the amount of running you will do from A to B to C in this game - it will save you a few hours of your time, otherwise spend on simple running back and fourth.

While this game has a number of issues - it's still by far the best One Piece game in existance to date (yeah, previous were way worse imo). For a franchise admirer, even despite all my rant, it's worth a buy to at least enjoy the close-ups of the favourite characters and some of their banter. But for an outsider - it's a typical mediocre j-rpg and if you are into the j-rpg's there are better time sinks around, like the "trail" or "atelier" series, Tales of Arise or the soon to be released FF-XVI.

So, in conclusion:
One Piece fan? Buy it.
Not a fan? Skip it, you won't lose much.

I was looking forward to this, but it gets boring and repetitive very fast.  There's a lot of stuff in here that is just meant to waste your time.  After you get through the first memory and it sends you back to the overworld, it makes you trudge all the way through the first memory again on foot to get the thing you need to advance to the next area.

I have completed the game, including all of the achievements.  The following is my fair assessment of the game's strengths and weaknesses, and I trend towards the technical, especially when it comes to nitpicks.

Short version: If you aren't a One Piece fan, you might want to give this one a miss.  Enjoyment of this game is extremely dependent on this factor.

As a JRPG, this game is extremely laid back.  You will not find any real challenge until the very end, and then essentially only with the optional content outside of the story.  This was definitely one of my main gripes with the game.  But I eventually realized that this was done in order to keep the gameplay loop from interfering with the story progression.  By and large, the game is balanced so that as long as you defeat every map enemy you see exactly once, you're set.  Balanced both in terms of enemy difficulty and tolerable enjoyment.  By that I mean this game doesn't inspire a desire to grind for levels, nor does it require this from the player.

The story is exactly what you would expect: A contrivance is conjured to provide an excuse for the Strawhats to relive the events of the story, just as generally occurs in the Pirate Warriors games.  There is a LOT of dialogue from just about everyone in the anime.  Enough to fill a season.  This helps considerably in selling the idea that you're taking part in the anime.

The combat has a surprisingly functional gimmick that perpetually inspires the player to do more than hit attack—fights simply take too long to finish if one is literally that lazy.  And here is where the game's biggest strength shines: The character animations for various attacks are extremely well done.  Easily the highest tier of competence in the game was lavished right here.  This turns out to be important, since fighting ends up being about half of what they player does in this game.

The music is serviceable with the occasional shining moment.  It's certainly not completely forgettable, but also not something you'd add to your playlist.  It's about as good as, say, the average Sakuraba OST—this is not praise, but not a condemnation.  It would have been surprising if the soundtrack had been amazing, but I wasn't expecting it to be.  As is tradition with anime-turned-game, there are ZERO references to the anime's music, front to back.

Sound effects are about on par here.  Just like with the music, even when there were definitely certain sounds that are always used in the anime for certain moments—such as Sanji's air hop, or the sound of Law's Room ability—the game doesn't tap those sounds and instead just comes up with something of its own.  Disappointing, but entirely within precedent.

This game uses an accessory system that has no meaningful balance.  In a game where difficulty simply does not come into play, it could be argued that a lack of balance doesn't matter.  Indeed, I just about ignored the accessories until I reached the end of the game and began grinding out the remainder of the levels, at which point I went about as ham as I could with making my characters overpowered... because the endgame/post-game is the only time when the content is actually truly balanced against those accessories.  This feels like the correct way to approach the accessory topic: Don't pay much attention to them until you reach the end, and then go crazy.  It's satisfying that the game DOES give the player a reason to grind out some powerful accessories, if only at the very end.

Exploration is there, but not much rewarded.  Things are only rarely cleverly hidden.  Luffy gets a haki detection ability that's intended to find hidden items, but actually discovering anything with said ability is extremely rare and, if you will pardon the mild spoiler, almost entirely limited to moments when you've fought a new boss—you almost invariably locate their codex entry if you do a search.  Since there are no rewards or achievements tied to this, the only incentive is headcanon completionism.  The same thing goes for finding hidden items that only Sanji and Nami can see: They're there, at least, but you get nothing unique out of it, the game doesn't reward you, and it's all headcanon.  The exception to this is Robin, whose hidden items are required if one is interested in finishing the game's list of tasks.

Small nitpick: This is the kind of game that will inexplicably hide food items and ingredients in chests.  Meaning you'd better be prepared not to treat this game as something immersive.  Treasure chests tucked away in dungeons for who knows how long will very frequently contain MEALS.  Meals which SHOULD have been something only Sanji could prepare for you.

The graphics are better than I expected them to be.  With a 3080, the game can be played at a flat 4K 60fps from start to finish, and the only hiccups I ever saw were in the "strange place", possibly because the room is very busy and shows every crew member simultaneously.  Unfortunately, because the engine is UE4, one has very little choice but to use temporal anti-aliasing, which always causes afterimages on objects moving in contrast with the background.  Comically, the pre-rendered cutscenes, which always play at 30fps, were very clearly rendered in UE4 themselves, as they ALSO reveal the artifacting characteristic of TAA.

My recommendation of this game is a bit like how I might recommend a One Piece movie: It's a spinoff, but it treats the property with respect and care, it uses the real voice cast fair and square, and it has a pretty high production value.  Fans of the anime are the target audience.  Pure JRPG fans should probably stay away unless you're out of options and need that blank filled.

Boring, easy, repetitive. Unfortunate for a game I was extremely hype for, 90% of the moves are the exact same with the same effects but different damage numbers, meaning using anything other than your best it pointless because your resource can be charged up in basically 1 turn. I've enjoyed pretty much all one piece games i've played by this one falls flat. The Story and characters are extremely predictable and nothing really new was added. There was a scene in dessrosa that felt very ham fisted as nice as it was. (you know what i mean if you've played) and if you haven't don't.
Very chill game for fans of One PIece. If you love a challenge, this game may not be for you. But if you love chilling around with the Strawhat crew, this game offers some quality time of just that!
lots of bazongas 10/10 very worth it

They treat me like a disabled child. They have to explain everything and force you to follow the path that the developers drew for you, even though the game is an open world, but all roads are wrong and only one is right. Also, you cannot discover that this path is wrong because you will not be able to take it. You cannot discover the game in your own way.
The game's boring, easy, and I don't like the way they hamfisted the characters getting nerfed for the story to even happen.
If you are a big fan of One Piece then this game is good for you.
.it's a good game with a good story.
I like one piece

applist.name: Killing Floor 2
applist.detailed_description:
Just Updated

Happy Holidays! Just in time for Xmas we're excited to bring you the Polar Distress Update for Killing Floor 2! Details below...


Blood & Bonfires Update

Happy Halloween! The Killing Floor 2 Blood & Bonfires Update is here! Details below...


Tidal Terror Update

The 2022 Killing Floor 2 Summer Update and Event is here! Read all about TIDAL TERROR below...


Chop 'Til You Drop Xmas Update

The Killing Floor 2 Chop 'Til You Drop Xmas Update is here! Details below:


Day Of The Zed Update

The Killing Floor 2: Day Of The Zed Update is here just in time for Halloween! For more information on the new content check out the Official Tripwire Forums here:

https://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/index.php?categories/killing-floor-2.25/


Interstellar Insanity Update

The Killing Floor 2: Interstellar Insanity Update is here just in time for Summer! For more information on the new content check out the Official Tripwire Forums here:

https://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/index.php?categories/killing-floor-2.25/


Dystopian Devastation Update

The Killing Floor 2: Dystopian Devastation Update is here just in time for Spring! For more information on the new content check out the Official Tripwire Forums here:

https://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/index.php?categories/killing-floor-2.25/


Digital Deluxe Edition


KILLING FLOOR 2 Digital Deluxe Edition adds the following to the base game:

  • DJ Scully character, with unique voice pack and set of face/body skins
  • Additional cosmetic items (each with multiple selectable variants):
  • “Scullyphones” headphones for DJ Scully, Mr Foster, Hayato Tanaka and Donovan Neal
  • 3D Glasses for Ana Larive and Hayato Tanaka
  • Bowler Hat for Mr. Foster and Reverend Alberts
  • Tom Banner and the Zweihander
  • Classic Masterson
  • Classic Briar
  • Oisten Jaegerhorn
  • Anton Strasser
  • Killing Floor 2 Soundtrack
  • Killing Floor 2 Digital Artbook

AND a copy of the first Killing Floor!


About the Game

In KILLING FLOOR 2, players descend into continental Europe where the outbreak caused by Horzine Biotech’s failed experiment has quickly spread and gained unstoppable momentum, essentially paralyzing the European Union— Just one month after the events in the original KILLING FLOOR, the specimen clones are everywhere and civilization is in disarray; communications have failed, governments have collapsed, and military forces have been systematically eradicated. The people of Europe know survival and self-preservation too well and lucky survivors have gone into hiding.

Not all have given up hope though... A group of civilians and mercenaries have banded together to combat the outbreak and established privately funded operation bases across Europe. Upon tracking specimen clone outbreaks, players will descend into zed-laden hot zones and exterminate them.

KEY FEATURES:

• Visceral Gore - KILLING FLOOR 2 ramps up the gore with a proprietary, high powered persistent blood system bringing new levels of fidelity to the genre. Players will send entrails, severed limbs, and blood flying as they wade through hordes of enemies. But they need to watch out! If caught, enemies will rip them, and their entire party limb from limb


• 6 player co-op or solo play— A multitude of varied playable characters await for players to choose from as they enter the fray in online co-op mode or solo mode for those willing to brave the horrific specimens alone


• Versus Survival Game Mode - Be the Zed! A 12 player PvP mode where two teams take turns playing Humans vs. Zeds in a pair of short matches. In the first match, one team plays Humans and the other Zeds until the humans all die during a single round or they beat the boss. For the second match the teams switch sides and when the battle is completed both teams receive a score based on their performance and the higher score wins!


• Terrifying Zeds - New enemies and fan favorites from the original game are back with expanded and smarter artificial intelligence, dishing out powerful attacks, working as a group to weaken the player’s party and pushing the challenge level and fear factor to new levels


• Unique Blend Of Weaponry - From modern militaristic assault rifles, brutal improvised makeshift weapons, classic historical guns, and off the wall “Mad Scientist” weapons, KILLING FLOOR 2 has a unique blend of killing tools that will satisfy any gamer


• Expanded Perk System - Perks from the original game have been reimagined with more added to the fold. All perks now progress with meaningful talent choices that amplify different play styles, giving players a progression path that is expansive and full of rewarding milestones


• Brutal Melee Combat - KILLING FLOOR 2 reinvents melee combat completely. Players now have control over the type of melee attacks they can perform, enabling them to deliver bone-breaking crippling attacks to Zeds


• Zed Time - Be the action hero you know you are! Zed Time returns to Killing Floor 2 better than ever, kicking everything into slow motion giving you that precious time you need to destroy the oncoming horde while watching your weapons at work in glorious high framerate

KILLING FLOOR 2 Digital Deluxe Edition adds the following to the base game:
  • DJ Scully character, with unique voice pack and set of face/body skins
  • Additional cosmetic items (each with multiple selectable variants):
  • “Scullyphones” headphones for DJ Scully, Mr Foster, Hayato Tanaka and Donovan Neal
  • 3D Glasses for Ana Larive and Hayato Tanaka
  • Bowler Hat for Mr. Foster and Reverend Alberts
  • Tom Banner and the Zweihander
  • Classic Masterson
  • Classic Briar
  • Oisten Jaegerhorn
  • Anton Strasser
  • Killing Floor 2 Soundtrack
  • Killing Floor 2 Digital Artbook

AND a copy of the first Killing Floor!

[b]Positive Points[/b]:

➜ Delivers an intense cooperative experience where players team up to survive waves of horrifying enemies. The game's focus on teamwork, communication, and strategy adds depth to the gameplay, making it highly engaging and satisfying.

➜ Combat is fast-paced, visceral, and improved compared to its predecessor. The game offers a wide variety of weapons with detailed animations and realistic gunplay. The addition of melee attacks, gore effects, and dismemberment mechanics further enhances the combat experience.

➜ Introduces a wide array of enemies, each with unique abilities, behaviors, and attack patterns. From hulking brutes to agile crawlers, the diverse enemy types keep the gameplay fresh and challenging, requiring players to adapt their strategies and weapon choices accordingly.

➜ Impressive visual and audio design. The detailed environments, high-quality textures, and atmospheric lighting create a dark and immersive atmosphere. The sound effects and music heighten the tension and contribute to the overall intensity of the gameplay.

[b]Negative Points[/b]:

➜ Primarily focuses on its core gameplay mode, which involves surviving waves of enemies. While this mode is enjoyable, the game lacks additional modes or variations, potentially leading to a sense of repetition over time.

➜ Similar to its predecessor, lacks a strong narrative or significant character development. The game's primary focus is on gameplay and cooperative action, so players looking for a rich story-driven experience might find it lacking in this aspect.

➜ Can have a steep learning curve. The game does provide some tutorials and guidance, but mastering the mechanics, understanding enemy behavior, and effectively coordinating with teammates can take time and practice.

➜ Primarily designed as an online multiplayer experience. While there is an offline mode available, it lacks certain features and can feel less engaging compared to the cooperative online gameplay.

[u]Killing Floor 2[/u] excels in delivering an intense and challenging cooperative shooter experience. With its improved combat mechanics, diverse enemy variety, impressive visuals, and immersive sound design, the game offers hours of thrilling gameplay. While the limited gameplay modes, lack of narrative depth, steep learning curve, and limited offline play may be potential downsides, fans of cooperative shooters and intense action will likely find Killing Floor 2 to be an enjoyable and worthwhile game.

applist.name: Tiny Tina's Wonderlands
applist.detailed_description:
Tiny Tina's Wonderlands: Chaotic Great Edition


THE CHAOTIC GREAT EDITION INCLUDES:

  • Full Game
  • Season Pass (Includes the Butt Stallion Pack, Blightcaller class, and 4 dungeons with new bosses, loot, and environments)
  • Dragon Lord Pack Bonus Content


About the Game

Party up with friends in cross-platform multiplayer!

Embark on an epic adventure full of whimsy, wonder, and high-powered weaponry! Bullets, magic, and broadswords collide across this chaotic fantasy world brought to life by the unpredictable Tiny Tina.
Roll your own multiclass hero and loot, shoot, slash, and cast your way through outlandish monsters and loot-filled dungeons on a quest to stop the tyrannical Dragon Lord. Everyone's welcome, so join the party, throw on your adventuring boots, and be Chaotic Great!

AN UNPREDICTABLE FANTASY WORLD

Tiny Tina is your disorderly guide through an extraordinary tabletop realm where rules rarely apply. Explore a vast overworld spanning majestic cities, dank mushroom forests, foreboding fortresses, and more!

GUNS, SPELLS, AND MORE

Blast baddies with powerful guns and devastating spells in frenetic first-person battles. Use your firepower to vanquish legions of enemies, including smack-talking skeletons, land-roaming sharks, and colossal bosses. Then delve deeper into dangerous dungeons for a shot at epic loot!

PARTY UP TO DEFEAT EVIL

Joining you at the table are headstrong captain Valentine and rule-obsessed robot Frette. During your quest to defeat the Dragon Lord, you'll meet a cast of lovable misfits like a lute-wielding Bardbarian and your very own Fairy Punchfather.

PERSONALIZE YOUR HERO

Create the perfect hero with deep customization, including a multiclass system that lets you mix and match six unique character skill trees, all with their own awesome abilities. Level up, refine your build, expand your arsenal, and become the ultimate adventurer.

BAND TOGETHER IN CHAOTIC CO-OP

Enjoy the story solo or start a party with up to three friends in seamless online multiplayer. Share the spoils or rush to get the shiniest loot—how you play is up to you!
