reviews.review:
This is more a 'meh' review than an actual negative one. The presentation is fine, but the game runs quite poorly for how it looks. The overworld as a way to connect locations isn't a bad idea, but it does feel a bit too less developed. The named instances for the most part are fun to play, but the rest of the content is fighting in rather short arenas that don't differ that much throughout the game.

That's my main problem with the game: The actually written content you get is good, but it's clear that it was padded with a lot of same-ish encounters. Most quests in the overworld are 'Go to arena and get item' which gets boring very quick. For 20-30 bucks this game is okay, but not for 60. Oh and stay away from the DLC. It is not worth it at all.

This game is just not good, it's soooo boring. It could have been a solid entry in the franchise but it's just meh, the combat is unfulfilling, the enemies tedious. It's a painful experience once that I didn't bother to finish because I simply lost interest. Instead I fired up Borderlands 2, a 10 year old game crushes TTW in every way that matters. This game is just not fun.

Been going down hill since BL2. Sadly i likely wont purchase any more games in this series. The quality just keeps getting worse. Who ever had the secret formula to a fun game back then must be gone and taken it with them.

bought and played on release. Overall a really cool combination of Borderlands and Fantasy/D&D. The game by itself is very good, but with co-op it falls apart. It's connection is very unstable, no matter your internet quality. I was horrified to see that the co-op instability STILL hasnt been fixed since release, almost a year ago... Co-op is a hugeee thing for me on borderlands games, very disappointing that it doesnt function properly in this game. Regardless, still great single player fun.
There are entire comedy TV shows that never manage to be as funny as the vending machines in this game

This is possibly the single most underwhelming game I've ever played,
I went into this game with high hopes as I've really enjoyed the other borderlands games,
the abilities for the most part feel like re-skins from previous games, 
most of the spells and guns do less damage than a wet fart in the wind and the gun generation is extremely repetitive
the characters just don't really stand up against the other games.
and that doesn't even mention the incredible amount of game breaking bugs that me and my friends experienced whilst playing, one of us crashed 5 times in 10 minutes...
is it too much to ask for a game to be playable these days?
Might play again if it gets patched for the game breaking stuff but as it is i wont be launching this again.
Lots of silly fantasy fun.

[b][u]Introduction[/u][/b]
To preface this review, I haven't currently finished the main story of the game, might make an update If needed by the end. I have only played Borderlands 2 before this and I have not played the DLC this game was based on. I'm playing 3 player co-op with friends, coming out of playing BL2.

[b][u]Player Characters, Customisation[/u][/b]
Character customisation was cool, It's fun being able to make a character and pick a voice, however the options feel a bit lackluster, especially when It comes to the hair and outfit. All the player character voices seem to be British but none of those voice actors are British and yeah, It Is noticeable lol. There are 4 voices and "personalities" but they all say the same things and act the same way. Whilst making your own character Is Interesting, the fact they all act the same sucks out the personality and charm that player characters had In the other games.

[b][u]World and Setting[/u][/b]
I loved the world going Into It, and a lot of the settings are absolutely gorgeous, they feel so colourful, fun and full of creativity, I adore them. But they feel too closed off. I think If the game played like a typical Borderlands, It'd feel so much better. I know the other game was instanced, but you FEEL It more In this game, as opposed to the instances being sort of walled off by gates and such, there's just an invisible wall here, and some of the levels are EXTREMELY small, and you feel really boxed In, and they get repetitive, especially for random encounters and side quests. 

[b][u]Story and Missions with the World[/u][/b]
Anything that Isn't the main mission feels a lot more half arsed and boring, like no effort went Into that half of the game, but the main story section feels pretty well done SO FAR, with epic cutscene moments and fantastic world design, I just feel like my immersion Is ruined when I witness something amazing happen to the landscape, only to walk fourth Into It to run Into an invisible wall and get teleported to the DND board overworld. I get that the game Is a parody based on a DND board game, and It was kind of funny and cool but sometimes It just sucks you out of It, and feels a little lazy to some extent. I think If anything, DND players love immersion and getting sucked In, but that part takes you out of what's happening for a while.

[b][u]Weapons and Combat[/u][/b]
Weapons, armour, whatever, It's all okay I suppose. The design of some of the weapons are really cool, but everything feels somewhat weak. Grenades are exchanged for magic spells, which there are a variety of. I do enjoy some of the spells, they are definitely cool, but some feel weaker than others or difficult to control. Melee weapons feel TOO weak In this game, like you're getting all up In the enemies business just to do way less damage than just using a gun would do, It's like high risk anti-reward. 

The store was confusing to me at first, I ended up accidentally selling all my equipped items because they show up with everything else you sell apparently LOL. The battle also feels unsatisfying compared to the last game with all the colourful numbers showing up as you fight the enemies, It feels really lacking In this game. I know the enemies are probably repetitive In all the games, but I just FEEL It more here for some reason, I'm so bored of killing skeletons, and now we're In a new zone, we're fighting crabs, which are really annoying, they are tiny, fast and have a shell that makes ur damage look like a joke. 

Another issue with combat Is, we can never tell when someone has died In this game, we have to just say on com's that one of us died. In BL2, there'd be an indicator on your screen with a sound when someone died so you always knew, but I find myself missing It all the time In this game. Also there's small things like I swear there's enemies with explosives on their backs that don't explode when you shoot them but that might be a nitpick, It just feels lame.

[b][u]Inclusivity[/u][/b]
Something I do like about the game Is how It feels more inclusive, I thought the range of characters and voice actors of different identities and ideals was pretty neat. You can also pick from a set of pronouns for your character. 

[b][u]DLC[/u][/b]
I'm not sure If the other games did this, but the DLC also feels shoehorned In a bit, like you're shown a class that you can't use, or worlds you COULD access with the DLC even though you don't have It, and are just told to go to the store. Looking at the reviews for the DLC, I'm assuming that's not a good Idea.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
I'm probably forgetting some things I want to say right now, but It just boils down to feeling boring, boxed In and unsatisfying. You can't get immersed Into this world, It feels stringed together and like nothing connects. The concept It great and I LOVE the worlds and stuff they have In here, they could have make something Incredible here but It just fell a bit short, especially If you're comparing It to the other games In the franchise.

This game Is not worth the curiosity, even If you're a fantasy fan. The game Is WAY too expensive, even on half price It's around £30, which Is In the high price range for me and my friends, I can't even imagine having paid In full for this. I can't justify It even at the half-way mark, It sucks, now I feel guilty for getting all my friends to spend so much on It, and I'm feeling forced to keep playing It just to feel like I got my.. or "our" moneys worth. I dread having to play It, and can't wait for It to end.

The (base) game is not worth the 60€ price tag and probably not even the 30€ that I got it at. Skyrim with My Little Pony mod installed feels more Borderlands than this.

The story of the game follows the familiar Borderlands format, with two caveats: there's basically no NPCs that follow you through the story, which is incredibly short. Sure, Tiny Tina and the Bad Guy narrate your adventures, but you're not regularly interacting with any recurring NPCs and there's very few familiar faces scattered about. For example, I would've expected Roland and Mr. Torgue to play significant parts in the game, what with their relationships with Tina. NPCs, in general, are entirely forgettable, with some minor exceptions.

While the overworld map that connects all of the different zones is a neat idea and I like the various items scattered across it, I feel that it is very lacking in execution and is thoroughly undermined by the fast travel system. Either the overworld or the fast travel system should not exist. Additionally, the approximately four or five maps that are there for the so-called combat/random encounters in the overworld get incredibly boring, incredibly fast. 

Speaking of maps, they are all very generic fantasy natural-scenery maps: there's a bit of grasslands, woods, city, sea floor and pirate beach. These are all fine and dandy, but the variety is significantly lacking in comparison to prior Borderlands titles. There's no volcano or underground biomes, for example, and what maps are there are very unimpressive visually.

The maps feature four primary factions: skeletons, greenskins, fungi and coiled (naga). None of the four factions have distinct mechanics or gameplay elements; there's nothing along the lines of skeletaurs, goliaths or hyperion bots at least before whatever is the equivalent of TVHM in this game. Technically, there's also pirates and bandits, but these are barely even visually distinct from skeletons, let alone mechanically. Scattered between the forces of the main factions are some fantastical beasts, such as wyverns and dogfish, which do distinguish themselves from one another.

With the fantasy theme come spells, which replace grenades and come with an automatic recharge mechanic. While some spells are incredibly powerful and feel great to activate as they can destroy an entire wave of enemies and put a huge dent even into badasses, most spells are lackluster and usually worse than firing a gun. The variety of spells is pretty good, but I wish that anything besides fissures actually had any "oomph" at all. For example, meteors come with a significant cast delay and have _tiny_ impact areas by comparison and absurd recharge times to boot.

Alongside spells there are the class-based skills. There are exactly three interesting skills: polymorph, invisibility and reaper of bones, though ambi-hextrous deserves an honorable mention for conceding that the spells are strictly more interesting than the action skills. Everything else is of the format "press button to deal damage", which is confusing at best considering how easily many of the action skills in Borderlands titles could have been reskinned with a fantasy theme. 

Skill modifiers also do not exist, which combined with the above leads to every class feeling basically the same despite having extremely distinct themes. Your choices are to either shoot at stuff or hit them with your sword/axe/mace. None of the skill trees feel like a substantial change to how I play the game.

As there is only a single skill tree for every class, an opportunity to "multiclass" is presented. This essentially means slapping on the passives from another class to your initially chosen class. Don't forget to google the skill trees before you lock in, because the game does not actually give you any indication as to what the choice entails beyond a "this class is good at fire damage" when choosing and I don't know whether it is even possible to choose again. Nor do I really care, because why would I when there is essentially no difference?

You can freely choose your character's body shape, pronoun and voice independent of one another, which is nice, I guess, if I cared about any of that and if all of them weren't so incredibly bland. I have always enjoyed the various quips, puns and dialogue of the Borderlands player characters, but that does not materialize here.

All characters look essentially the same and outfits — the visually most distinctive part of your character — are tied to your class mod. There seems to only be a small handful of variants, all of which look the same. If you thought you could be a robot-ninja-pirate, think again. The color/pattern alterations you can make to your outfit are also incredibly bland and require you to find them as drops from enemies or from collectibles scattered around the world. If you thought Borderlands 3 had bad customization options with the ugly-ass head and body options, you really don't want to see what Wonderlands has to offer.

TL;DR: it's bland. Buying and playing the DLC again is a better use of your time and money.

TLDR; Don't pay more than $30 MAX preferably $20

Pros: guns are cool. "multi classing" is fun. good VA's
Cons: UI feels more cluttered than other Borderlands games. LOTS of dialog.

I want to like the game but I can't. There is way too much dialog that blocks you from progressing. There are so many times in this game where i just have to sit there and wait for pointless dialog to finish so i can move forward. It made the game so unenjoyable that I couldn't finish the game.

Not sure why so many people complained about this game being too short, it took me over 40 hours to finish the story with still a few side quests to do and plenty of collectables left to gather. That's plenty of game and honestly it got a bit samey after a while anyway. After about halfway through you've pretty much seen all the enemy types in the game so the combat can get repetitive. That said it is also very fun if you're just after more Borderlands. The inclusion of spells is a nice change from grenades for the franchise, though I'll admit I pretty much used only 1 or 2 different spell types because having to hold down a button for several seconds looking at the point you want to cast a spell leaves you a vulnerable so got annoying. Good variety of classes and more interesting perk upgrades than usual.

Now the bad stuff. The game is way too easy. I rarely died and if I did it was because I missed a jump or accidentally bashed an exploding barrel thinking it was a regular one. Most boss fights were over within a matter of seconds with no strategy needed to defeat them. Ammo crates are spammed every 5 metres you walk so you never run out of ammo and have to change weapon so you only do so when you get bored. The UI is pretty poor. For example, to put a way point down on the map you think it would make sense that you could just click on the map where your mouse cursor is right? Well apparently not, because you have to drag your mouse across the screen to move the map cursor to the point on the map you want the way point to be. It's really awkward. Also the characters in the game apart from Tiny Tina are really lame and annoying. Not quite as bad as in BL3 but not far off. It was cringe inducing stuff.

There's a good game to be had, but the incessant chatter from cringey dialogue and laughably easy combat makes it easy to forget that the core gun play is the only thing holding this game together.
no claptrap

I love me some borderlands. I picked up the assault on dragons keep for free and was digging the style so I snagged the game. It is embarrassingly short. I missed this when it came out and didn't read any reviews because it's borderlands. The game is beautiful, the cross with D&D is fun, the over world I thought was a nice edition. I was taking my time doing lots of side quest and such and beat the game on accident. They put a lot of effort into the game so I can't understand why you wouldn't write a better story. Sad. If this was a ten dollar game sure, but full price for the rubbish story is a big disappointment. They want you to buy all this DLC when the game is shallow is a slap in the face. Shame.

My brother and I decided to try it. 5 hours later we decided to end our trial.
We couldn't take the non-stop talkin, lamenting, joking and references. We just wanted to loot and shoot but there was so much down time between the actual shooting... 
we didn't want to find out if there will be actually more looting and shooting.

[h1]NOT RECOMMENDED - MY REVIEW[/h1]

[b][u]COMBAT (4/10)[/u]
-Extremely repetitive. You'll fight through the same combat arenas over and over again whilst clearing out bandit camps and dungeons etc.
-There's a solid range in weapons and magic, but again, over time this will become repetitive and you'll genuinely find yourself getting bored. 

[b][u]STORY (2/10)[/u]
-The story seems like it's tailored for an audience of five year old's or teens with the sense of humour of a toddler. For me, it didn't really draw me in that much as the boss fights were lackluster along with the rest of the combat. Nothing felt really special. 
-There's an abundance of left-wing wokeness in this game. You have trans/gay pirates, pronouns, gender-neutral terminology, so on so forth. I don't play a game to be surrounded by political propaganda.

[b][u]THE OPEN WORLD/EXPLORATION (6/10)[/u]
-The Overworld is poorly designed and looks terrible. 'Nuff said. 
-The area's you'll go into all unique in their own way, and host a lot of side-quests (which I'll touch on later in this review), which is somewhat of a good thing. 
-These unique areas can be quite large and repetitive however, so you'll find yourself getting bored after only a few hours of playing. 

[b][u]SIDE-QUESTS (3/10)[/u]
-The side quests feel the same as the main story - very plain and boring. "Go from A to B to collect or kill XYZ". You'll fight against the same enemies spouting the same two voice lines they have over and over again. Very boring and tedious. 

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS (6/10)[/u]
-I've been unlocking a few achievements just by playing through the main story and the side quests, but I've taken the time to look at the rest of the achievements for 100% completion. If you look at my profile you'll realise that I'm a fan of 100% games, but I don't think I'll be able to bring myself to do it for this one. The niche achievements look very boring and way too grind-filled. At this time I'm not planning on completing this game with all achievements, but if that changes I'll be sure to update this review. 

[b][u]VOICE ACTING (8/10[/u]
-The voice acting in this game was good, done by some familiar names such as Andy Samberg. At the end of the day you can't blame the cast for bad writing. They did their job well for this game and how bad the writing was. Hats off to them. 
-You can see the full cast here https://www.imdb.com/title/tt14831458/

[b][u]SUMMARY/OVERALL SCORE = 4.8/10[/u]
-I purchased this game at 33% off and would not recommend anyone to buy it at full price. The game was enjoyable for the first few hours, but after that everything this game provided became repetitive, and the cringe writing became unbearable. The voice acting was good, and the weapons/spells were mostly enjoyable, but everything else about this game is just plain boring.
Like Borderlands but fun
mid
no tvm

The base game is good. The story is ok with a lot of the humour that you would expect and some old favorites (or hated chars...hehe) returning for some banter along a board game, its not a bad move since this has been done in BL 2 with great success. However, it is quite shallow and since it is a board game it does not really engage me in the story, but it was ok, nothing special at all but ok.

Gunplay is great as usual, builds are fun to explore etc. But.... the DLCs are so bad I do not even have words for it, next time just add more items in the game with the patch and skip the teedious quests that takes away the tempo of the game and offers zero in interesting lore. The DLCs are pure shir, sorry for the language. They are all annoying to do compared to BL content overall and there is ZERO story or rewards to care about apart from some new items. 

Late game farm is not terrible. I will for sure spend more time doing more builds etc. But keeping track of gear in the stash with no possibility to word search etc. is a bit of a joke by now. Having multiple chars with one bank with sortiing and scrolling being the only options for overview is beyond bad. Lots of bugs still but that does not matter for me, yet, since none are game breaking. 

A really good game overall for new players (i think, if they only want to go through it and maybe spend a few hours more after last boss) but for BL standards I give it 6/10 since it could have been so much better.

applist.name: Warhammer 40,000: Inquisitor - Martyr
applist.detailed_description:
Sororitas Class DLC out now!

https://store.steampowered.com/app/2138210


About the Game

A STORY-DRIVEN SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN

Far from the guiding light of the God-Emperor, torn apart by the foul tempests that distort reality, the Caligari Sector is slowly rotting away from the inside, tainted by the Chaos Gods. Purge the unclean with the most powerful agents of the Imperium!


Warhammer 40,000: Inquisitor – Martyr is grim action-RPG set in the violent 41st millennium, when the galaxy is at constant war. Become a mighty Inquisitor and carry out the Emperor’s will. Choose one of the multiple classes and take part in brutal combat encounters: embark on a huge variety of missions with your fellow agents and fight through the single-player story campaign set on a haunted fortress-monastery which hides a terrible secret from the past of the Inquisition.

THE NEXT MILESTONE IN THE EVOLUTION OF ARPGS


The first Action-RPG set in the grim future of the 41st Millennium takes the genre to its next level: an open-world sandbox game with a persistent universe with a huge variety of missions, tactical, brutal combat encounters in destructible environments and a storyline influenced by the community of players. Use the cover system for tactical advantage, perform executions in epic boss battles and become a Protector of any solar systems with your glorious actions!

INQUISITORS: SECRET AGENTS AND SPECIALISTS


Forge your own playstyle with different character classes and specializations: hold your ground with the Crusader Inquisitor while enemies close in on you, bring in your finesse and cunning with the Death Cult Assassin background, or use the unspeakable powers of the Warp with the Primaris Psyker background. Choose from three specializations for each classes that fit your playstyle.

TRAVERSE A WHOLE GALACTIC SECTOR


Explore the Star Map of the vast Caligari Sector, travel in different subsectors and explore an immense amount of solar systems, visit a growing number of unique points of interests: investigate on different planets with distinctive terrain conditions, fight your way through corridors of infested Void Stations, abandoned Star Forts and other diverse environments!

FIGHT THE CORRUPTION TOGETHER


You can go solo as a lonely Inquisitor, but you can also assemble a team of your friends! Play missions in co-operative mode with up to 4 team members, blast away your foes together claiming great rewards, and form Cabals to gather your close allies! Inquisitorial Cabals are groups of Inquisitors working together. Cabals can progress just like characters do, and being a member can often grant special missions. The Inquisition has a lot of different factions with different agendas, and Cabals sometimes clash with each other in the shadows.

IMPROVE YOUR WEAPONS, CRAFT MISSIONS AND TWEAK YOUR SKILLS


Looking for a specific loot or reward? Use Uther’s Tarot to set the conditions of your next mission, collect Blueprints and use Crafting to improve your equipment, and use the Inoculator to fine-tune your different skills. Choose your loadout to your advantage for each mission!

A LIVING, EXPANDING WORLD

Warhammer 40,000: Inquisitor – Martyr is an ever-growing, long-lasting experience. Expansions and regular free updates will introduce new enemy factions, new terrain settings, new missions and mission types, new story-driven investigations and new gameplay features.
Chapters are big, free updates that will introduce longer story arcs in which players can shape the persistent world of the Caligari sector with their actions. Global Events and Chapters ensure new challenges – there’s always something new to explore or to collect!

reviews.review: Game is unplayable because it's always online and I am disconected mid missions. Can't even play solo.

Aside from some occasional control issues when Items clutter the battle field during a fight and the game prioritizes looking at them instead of moving, or fighting, or pretty much doing anything other than staring at the floor and taking the beating, its pretty fun.

90 percent of the time the game is like firing a howitzer into a koi pond, but then again, sometimes its just nice to be fishing.

Ultimately, If its on sale and you're looking for some mindless mayhem with a coat of Warhammer paint on it, Inquisitor is worth the look.

First thing I will say this game has no business being Online-Only.
It's a massive restriction that's annoying and limits the potential of the game.

The game is good I recommend you get it on sale.
However most of the negatives you see from other reviews about the game are 90% true and real.

I personally love playing the game when listening to an Album/Podcast in the background.
The Graphics, Story and Gameplay is pretty well-done, even though the level design could be improved on.

The Game is absolutely god-aweful at explaining how the systems works.
I spent most of the time reading the in-game Journal to even understand what most of the things mean or do.
All the 'tutorial' and 'hints' are useless, they never tell you anything important.

Only when I was 40+ Hours in did I find out my 'Sororitas' can turn into an 'Embodied Saint' for a period of time because the game never tells you.
I had to find out about the 'Tarot Card' system from a YouTube video about the game.

So most of the charm about the will definitely be missed for new players like myself.
Buy the game on sale it's really fun but will be difficult and a bit repetitive later on.

When I started playing this game, all of its problems drove me nuts.  (Most of the negative comments and issues described in the other reviews are accurate.)  But nevertheless, after a while I was hooked.  The setting is appropriately grimdark, the music is great, the combat is a lot of fun, and although there are only a few classes there is a lot of customization available to keep things interesting.  The dialogue is inane, but this is Warhammer; what else would you expect?  Some of the voice acting is hideously awful though.  It sounds like one of the devs recruited their middle-school kids to do it between dinner and homework.  The main story and sidequests are engaging, and the random missions are fun for multiple replays.  Co-op is available, and has an auto-leveling feature.  PvP is supposedly available, but I never have tried it.  There are co-op and PvP lobbies available, and joinable "cabals", but these features appear to be pretty dead at present.  The devs made a serious effort to overhaul the game after its initial mediocre reviews, but it's pretty clear that they've moved on so not much more will happen with the game. 

If you like "Grim Dawn" or "Torchlight 2" you will probably like this game.  I really can't speak for Diablo fans because I didn't like it, but it's the same general concept so if you liked Diablo there's a good chance it will interest you.  Also, if you like the Warhammer 40,000 universe, it captures that atmosphere and should appeal to you on that level.  It has a lot of problems that the other reviews describe in detail, so you should definitely wait for a Steam sale.  (And although I don't have the "Sororitas" DLC, it is clearly not worth full price because there is no additional content, aside from the class itself.)  The Emperor Protects!

EDIT: I should add that a really fun feature is the destructibility of various objects and terrain features.  Eldar shooting at you from behind barrels?  Blast the barrels out of the way!  Tyrannids under a pillar?  Bring it down on top of them!  Just in a bad mood and got a big gun? Destroy everything you can!  Also, the smaller terrain features often have rewards when destroyed.  Usually it's only a bit of money, but sometimes you can find  health, supplies or equipment.  Long Live The Imperium!
At least its not a Blizzard game.
Consistently crashes after the first level. I really want to like this game but oh well.
Pretty relaxing game about mass murder

A quick overview of the game's post-release evolution. When this game released, it felt very sluggish  - moving, engaging, looting all felt slow. The devs did a massive overhaul of combat, increasing movement speed, combat moves and cooldowns, and there are simple loot filter and auto-pickup options (neither of which need to be enabled. They are off by default). This level of attention after the release of the game, when other devs might have moved on, is remarkable to me. They took a game that was Not Bad and made it into something very memorable to me.

After that overhaul, seasons with unique season mechanics began. These have unique mechanics that cause enemies and/or anomalies to appear in normal missions and interacting with these give you progress toward season-specific boss missions. The season will also have a new type of affix that can now appear on weapons (such as one affix that allows you to release lightning on hit or being hit while other affixes combine to make it chain longer or do more damage, etc). There are also the equivalent of runewords (psalm-code doctrines) and the components can be removed at any time and leave both the item and components intact for use in other gear.

The sound is good, especially the fighting sounds of guns, melee, fire, explosions and more. There's nothing like jump packing into a mob that explodes as you use a las cannon or flamer to melt the survivors. The story is fine though nothing to write home about. Leveling is steady even at higher levels, making the tarot cards that give extra XP feel like viable options.

There are a couple options for endgame. You can continue regular missions (of which there are 10 types) that you can do to earn gear and reputation in the respective systems (of which there are 20). Acquiring reputation unlocks additional systems and, more importantly, tarot cards. Tarot cards are the difficulty + reward multipliers for any endgame map. A card will specify the type of negative and positive it will give you - I.E. melee enemies get a random damage or defensive buff but you have a chance to double the end-of-mission rewards. Some tarot cards also raise the area level until it is many above your own, allowing the game to continue scaling after level 100.

There are also random intel missions which are short quest chains with a reward at the end and it provides you 2-3 mission types to choose from at each step.

The main endgame option is Void Crusades. There are 9 different ones, each with its own static map creating a web that connects the nodes. You can path through the web differently depending on if you want the maximum reward chests at the end or if you want to save the nodes that raise the difficulty of all remaining levels so that you have an easier run overall.

I haven't touched on many things like the solid crafting/rerolling system (you can modify all but one class of item as many times as you want) or character classes (3 base classes with 3 specializations each in Inquisitor, the WH40K:Inquisitor - Prophecy stand-alone game has another campaign and character with it that can also be used in this game, and the Sororitas DLC that came out recently is a 5th class (class only, no new campaign/missions).

I've played this game on and off for years. I never bought into the random negativity in the discussion board. I just get on for a few weeks at a time and have fun purging heretics, xenos, and daemons.

as a 40k fan I am the target audience, still despite multiple attempts I cannot get to like the game. The progression is very slow and meaningless, it is not exciting to have +1% to something when you level up, the graphics are murky and ugly, sound design is sub-par. I cringe a little whenever I see this game in my library.

I unfortunately ultimately can't recommend the game, even though it has a lot going for it. Leveling up, going through the campaign, playing all of the classes, are all fun to do. I love the Warhammer 40k setting, but the game really falls apart at endgame.

To put it into perspective, this is the first season I participated in and the first time I fully completed the campaign. After putting in 160 hrs into this season, I still haven't had the one piece of armour with the enchant I need on it to finish my basic build. The make matters worse, it is of a rarity type that you aren't able to reroll the enchant in hopes of getting to one you need. The chances of finding a specific type of armour with the exact enchant you need is astronomical. 

  I also have not yet been able to complete the last seasonal goal of upgrading a tarot card to level 3. The reason for this is that if you upgrade your tarot cards when you can, as a player would naturally do, you have just added weeks, months, or even years to your grind without knowing it. The only way you can avoid that is to stumble upon a new player tips guide or forum post somewhere before you make that mistake. It also means that when I unlock a new type of tarot card from gaining reputation in a star system, I'm not happy about it, but get angry because they just instantly added another week to the grind. I ended up adding weeks of extra RNG to my tarot card upgrading before I found out how the system works. 

I can say I will not participate in endgame again, as the amount of RNG and grind is unreal. It rivals any mobile game, but in mobile games at least people have the option to pay to speed up their progress and not spend months or years grinding it out. Whoever runs the maths on this stuff is so out of touch with reality.
They removed the heavier slower combat, reminds me more of path of exile, I like the previous gamely, still fun if you want fast APRG, I did not sadly.

I change this review to negative after many days of playing. 

The game uses some server system that is not Peer-to-peer, and is susceptible to how busy it is. 
Sometimes, a server can not be found so you can not play coop.
Sometimes, a server is found but it is very laggy (ping over 300)
Sometimes, a server randomly STOPS!

Me and a buddy lost our Void Crusade (a rogue-lite game mode with good rewards at the end). We had the final boss in the final mission at 30% and we got KICKED with the message 'server shut down'.


There is no more support for this game, so see this review as a caution: you may lose progress in multiplayer randomly.
it's a grinder- but in the Warhammer Universe and has a backstory for each character. Sometimes you need a grinding game ....;-)
Its not as good as path of exile, but its better than diablo 4.
For the Emperor.

Very pleasant  40k experience! Captures the grim dark from the far future like few others were able to. 
The story was well thought and the variety of warhammer assents are pretty solid. 
Neocore has done a nice job in keeping the support , with seasons, events, etc.
My sole complaint is that i cant use the techpriest from their "standalone" expansion on the martyr quest story.
Other than that, its a pretty compelling ARPG.
Fun ARPG, very basic and straightforward while levelling (and haven't seen the endgame yet). It might be 'too basic', but this franchise has so much potential

3/5 Woulkd give 5/5 if it didn't either lose connection to the server after every stage and or crash the client. Needs to be an option for "Offline Play" or if in Single-Player runs just run off local files... Outstanding game otherwise so PLEASE FIX CRASH ISSUES
Diablo but Warhammer.
Crafting and skilling is cool, but after a while are the quests kind of familiar ... however I consider it as a good buy (in Sale)

applist.name: Monument Valley: Panoramic Edition
applist.detailed_description:
Discover Monument Valley - A quest for forgiveness in a strikingly beautiful and mysterious world.

Embark on a journey of forgiveness along with Ida, the silent princess, through impossible environments and illusionary puzzles. Experience this meditative and calming puzzle game by manipulating monuments and creating evolving paths to explore new, surreal, and mysterious worlds.

Step into the new expanded world of Monument Valley: Panoramic Edition - and experience more intriguing impossibilities than ever before.


The Modern Classic Comes to PC.

  • In this multi-award-winning title, solve tricky but immensely satisfying puzzles with optical illusions at their core.
  • Evolve landscapes to reveal paths that would have otherwise been impossible without your help.
  • As you progress, discover beautiful architecture, transforming landscapes through pushing, pulling, clicking, raising, lowering and more.

Ida is not alone in this world, and you will need to use your wits to outsmart the enigmatic Crow People who block the path from Ida quest for forgiveness.

Simply Explorative

  • Click to manipulate a beautiful variety of worlds, all built for a one-of-a-kind PC experience. Designed for players of all ages and experience levels, Monument Valley allows players to explore evolving environments, transforming scenic and visually stunning landscapes as you play. Everyone should be able to pick up, enjoy and complete Ida’s journey. This is the biggest and best way to play Monument Valley yet.

Beautifully Reimagined

  • Whether playing in Full HD, TV or on ultrawide 21:9 displays, Monument Valley looks better than ever with stunning full-screen panoramic artwork. With more perceptible visuals than ever before, what secrets will you uncover?

Every World Included

  • Monument Valley: Panoramic Edition is the total collection of all Monument Valley content - with every chapter, add-on and DLC to make this the ultimate game to add to your collection. Inspired by minimalist 3D design, optical illusions, and ancient architecture from around the world, every monument is a unique, hand-crafted world to explore.

Panoramic Collection Out Now

  • Monument Valley: Panoramic Edition and Monument Valley 2: Panoramic Edition are both available at an exclusive bundle price when purchased together on Steam. The Panoramic Collection is the best way to play the Monument Valley series - with every chapter and DLC included.




ustwo games are proud independent developers, best known for the award-winning Monument Valley series, Land’s End, Assemble with Care and Alba: A Wildlife Adventure.

Monument Valley: Panoramic Edition Gameplay Trailer
Monument Valley: Panoramic Collection Release Trailer

reviews.review:
[h1]一段清新、孤独、放松的旅程, 其他游戏疲惫时的不二之选[/h1]
游戏讲述了一位公主寻找她遗失之物的旅程。为了完成她的心愿，玩家需要解决系列谜题，扫清她路上的障碍。

[b]优点：[/b]
创新的游玩方式 
优雅的画面
有趣的谜题设计
动听的音乐
让人感觉放松 

[b]缺点：[/b]
云存档只能保存整个关卡的进度，如果换了电脑的话，只能从本关卡重新开始……

[h1]A lonely, refreshing, and relaxing ride, I'd say, a must-play when you fail to try other intense ones ;)[/h1]
Monument Valley is a calm journey in which a princess needs to find something lost. But many "obstacles" stand in her way, and players need to help her clear them in succession by solving intricate puzzles.

[b]Pros:[/b]
Unique gameplay
engaging art
clever 3D puzzles
immersive music
relaxing feelings

[b]Cons:[/b]
Cloud save, LOL. It cannot save the latest progress, so you must play from the start of the scene when switching computers.

applist.name: Hi-Fi RUSH
applist.detailed_description:
Digital Deluxe Edition



Included in the Hi-Fi RUSH Deluxe Edition:

- Hi-Fi RUSH (Base game)
- Two Chai outfits*
- Seven bonus Chai t-shirts
- 808-Themed Guitar Skin
- 808 Alternate Skin
- Gears Starter Pack with 20,000 Gears for unlocking combat skills and other upgrades. (Note: Gears are obtained through combat and exploration in-game and not available as a purchasable currency.)

*Each of the Chai Outfits includes an alternate robot arm, scarf, jacket, trousers and shoes which can be mixed and matched with the other cosmetics in-game

Note: Gears are immediately available after purchase. Players get access to the other items after beating the opening stage and can change their outfits in the Hideout.


About the Game

Feel the beat as wannabe rockstar Chai and his ragtag team of allies rebel against an evil robotics enhancement megacorp with raucous rhythm combat! From Tango Gameworks, the studio that brought you The Evil Within® and Ghostwire®:Tokyo (no, really) comes Hi-Fi RUSH, an all-new action game where the characters, world and combat stylishly sync to the music!

Chai Versus the World


Labeled ‘defective’ after a shady corporate experiment mistakenly fuses a music player to his heart, Chai must now fight for his freedom in a slick animated world where everything – platforming puzzles, enemy attacks and even the colorful gags & banter - are synced to the beat.

Open Up the Mosh Pit!


Take on armies of corporate drones (read: actual robots) in satisfying, rhythm-amplified combat. Time your moves to pull off flashy Beat Hits, hard-hitting special abilities and even combination attacks with your allies! Want to show off? Go further and tap into the beat to amp up your skills and earn those covetous S-rank scores.

Rowdy Rebels Vs. Badass Bosses


Lead a squad of colorful teammates and take the fight to the heart of an, er, heartless corporation. Square off with each department’s boss, from Production to Marketing to Finance, each more ready to protect the company’s bottom line than the last in over-the-top battle sequences accompanied by their own music tracks!

Grab Your Headphones


Tap your toes to a killer mixtape of original music, as well as songs by Nine Inch Nails, The Prodigy, The Joy Formidable and more! Want to show off your skills to a live streaming audience? Fret not: Hi-Fi RUSH includes a streamer-friendly alternate audio mode which replaces those licensed songs with original tracks made especially for streaming Hi-Fi RUSH.

highlighted.name: This will cost you big time
I think I deserve some praise, here!

reviews.review: Hi-Fi RUSH is a reminder that you don't need ultra realistic graphics and physics or open world & a massive multiplayer to be a good game. Playing Hi-Fi RUSH felt like re-playing a timeless classic such as Okami HD, Super Mario 64 or Psychonauts, but made for the modern era. The whole time playing felt like I was watching an interactive comic turned into anime. Before I started to play Hi-Fi RUSH, being a rhythm game I thought only combat would be on a beat, but I was wrong because when I actually started to play it I realised that the ENTIRE WORLD INTERACTIONS ARE SYNCHRONISED TO MUSIC! Mind blowing concept! Gameplay is smooth, art style is fantastic, the soundtrack is awesome & the challenge is superb! My last note is that I did not encounter a single bug or a crash which is a surprise because in the past decade or so, every newly released game was unplayable & some companies took years to fix their products, but not this game. It's truly a flawless masterpiece and I can't praise it enough. Well done Tango Gameworks and Bethesda Softworks, because you made a game that I will fondly remember for ages!
This game feels like that scene in Ratatouille where the food critic flashes back to his childhood 10/10
cat
i wish i had musical robot powers and a cat

An emphatic yes for this game.

I picked it up after seeing a very short combo video from a friend.

Hi-Fi Rush is a brilliant, brilliant game. Amazing VO. Fantastic writing/narrative design. Solid combat. Fun levels. TONS of feel good moments. I wish I could re-experience this game again for the first time. 

What a gem.

[h1] Hi-Fi Rush REVIEW:[/h1] 

[b]Hi-Fi Rush[/b] is a rhythm-based action game developed by [b]Tango Gameworks[/b] and published by [b]Bethesda Softworks[/b] for the [b]Windows and Xbox Series X/S platforms[/b] and right off the bat, this game GOT ME JAMMING to that wonderful composed soundtrack which was created by former Konami composer [u]Shuichi Kobori[/u], former Capcom composer [u]Reo Uratani[/u], and Tango Gameworks' sound designer [u]Masatoshi Yanagi[/u]. It have ten licensed music tracks throughout the story and all of them fits perfect to where you at in the game right now and the boss fights. I can guarantee you 100$ or more that you will jam to one of these soundtracks FOR SURE. The [b]Gameplay[/b] is rhythm-based where you will need to perfect time hit a button to perform QTE or just the combat of this game and i appreciate that in this game it is not necessary to perfect time every hit thanks to the design of the rhythmic traits ( except few must needed parts which are pretty easy ). Even in order to help you find your rhythm, the whole world of Hi-Fi Rush pulses with the beat of whatever music is currently playing, providing you with both visual and audio cues for nailing its timing.You get different skills / combat moves as you progress through the game and they are easy to learn through good tutorial for each of them. The [b]Story[/b] of Hi-Fi rush is also very well written and keeps you entertain throughout the time you spend on it. It starts off with [spoiler] [b]Chai[/b], a 25-year old man with a disabled right arm and a dream to become a rockstar, arrives at the Vandelay Technologies campus to volunteer for Project Armstrong, a test program for cybernetic limb replacement. Unbeknownst to Chai, the CEO, Kale Vandelay secretly designates Chai to be a garbage collector for the company’s waste management [/spoiler] and how you go on from there ( pacing ) is well done IMO. It is a straightforward story BUT there are fun twist and turns throughout it. Other than that the [b]Boss fights[/b] were super fun to beat and the characters are REALLY REALLY well written, fun to hang around with, to learn about them and [b]Chai, the main hero of this game [/b] is super well voice acted, funny and just you just get to love him in this game. The game looks visually stunning to look at. Performance is also super well optimized with me having 60fps throughout it and you can get above that also with powerful GPU

[b]OVERALL, Hi-Fi Rush Shadow-dropping tactic by [u]Tango Gameworks[/u] was a very brilliant and smart move and this game is a MUST-PLAY if you are into listening / jamming to good soundtrack and rhythm-based games, Worth all the price of it ( or play it on Gamepass which makes is 2 times worth it )[/b]

[h2]Game Link:[/h2]
https://store.steampowered.com/app/1817230/HiFi_RUSH/

[url=https://www.xbox.com/en-US/games/hi-fi-rush] Hi-Fi Rush on GamePass [/url]
It's FLCL meets Devil May Cry with Jet Set Radio's artstyle. What more could you ask?

Timeless art direction.
Great characters that are well written and actually made me laugh.
Fun rhythm-based gameplay that offers a solid challenge, especially on hard mode.
Fantastic music, whether it be songs they licensed or songs they wrote.

All in all, this game is 100% worth picking up, even for full price.

HOLY ENDORHPINE BOZO BLAST HATRED MAN KILL! KILL! SEX OVERDRIVE JOE BIDEN FLASK OPEN CASKET MONKLEY CEREMONUY JAZZ PEROFROMANCE HAND TO BAND VOMIT JOLLY RANCHE

It kinda shocked the heck out of me when the announcement for this game dropped just out of the blue and it was playable the same day! This game is outstanding and deserves even more love than it gets already!

From the devs that made... *checks notes* THE EVIL WITHIN?!? Daaaaaaaaamn their comedy and art direction in this is S-Tier! The game plays like an old Gamecube/PS2/OG-Xbox era action platformer, with rhythm attributes in the mix. You can tell that a lot of love went into this game, from the stage design, combat feel, to the voice acting. This game has charm in spades and then some, and runs really well too!

I've only rarely encountered minor stuttering, but it's not enough to detract from the experience. It's only really happened to me when I was in a traversal segment and there's not much going on anyhow. Other than that, it's been completely bug-free so far.

Also, one of the big bads is a reference to Jojo's Bizarre Adventure and the weeb in me squeals with delight. I also love the nods to The Evil Within with some robo-ified Sebastian and Joseph cameos.

This game honestly deserves your money even at full price. The amount of detail and love put into this game is insane and exactly what the industry needs in this day and age!

applist.name: Gunfire Reborn
applist.detailed_description:
About This Game:

  • Gunfire Reborn is an adventure level-based game featuring FPS, roguelite, and RPG elements. Players can control unique heroes—each with different abilities—as they adventure through procedurally-generated levels and pick up randomly-dropped weapons. You can play Gunfire Reborn alone or cooperatively with up to three other players (4-player co-op).
  • Every level is random; each new restart is a brand-new experience. You will meet different heroes and experience new weapons, items, checkpoints, and unique combat rhythms throughout the game.

    Game Features:


    • FPS+Roguelite+RPG combined gameplay, construct diverse Build through death cycle for different experience


    • Elaborate, yet randomized stage experience


    • Over 100 different items and various weapons


    • Many heroes and multiple game plus with different game mechanism


    • Unique art style


    • Co-op level-based adventure

reviews.review:
okay so, I'm too lazy to learn video editing to link it in a steam review so I'll just describe it
it's that clip from family guy where quagmire comes out of his house after being inside for a week after discovering porn and his one arm is super buff, except instead of quagmire its me and instead of porn its gunfire reborn and instead of a week its over 2 years

TLDR down below.

Best shooter roguelike out there.

Has everything a modern roguelike should have: 

- Multiple characters that feel unique:
 Every character has multiple styles of play. You can focus on one of their 2 special abilities or on abilities that improve your weapons. But this is not required, you can use a bit of all 3 styles and still feel strong. Most characters gravitate to certain kinds of weapons with which they will probably do best. All characters have 3 trees of 6 power ups that you can pick from after you finish a stage.

- a lot of different weapons to get:
There are over 50 weapons divided into 8 classes. Most weapons feel unique and have their own gimmick. You can carry up to 2 weapons making certain combo's is possible. A downside with such a big selection is of course that some weapons feel like weaker versions of others. Also each weapon being pretty unique means that some will not be suited to your style at all. 

- Permanent upgrades:
There is permanent progression between runs you can upgrade with a currency you get by playing. I know this goes against the definition of roguelike but all modern rogues have this feature. The devs can make harder/more fun encounters that feel unfair but get less unfair the more you invest in this system which ultimately makes the game better since they can push the boundaries the game. You can also go for an extra challenge by not/ partially investing in this to make it harder for yourself.

- Difficulty settings:

There are 4 difficulties to play in. You are locked to normal at the start but unlock higher difficulties by beating the hardest difficulty you currently have. The 4th difficulty is the most unique, it features unique upgrades you can buy with the same currency used for the permanent upgrades (this means that currency is not useless when you unlocked the whole prema upgrades tree which is nice) which will change the way you play in a major way and is so much fun! The game never feels to unfair, you can win the game with any combination of weapons/power ups as long as you can keep dodging!

- Many upgrades
During the run you encounter these power ups called occult scrolls, they can straight up boost your damage/survivability or change the way you play. Some boost you in a big way but will also restrict you in a way, there is a lot of different 'builds' you can aim to go for.

- 4 worlds to go through, with their own enemies to fight.
The enemies are cool, there is ranged and melee enemies. Some have unique mechanics that are not super hard to play around. Of course this gets harder when it's accompanied by other enemies. Enemies get harder in the later worlds, it's not uncommon to almost get oneshot there. The bosses of these areas are also very good. Huge monsters in their own arena with alot of different attacks that have to be dealt with, and somewhere in between you are supposed to actually kill them.

- Active devs
The game still gets regular patches and updates, there is still a roadmap for their future content like in the beta. They have added new characters, bosses, a new world and a new game mode since beta. There is still more to come as well. When you encounter bugs in game there is a feedback option which you can access during your run and explain the bug. And you actually get listened to, every bug I have reported over the years has been fixed in a reasonable time frame, almost always in the next patch.

- Good pricing
This game is 100% worth getting at full price. It is more then reasonable if you see the huge amount of content here that puts AAA games to shame. There has been 1 DLC so far which included 2 characters. So far it is the only content that is gated behind a DLC, their new game mode that could have been a DLC in itself was added completely free. If you are looking for a game like this I would just buy it now!

- Multiplayer
The game supports multiplayer, there is a matchmaker to play with random people as well. I cannot comment on the quality of that since I never did that. I have only played multi with 1 friend and it was fun, every player gets their own weapon and scroll drops so nobody can 'steal' your upgrades like in Risk of Rain 2. If you don't need your drops you can press a button to make them visible for your allies so they can pick it up. You can help each other get to their preffered build faster but you can't get 'griefed' by people that steal your drops. I feel this is the best way to create a multiplayer experience in a co-op game. The new game mode can also be played with friends. 

TLDR:
if you like this genre, you should definitely buy this. Big worlds, al lot of characters, weapons and power ups. Different difficulties for everyone, a multiplayer that is done extremely well for a co-op game. The devs should feel very proud of what they accomplished with this game. I look forward to the bright future of this game!

The game has this big "one more run" feel that every good roguelike should have.

If I have to put a number on it it's a 9,5/10 for me. I hope this review helped any people with doubts to make a good decision!

Meh, I want to like this game more but it's got a lot of problems for me personally. It's not bad, I enjoy it and play it with friends or on my own occasionally but everytime I do nowadays I just end up irked over one thing or another. I could probably recommend it if you like this sort of thing, but I'd like to list out my problems as someone that's played both a lot of shooters and roguelikes/lites.

Although I'll start with the good, the gunplay and weapon designs are incredible and a ton of fun to mess with, reincarnation is incredible too, the wacky builds you can pull off at that point are a ton of fun. That's really the main positive here, and if that's good enough for you you'll probably love this. It's great for more casual play.

The problems start with the enemies, its not necessarily their attack patterns, their hp, or anything like that. They're well balanced, but for a few reasons they don't *feel* satisfying to fight. The way they move around is kind of awkward, rigid, and janky, its not smooth at all and feels random and just frustrating enough to lower the feel of combat for me. Its not bullshit or anything, but it makes it harder to enjoy the great gunplay and with enough playtime it became harder and harder for me to overlook.

The game has a lot of content, side modes and such that might seem like nice mixups at first but it all ends up being kinda mediocre and I just end up playing reincarnation instead. Spirtual Assault is still a complete mess, its not a bullet sponge hell-hole anymore but its just soooo boring and really highlights the unsatisfying enemy design. It needs to seriously be cut down and better paced, it goes on way too long for how mindless and spammy it is. The final boss for it is designed okay move-wise but is still annoyingly tanky and unfun to fight as a result.

The further you go into the game progression wise the more of a problem the stat system becomes.  It's much better to stick with one weapon early on with good affixes and pump all the money into it. Unless you're playing a character like the dog there's little reason to ever switch between two weapons, ammo is plenty and its way too costly to invest into two weapons when you can just funnel everything into one broken one. 

This isn't inherently a problem necessarily but then it leads to runs becoming samey, you're just waiting until you get an OP combination and then just spamming that weapon at enemies, it leaves the combat loop lacking depth, the only skill thats really rewarded as a result is the ability to dodge enemies. There's no major tactics here, most characters except like, the monkey, have a clearly defined weapon type/s they're good with, so thats what you go for. 

You want shotguns/melee, you play the bird, you want smgs/assault rfiles play the bunny, fire weapons? the fox. I wish the characters were more open-ended in their design, would be much more interesting for builds.

Overall its not a bad game, just a shallow one. Don't go into this one expecting any major complexity or depth. You shoot the bad guys, dodge occasionally, and build around whatever rng has given you. It's a passable way to spend the time, but there's both roguelites and shooters out there that offer way more depth and engaging gameplay than this if thats what you're looking for.

• 10 Boosts for each MyCAREER Skill Boost type
• 10 Boosts for each Gatorade Boost type
• 4 Cover Athlete T-Shirts for your MyPLAYER
• MyPLAYER backpack and arm sleeve
• Custom-design skateboard for MyPLAYER
• One 2-Hr Double XP Coin


About the Game

Rise to the occasion and realize your full potential in NBA 2K23. Prove yourself against the best players in the world and showcase your talent in MyCAREER. Pair today’s All-Stars with timeless legends in MyTEAM. Build a dynasty of your own in MyGM or take the NBA in a new direction with MyLEAGUE. Take on NBA or WNBA teams in PLAY NOW and experience true-to-life gameplay. How will you Answer the Call?

TAKE MORE CONTROL
Feel refined gameplay in the palm of your hands on both sides of the ball in NBA 2K23. Attack the basket with a new arsenal of offensive skill-based moves, while you unleash your potential as a lockdown defender with new 1-on-1 mechanics to stifle opposing players at every turn.

AN EPIC VOYAGE AWAITS
Embark on a swashbuckling basketball journey aboard a spacious cruiseliner equipped with pristine courts, scenic views, and a boatload of rewards for you and your MyPLAYER to enjoy. Plus, there’s even more to explore during shore excursions.

JORDAN CHALLENGE RETURNS
Step back in time with era-specific visuals that captured Michael Jordan’s ascent from collegiate sensation to global icon with immersive Jordan Challenges chronicling his career-defining dominance. Lace up his shoes to recreate his otherworldly stat lines and iconic last shots, while listening to first-hand accounts from those who witnessed his maturation from budding star to basketball legend.

BUILD YOUR SQUAD
Ball without limits as you collect and assemble a bevy of legendary talent from any era in MyTEAM. Dominate the hardwood each Season, and bring your vision to life with a broad set of customization tools to create the perfect look for your perfect starting five.

I finally got decent enough to have ONE efficient game, ONE, in which I LOST, and when it went to cash out the 1500vc(which is NOTHING), for some reason the server felt in needed to investigate and ended up crashing my game, and when I got back on, I was banned. I will never buy another 2k product, I will pirate the game, and I will use cheat engines and everything they don't want us to use that costs them money out of their greedy a** pockets. We get old gen games at new gen prices, they treat the honest players like trash, they can't do anything to combat the cheaters, and they care only about money, not their product. It's the most pathetic thing I've ever seen.
bring back where you can play my Carrer story ofline

Another year and yet no autonomous method of dealing with people who cheat. As usual the players who play fairly and by the rules are punished. Without directly naming anyone, I expressed my frustration regarding cheaters in a discussion forum and my message was swiftly deleted. The moderator expressed that even though I did not call anyone by name, I am not allowed to insult cheating behaviour in general. I was also asked to add citations to my message which I think it not necessary in a gaming forum. Not only do players themselves have to report cheaters one by one with extensive video footage, we are also not allowed to name call the very cheaters who (for years) have been disrupting our days/game-play everyday. I have also invested a considerable amount of time and money in the My Team game mode and cheaters are able to quit the game when they are losing and the score will not count. This is unacceptable and not professional behaviour by both the cheaters and the management. This seriously needs to be investigated.

(If any cheater reading this is having an existential crisis and is deeply offended by my review, I simply don't give a damn. I will be in Ante Up if you want to vs me but you don't have to bring your balls because we all know you don't have any.)
If youre thinking of buying it because its $9.59, please dont. Save that and go buy some food. At least youll enjoy that
fix that stupid as bully badge im tired of getting tossed around like a school thot

NBA 2K23 is a yet another follow-up in the long-standing 2K basketball franchise that continues to release repeated versions of the same game, re-skinned and re-titled to fit the year, and the real-life players drafted that year, it represents. As expected the core gameplay has been worked on to perfection for years now so players know what will be brought to the table - just an overall smooth and crushingly-detailed basketball simulator. This isn't the first time Micheal Jordan has graced the cover of a 2K sports game, but a lot of time has passed since then and things have changed for the good and for the bad.

If you look to play this, you have to consider many things: do you care about the you-against-the-AI aspect of it all or do you really crave that online player-vs-player feel. If your heart lies somewhere in the middle, you have to choose a side here because there's no in-between. Playing online-only means that you will have two years at max before the servers are shut down intentionally, forcing you to pay top dollar for the inevitable next installment. Playing against the AI means 2K can't do s**t to you if you want to stay in 2K23, having fun at the various modes it has to offer - NBA 2K23 will be playable even after the specific game has been deleted from the store. So choose carefully... when it's on sale (don't feed the pigs even more).

On PC, this game is fun to play against the AI - no bugs, no glitches and an overall satisfied experience playing completely alone. Do I recommend NBA 2K23? Yes, if you play against the AI, If you aim to play online - please read the other reviews of players who've had an even greater experience than me there. It's a lot to unpack there, for sure.

Follow your heart.

applist.name: UNO
applist.detailed_description:
One of the most iconic classic games which we all grew to know and love! UNO makes its return with an assortment of exciting new features such as added video chat support and an all new theme system which adds more fun!
Match cards either by matching color or value and play action cards to change things up. Race against others to empty your hand before everyone else in either Classic play or customize your experience with a variety of House Rules and match settings to ensure you and your friends never play the same game twice!
Also, get ready to shake things up with new branded themes introducing never-before-seen Theme Cards that really change the way you play the game!

Uno with friends can be very frustrating, you know whats even more frustrating than the game itself? Trying to even MAKE a lobby with your friends to play the game you just bought. Never able to get all 4 of us in a lobby to play. Would stay far away from this game if you plan to play online at all.
The game destroy the friendships
ubisoft launcher
might end friendships
i have uno

Only downside is the Uplay DRM
Waiting for Dos...
Ubisoft connect.

Bought this game as well as some DLCs for it to play it together with firends. The thing is, I can`t, because I simply can`t start a lobby. It`s some "NAT" problem (which from what I`ve seen is comon for this game) so  when I try to host a game it doesn`t work and displays this "NAT" eror. I tried all the ways possible to fix it and none of the ones I found worked. But it gets even worse, cause the day before I wanted to buy DLCs everything was just fine, I hosted a lobby and everything worked perfect, and nothing has changed since that day. And we don`t really want to play standart UNO, and since I can`t host a game and my friends don`t have DLCs or want to buy one, we just don`t play it. If they at least added feature allowing host of the lobby launching DLCs other players in lobby have, I wouldn`t complain, but there isn`t one so this game is just waste of money.

If you're into playing Uno with a bunch of randoms or bots, or you really like staring at a menu screen while repetitive music plays, waiting for your friends to brave the insufferably incompetent games launcher that is Ubisoft Connect so you can play uno then this is definitely the product for you. 

I must warn however that if you live within a 2 hour drive of the people you intend to play uno with it is probably much faster and less headache inducing to simply get a real deck of cards and play uno with them in person. The added benefit of this is when your friend finishes the game on a draw 4 card for the second time that night you can punch them instead of your monitor.

The game itself is fun, but Ubisoft Connect makes it worse. I can't create a Ubisoft account because I do not meet the "requirements". Ubisoft was like "Let's release the game on Steam but also require our garbage launcher, so people could waste their money on some game they can't even launch because of our garbage launcher :)". There is no point in requiring a launcher. I am not buying a game that requires a 3rd party launcher.

applist.name: Little Nightmares II
applist.detailed_description:
PC Enhanced Edition


Dive into an unsettling adventure that you'll never forget, now enhanced in mesmerizing 4K at uncapped FPS.

Little Nightmares II owners also get access for free to Little Nightmares II Enhanced Edition upgrades.
The Enhanced version visual upgrade includes Ray-traced reflections, improved volumetric shadows, and increased game details such as interactive particles.
A new immersive 3D soundscape mix will also be accessible in 5.1 and 7.1. to make your Little Nightmares II even more immersive.

For optimal Enhanced experience
OPERATING SYSTEM: Windows 10
PROCESSOR: Intel Core i5-8400 | AMD Ryzen 5 1600
MEMORY: 8 GB RAM
GRAPHICS: Nvidia GeForce RTX 2080, 8 GB | AMD RX 6800


Digital Deluxe Edition



Purchase the Deluxe Edition and receive the following digital content:

- Little Nightmares II Full Game

- The Nomes’ Attic DLC
Follow the Nomes to find this special in-game puzzle and unlock the Nomes’ hat as a reward upon completion.

- Full Digital Soundtrack
Enjoy the full Little Nightmares II soundtrack, composed by Tobias Lilja from Tarsier Studios.

- “The Art of Little Nightmares II” Digital Artbook
Dive into the making of Little Nightmares II with this 56-page artbook full of sketches, artwork and design decisions by the Tarsier Studios art team.

- A Wallpaper Set

- Mono & Six avatars


About the Game



Return to a world of charming horror in Little Nightmares II, a suspense adventure game in which you play as Mono, a young boy trapped in a world that has been distorted by the humming transmission of a distant tower.

With Six, the girl in the yellow raincoat, as his guide, Mono sets out to discover the dark secrets of The Signal Tower. Their journey won't be easy; Mono and Six will face a host of new threats from the terrible residents of this world.

Will you dare to face this collection of new, little nightmares?

reviews.review: I have to say, there's a lot about Little Nightmares 2 I don't like. I find the gameplay frequently frustrating, especially in how you can know exactly what you need to do but the camera angles and controls get in the way, so you have to repeat things not because of challenge but because of a lack of precision. I don't think the characters make much sense, nor does the story add up, relying on grimdark twists instead. But in spite of all of this, the artistry on show in the series remains excellent. I can't think of many video game worlds that feel this tactile. And even if the whole is less than the sum of its parts, the individual parts are of a dark beauty that is unparalleled. If you can accept the gameplay being so-so and the story not being all that coherent, and if you like the game's aesthetic, do check it out.
best game

On sales for around 15€, totally recommend.
5 hours of gameplay, in the worst child's nightmare environment. Graphics and audio are outstanding, game is well optimized, gameplay is quite good, characters are kind of attaching even though they don't speak...
5 hours is a bit short, but it's exactly what such a game should be. It's totally worth it. I loved the 1st, love this one as well.
Well done to whatever studio made this game.
Difficult as all hell. But a genuine 10/10 puzzle and horror game. No jump scares either, just disturbing horror and creepiness.
NICE GAME!
Love it. Insanely creepy, but the story is very fascinating and you'd need to think while playing the game. Highly recommend :).

This is the first time I'm playing this game and couldn't put down the controller for 4 hours. 
The story and the atmosphere are amazing. Everything is great about this game. 

The only thing I don't like are the controls and how easily the main character let go of everything if I don't hold R2; but maybe that's just me getting used to Assassin's Creed characters holding onto things with/or without me holding R2 all the time. 

Totally recommended anyway.

This game is a very exciting journey in a wired and wacky mood, full of strange creatures and places. It was a lot of fun to play except here and there where I had to play parts over and over again. But maybe because I diden´t play it in one rush. My advice: Put it on you wish list and grab it when it is on sale, or anyway.

I played and finished the first game and enjoyed it and wanted to get the sequel. Overall, the best parts of the game were the graphics, atmosphere and music/sound design. It lends itself to a creepy feeling, tense experience. Those were my favorite parts of both games. 

On the flip side, probably due to the nature of the way the game is played as a 'side scroller', but also 3d, it can be extremely frustrating at times to control the character how one desires. For example, making jumps across and not knowing the depth of the field in terms of how far forward or back the character is, can be confusing. Also, picking up certain objects can be very annoying as the hit box sometimes works and sometimes doesn't. I got to the point where I dreaded any section where I had to use mechanics to get through. The frustration with the controls/mechanics ruined the immersion for me several times unfortunately. 

As far as the story went, I felt like it was OK, but certainly left a ton to the imagination. I wouldn't have minded if there was something more direct in terms of narrative. It got me thinking about what a game like this would be like with a very direct story that presented information not telling the gamer what conclusion to draw, but at least presenting something more specific. 

At this point, I am not sure if I would buy a third incantation of the game unless I saw some reviews that discussed how the game controls and mechanics were more smooth/usable. Ultimately I would recommend this game as long as someone doesn't mind being patient with some janky controls/mechanics and maybe has played the first game so one knows what's in store.

I recommend this game even it there's a section that's really annoying. In the big picture, this game is really awsome. The  music, the sounds, the environment, the story, the characters.

When I was deciding to purchase the game I read the comments saying that the controls were clunky, and the 2.5D is weird and all, these things to me were not a problem. Although there is a chapter where they introduced a new macanique that is actually realy annoying to control, and you are required to use it with a certain level of precision that the controls just don't offer.

I really enjoyed the game up until this specific chapter, during the chapter I wanted to rage and quit and thought the game was bad, and after that the game came back to being awsome. So I still recommend the game. Even if to me personally there was a polarizing point in the game were you need to master a IMO badly implemented mechanic.

So buy it, enjoy in, but brace yourself for chapter 3.

Sorry but LN 1 is somehow more memorable, especially towards the end. Maybe more dramatic and aesthetically creative.

LN 2 is still good though! Scratches that itch.

This game is short compared to the first game. Nothing new except for interactions with Six. I think the first game had more depth and it was more thriller. This game is something that could be a  dlc for the first game. But still it was a nice experience. It does not worth the original price, you should definitely wait for a huge discount. They think they introduce a complicated situation by uncovering the relation between the main protagonist and antagonist but in reality it does not make sense.
to the person that made the mannequin level: I am going to find your address and pull up with a assault rifle

applist.name: Library Of Ruina
applist.detailed_description:
“May you find your book in this place.”



Become the owner of the Library and receive your guests.

Your librarians will fight for the Library.

Combat between the guests and the librarians breaks out as if it were on a stage.

Defeated guests turn into books, and the Library grows onward.

A good book will allow you to invite new guests with greater secrets.

Amass a collection of books and explore the secrets of the City.

And eventually, get your hands on…

The one singular, perfect book.



[Introduction to the Game]


“May you find your book in this place.”

Become the owner of the Library and receive your guests.

Your librarians will fight for the Library.
Combat between the guests and the librarians breaks out as if it were on a stage.
Defeated guests turn into books, and the Library grows onward.

A good book will allow you to invite new guests with greater secrets.
Amass a collection of books and explore the secrets of the City.

And eventually, get your hands on…
The one singular, perfect book.


[A Library Battle Simulation]


Library of Ruina is a game that uses the concept of a “Library Battle Simulation”.
You will invite guests to the Library and engage in combat with them to gain 'Books' with their stories.

Battles are played with the 'Librarians' and the 'Guests' using cards and dice.
You can plan against the guests’ moves by looking at the cards they will use and select the most optimal card to oppose them.

When combat begins, how the dice from your chosen card fall will determine victory or defeat in the struggle.
However, the outcome of the dice is not simply determined by pure luck.
Certain effects and variables will shift the outcome of the dice for and against your favor.

Be sure to carefully choose which cards you utilize to win the battle with your guests.
Behold the outcome of your choices and how luck unfolds as your librarians and guests skirmish.
You can go through an exhilarating experience, putting it all on the line with thrills just like betting.


[Conflicts that Build Emotion]


Confrontation in the Library is not just about killing your enemies, it is about heightening emotions.
The emotions of the librarians and guests rise as the battle progresses, and as it grows fiercer and comes to a head, they will surge.

Depending on your librarian's feelings, positive outcomes or powerful effects with penalties can occur.
In addition, as the emotional tension of the guests grows, the difficulty of combat increases, yet at the same time, rarer books can be acquired.
Furthermore, dialogue can appear depending on the situation of the battle and will make one’s viewing experience of the match unfolding even more enjoyable.


[Books Can Be Anything]


A guest who dies in the Library will turn into a book.
These books can be a librarian's body, materials to grow the Library, or new cards for battle.
You can also use books as the parts of an invitation to bring forth another guest.

Invite different guests to acquire various books, then utilize them accordingly.
How you make use of your collection to grow the Library is up to you.


[The Story of the City and the Library]


In Library of Ruina, you will be witness to the stories of Angela, the Sephirot, and Roland following the ending of Lobotomy Corporation.
You will also watch various events occurring around the huge city in which the Library is located.

Accumulate books to grow your Library and librarians, and invite more powerful guests to gain better books.
From lowly canards to urban legends and beyond...
Throughout the game, you will gradually become familiar with the story of the City.

May you find your book in this place…
