reviews.review:
Probably not for me.
I'd feel different about this game, if the combat was less "clunky" I guess?
I like the idea of defeat scenarios, like being enslaved by bandits, or randomly rescued to a far away place. But the limiting stamina meter in this game refills extremely slowly.
That wouldn't be the problem, if enemies played by the same rules, but their stamina is infinite, meaning:
1. They can spam attacks all day long, making the player wait their turn for 1 small window of opportunity.
2. When the window of opportunity presents itself - they input read and perfect dodge 70 - 80% of the time.
3. Most of the time, combat is vs multiple opponents, which isn't fun with a lock on system and spammy enemies like this.
And the stagger meter is also nearly useless due to this, even with the kick ability.

Also, the enemy AI ain't the best with constant pathing issues.

Maybe the game gets good after 10 hours of scrambling for silver and getting strong equipment, but those are 10 hours I could spend in a game I enjoy the combat of...

Not worth the headache. Everybody says this game is "meant to punish you" which I guess yeah they succeeded. I can't play this game anymore without going into my game files and deleting the autosave of my death so it goes back to a slightly better one. I'm tired of getting my stuff confiscated into bugged areas that have a chance of making all of my loot disappear if I don't do it right. Will I still play this game? Probably. There's a lot going for it. But it lacks features that make me not want to recommend it to people anymore.
Combat feels like performing an open heart surgery with a wooden bucket. Worst combat system i've seen so far.
Elden Ring at home.

Highly recommended

Pros
-High replay-ability value
-Fun to build your character
-Gorgeous world
-Incredibly rewarding to beat an enemy that was beating the ever loving stuffing out of you
-Difficult and deadly even at the latest stages of the game
-Playable in co-op, so get your bud and share a refreshing experience in this rpg world
-Diverse enemies and MANY boss fights
-Dungeon delving and rewards full exploration
-Rewards preparedness and thinking ahead
-Great OSTs 
-Unique death system
-Better than Skyrim 

Cons
-The combat system can be difficult and clunky
-missing some quality of life items I like in my games that had to be fixed with mods (UI and other misc)
-It can be difficult to understand what you need to do next if you aren't reading/paying attention

In any case, I recommend you play this game. Go into it with a open mind and know that you will fail. In this game, you must learn in order to adapt and over come obstacles you may not have realised were solvable in that way. Give this game a chance, I promise you wont regret it. I didn't.

It has an old school MMORPG feel to it. I had fun and found myself watching a ton of youtube videos about it during times when I was not playing. I enjoyed seeking out certain weapons and armor sets. I played through the faction quest line. Then I got to the DLC with the town building aspect and decided I was done, because the game seemed to have run out of content and was trying to be something else. Overall, it was interesting in a low budget sort of way. The combat was janky, and the graphics were just ok, but there are somehow not enough games with this amount of soul. The musical scoring is fantastic. I absolutely love the sweeping themes in the open world and the cozy tunes in the towns.
I'm going to be honest I have no idea what is going on

~10 hr impressions; 99% walking and exploring, 1% fighting. VERY light recommend on heavy sale.

tl;dr -- Outward is a confusing and hard game to recommend. I like what it's going for but it's just a frustratingly hard game to get into. Not necessarily because of skill but because it's a constant test of patience. Unless you know what you're doing, you're sinking many hours in just to get to a comfortable place. Otherwise, it's an absolutely tediously slow and punishing experience for even the smallest mistakes.

edit: Literally spent an hour after this review stuck in the Marsh, dying over and over because I spawned back with reduced health and stamina, sometimes next to enemies, sometimes surrounded by poison water. Couldn't even leave because animals ate all my food and you CANNOT travel between areas without rations. I even died next to the exit and got dragged half way across the map.
edit 2: This happened twice. 3 creatures were just sat outside a dungeon and immediately killed me, taking ALL my food. Not half, not a third, every - single - piece. 

You can spend your first few hours preparing, set your eyes on a goal, then immediately get humbled by something you couldn't possibly have prepared for, which incredibly slows your progression as you stumble around to recover, retreat, or just end up in a loop of death. You need gear, you need money -- to get either reliably, you need both. Otherwise, you're getting two shot from some random NPC or creature out in the wild, spending more time recovering than actually progressing quests or your build. 

Speaking of builds, they are obnoxious to even begin. Have your eyes set on a certain playstyle? Well good luck! You chose a certain faction and are locked out of an entire set of abilities that make the playstyle playable or at least easier. You're practically stuck with one playstyle until you save up the silver to buy new skills. You can't grind enemies like a Souls-like to invest points into what you need. Well you can, but you're getting things worth 1 silver and spending a minute killing a handful of enemies.

It feels a bit disjointed, at least in the early game, in its survival and its action RPG aspects. The survival mechanics aren't hard at all and the action combat is simple but clunky. The quests don't really push you in the right directions to gradually prepare you so you gotta either rely on a guide or suffer constant trial and error. 

Bugs?
-Locked at 30 fps for seemingly no reason. Had to restart PC to fix.
-Stuck in water? Idk if intended but I get stuck the moment water reaches thigh level. Basically guaranteed death in poison water.
-Stuck in tent. Had to exit to menu then reload.
-Enemies hitting me through walls.

So, before I start out - I understand why this game is great to so many people. Before buying it on Steam, I pirated it and beat it with my wife and we had a blast. Now I'm 3/4 of the way through a 2nd playthrough and I just can't do it anymore. 

The main criticism is that Outward punishes failure with boredom. If you die, look forward to 5 minutes straight of holding L1 while watching your character doubled over in exhaustion as you beeline back to where you were. There is no challenge to this besides your patience for boredom. Even healing up with sleeping requires going into your inventory, dropping the tent, sleeping by designating sleep time/repair/guard duty, then you wake up, drink and eat food (all which require the menu AGAIN), and then another button press to put the tent up. Its like 10 button presses which offer zero challenge except again for your patience for monotony. And very quickly, the in-game economy becomes trivial. It doesn't take long for money to mean next to nothing. And story is light to. So I found myself asking why I was watching my character run through empty wastelands just to fight more boring enemies that essentially all require cheesing. I know its low hanging fruit to talk about FromSoft games, but I find myself asking why I'm not playing them instead since every aspect of this game besides combat is an exercise in padding for time. 

Not a super well constructed review, but it does suck to realize that over time, I have grown to be completely bored with this game. There is no room for toying with builds unless you use a wiki or watch guides, because again - you are locked into your choices, and you will be required to run for 20 minutes at a time (no BS) only stopping to drink water, eat, and recover stamina (fun!). Some people love this title and thats great for them. I would really like an Outward 2 with more engaging combat, and a lot more QoL improvements.

I want to like this game so bad. The concept is cool, graphics are fine, just overall seems like a cool game. However the combat is so hard and clunky. Every time I go to play this game thinking I want to I end up remembering why I don't play it more. It could be great and some combat changes would really benefit it in the long run

I can confidently say this is my favourite game of likely my entire life for a couple reasons:

1: Combat in this game is amazing and mostly misunderstood by beginners it is the most developed combat expirence i have and will ever have the pleasure of enjoying,many say it is "clunky" i would just put this down as an issue with approach and expectation or the more pretentious "skill issue". This of coarse can be fixed with time using the system and the insane variety that the different breakthroughs allow (Skill trees).

2: The world building and quest variety are insane when you dig for the info an example of this is when i returned a idol to a pedestal just to learn 2 hours later in a completely different quest that i had just helped a Lich who acts in opersision to my chosen faction.

3: The graphics of the game may not be to a AAA standard however i believe this "Limitation" to the game adds to the general aesthetic of the game.

I was prompted to write this after just having completed my first flawless run of the game and gaining the achievement for having never died for the entirety of the main quest.
Interesting Combat. Sort of Souls-like. Thousands of builds and weapon combinations possible. Almost to 700 hours and still going strong.

Outward is in my Top 3 Favourite games of all time. The other 2 are Playstation All-Stars Battle Royale and Bugsnax. I am not joking. and you cannot convince me otherwise. Outward is a Masterpiece and I am still waiting for PSASBR 2. But yeah outward is super fun. it took me and my pal a good 3-4 attempts and about 20 sheenshots videos to figure out what we were doing, but once you get into it, theres no going out of it. 

and now since youre still here, playstation all stars was a game my dad bought me when i was 7 i think, because it came out 11 years ago. and it became my favourite game because I prefer the party game style fighters like smash bros and stick fight whatever its called. so PSASBR was a super fun game for me, and it also had characters in it i knew such as Nathan Drake, Kratos, Sly Cooper, Ratchet and Clank etc. My Dad played Kratos and he would always Cincinnati Slambo updog triple wigwam forward neutral air falcon kick style wipe the floor with my sister and i whenever he played Kratos.
my dad wasnt allowed to play kratos anymore. 

OH YEAH SACKBOY WAS IN THE GAME TOO

moral of the story, I highly recommend outward. 
since i still have you here, youre probably thinking "hopefully outward will give me fun memories like the kind of memories noah (me) has with his dad and sister. I tell you what, outward will definitely give you some great memories. Off the top of my head there was that one time that mason and i were stripped of all our belongings and forced into prison, there was another time when mason and i beat our very first wendigo, and the other time when mason and i went exploring and we accidentally found the first cannibal, and we died, and all of the times Gep saved us.

Just bought the game and managed to get captured after my first hike outside after I paid off the lighthouse.I ran into a keep and now I am a slave in Vendavel fortress xD
Weird feeling i cannot wait to slave myself out of the keep or maybe jump into the dark pit of mistery lol

2 hours in and already in love I cant wait for more to come
Resource management, exploration, factional conflicts, dungeons, weird lore, game breaking character builds, crafting useful items and powerful gear. This game has everything, except a map cursor.

I like the game personally but I recommend watching YouTube videos first so that you can decide if this game is for you for 1st time players you will die a lot and most probably will get frustrated like my 1st experience but if you decide to still keep playing like I did you will find the feeling of overcoming hard obstacle/situations rewarding.

Advice for new players with combat try to as much as possible isolate enemies you will have a hard time when fighting multiple enemies unless if you have prepared like setup trap's 1st. Also do not expect to chain multiple skills in quick succession like a combo (I tried it. Tried to swing my sword while pressing the kick skill expecting the kick skill will cancel my sword swing it does not. their is a delay between actions and skills). You can try holding down the block button then activate your skill when the time is right helped me a lot in many fights. Also use any means at your disposal traps, making enemies fight each other, stealth, long range archery to give you an advantage this games does not like to fight fair.

Also you do not need to buy recipes in order to craft or cook anything just quick search a guide on recipe and their ingredients here on steam and that might save you money in the early game to late game.

You can easily gets lost in this game but with experience you will eventually memorize the landmarks.

Overall 4/5 you will love or hate this game or both.

I've beaten this game over 10 times at this point. I have in PC and every console I own. It's a great RPG with light survival mechanics, some inventory management, and no quest markers. Best of all you can play the entire game with 1 friend online or even split-screen locally.
bought the game on 3 separate systems. Crossed fingers for a switch port.

Infatuated with this game. Love the survival aspect, and the combat is difficult but so satisfying once you get the hang of it. I do think that it loses some of it's immersive capacity with the lack of interactiveness in cities and people, and the story is good but light-touch. However i still love love love the game and appreciate it's a small team who developed it

Survival game with more of a story than most, it's a challenging start, not great controller compatibility, so only buy if you can play and enjoy keyboard combat. Still very new to the game, but enjoying it. One thing: your character is ugly af no matter what you do

applist.name: Dying Light 2 Stay Human
applist.detailed_description:
Just Updated



It’s high time to get brutal and pack a greater punch! The most recent patch includes multiple updates to the combat system, along with improvements and fixes that will bring you more gore, blood and guts. Your enemies will have a hard time staying whole after an encounter, especially if you have access to your favorite weapon, thanks to the improved blueprint mastery. Speaking of killer style, you can now alter your clothing while keeping your lethal stats with the new transmog system.


Deluxe Edition



The Deluxe Edition contains:

  • Dying Light 2 Stay Human: Bloody Ties - the first official story DLC
  • Exclusive weapon charms
  • "Legendary" outfit
  • "Legendary" renewable weapons
  • "Legendary" paraglider skin
  • Wallpapers ready to print
  • Digital comic
  • Digital Artbook
  • Digital Soundtrack


Ultimate Edition



The Ultimate Edition contains:

  • Deluxe Edition
  • 2h Night XP Boost
  • Crafting items
  • Expansion pass with 2 extra stories that will be available in the months after the release


POST-LAUNCH ROAD MAP



It’s been a great first year, but the best of Dying Light 2 Stay Human is still ahead of us. Prepare for the next phase of our post-launch support that guarantees major content updates, events, rewards, Chapters, DLC, and much more. The following is only the tip of the iceberg regarding what awaits you.


About the Game

Over twenty years ago in Harran, we fought the virus—and lost. Now, we’re losing again. The City, one of the last large human settlements, is torn by conflict. Civilization has fallen back into the Dark Ages. And yet, we still have hope.

You are a wanderer with the power to change the fate of The City. But your exceptional abilities come at a price. Haunted by memories you cannot decipher, you set out to learn the truth… and find yourself in a combat zone. Hone your skills, as to defeat your enemies and make allies, you’ll need both fists and wits. Unravel the dark secrets behind the wielders of power, choose sides and decide your destiny. But wherever your actions take you, there's one thing you can never forget—stay human.

VAST OPEN WORLD

Participate in the life of a city engulfed in a new dark era. Discover different paths and hidden passages, as you explore its multiple levels and locations.

CREATIVE & BRUTAL COMBAT

Take advantage of your parkour skills to tip the scales of even the most brutal encounter. Clever thinking, traps and creative weapons will be your best friends.

DAY AND NIGHT CYCLE

Wait for night to venture into dark hideouts of the Infected. Sunlight keeps them at bay, but once it’s gone, monsters begin the hunt, leaving their lairs free to explore.

CHOICES & CONSEQUENCES

Shape the future of The City with your actions and watch how it changes. Determine the balance of power by making choices in a growing conflict and forge your own experience.

2-4 PLAYER CO-OP GAMEPLAY

Play in up to four-player co-op. Host your own games or join others and see how their choices have played out differently than yours.

highlighted.name: On the Trail of the Enemy

reviews.review:
Dear Techland

OK, this is coming from a Dying Light series veteran.
FInally got a gaming rig and steam 2ish years ago, so all my old DL1 stuff is on my PS4.

DL2 is overall a phenomenal game, hands down the best parkour EVER. (and yes I have played Mirror's Edge 1 and 2) The amount of control and diff parkour moves that are in this to figure out as you play is unmatched.

This is ultimately what i look for in gaming.  Just give me one massive openworld to explore and freerun around as i please.  Give me a very deep and adjustable skilltree, perks and abilities to upgrade to keep the dopamine hits coming.  I want awesome gearsets, skins, outfits, TRANSMOG!! (thank u finally) and legend levels to keep the end game going for the long haulers.  Most of these things have been provided, but definitely not all.  We'll get into that.

OH, you guys need to make a Gear-set Tab under the Equipped Gear in the Inventory Page.
Would be nice to be able to switch from my Medic build to my Archer build with 1 click.  
Same for Weapons.  If i switch to my Archer build, then i would also like to be able to swap my current weapon Load-out for bow, crossbow, guns, etc. (in one click)

AND HOLY $h!t!  let me put the stamina bar directly below the health bar.  i want it on the screen just not right in my damn face.  
OK...that's out

As dead as the streets are meant to be.  the public space rooftops need to be frickin' poppin'.
Namely the city square itself...The Fish-Eye.  I want to see other NPC Night-runners and or Couriers gliding onto that damn rooftop on their para-gliders, and walk into the bar or just anywhere on the roof (mix it up) and even let me walk up to them and they can give me side quests or something, like info on a rare blueprint, again (mix it up).  Imagine seeing other NPCs gliding around the city, going about their business.  Maybe interacting with some.
(Talk about giving the city a pulse.) 

BTW, what happened with having all sorts of different guilds around the map.  Having them hand out missions and whatnot.  this needs to be looked into.

At night, the people should be locked up in their homes or safe zones...like terrified...like insanely terrified.  However, once that sun comes up, the people should immediately become calm again, opening the windows, doors, etc. (on the rooftops obviously) putting laundry on the clothes lines, baking bread, kids playing, people chatting in their corners, guys chopping firewood, give it a pulse, ya know.

Basically, the Survivors have accepted life on the roofs and that the undead rule the streets below.  Lets embrace that more.  I want to see NPCs freerunning around town on the rooftops.  Parkour is no longer an activity of fitness and expression.  It is the evolution of how we as humans must survive in that world.  Not saying every Survivor member should be a master tracer, but i should be seeing other NPCs out there freerunning.

It should LITERALLY feel like a night and day difference.  Not just the actual light and darkness.  The people need to reflect this better, the pulse and tone of the city needs to reflect this far better.  Day must be lively and bustling with people carrying on however they would in the "Modern Dark Ages".  Night...night should be absolutely terrifying.  I should be hearing NPC mothers telling their children to "hush" and "stay away from the windows!" from inside their homes on the rooftops, while I'm running around outside.  I should be hearing the utter horror in their voices as they say "daddy will be back soon kids, don't worry"  You guys do keep improving the game.  I just reaaalllllly need these things I've mentioned to be added.  I love this game, well the DL Series in general and i want to keep having fun with it.

I'll close with this...may write again
I know I've found a good game when i can beat the entire game, finish every Main Mission, Side Quest, Bounty Hunt, Random Encounter, World Event, ALL OF IT!
and yet, I can still find a game within a game.  When i can run around an awesome openworld with nothing holding me back, having everything the game has to offer...i can make my OWN quests, my OWN adventures.  I find myself getting lost in making my OWN fun.  not waiting for devs to give me the next list of check-boxes to check-off.  (not that you shouldn't be giving us content) I just know that i have found a good game, when i can make my own in the meantime. 
 
Please don't give up on this game.
There is definitely something special here.

quik recap_ i know forgot to mention a few of these but check'em out anyway.

1. Gear-Set Tab / Weapon Load-out Tab

2. Guild Factions - give side quests, hidden Blueprint locations, rare gear/weps, outfits, skins, etc

3. Blacksmiths need to have a Workbench...for disassembling, crafting, upgrading, modding, re-rolling, etc.  (side note, let us disassemble gear, not just weps.)

4. Re-Modding / Re-Rolling Gear/Wep Specs - Mods should be able to be swapped WHENEVER ON WHATEVER (at workbenches only, of course) and mods should stack.  
e.g.  2 Slit Mods should double the crit chance for bleed. (It allows for more options in modding)  and let us re-roll stats on our gear and weps.

5. Pulse or Survival Sense - OK, this one can be controversial, but...You shouldn't start out with this ability, right away AND it should have to be leveled-up.  like lv.1 would be pulse common loot only.  lv.2 could be pulse common loot and rare items.  lv.3 pulses loot, rarities and walkers, lv.4 pulses all enemies.  I mean...however, just shouldn't start the damn game off, being able to pulse everything in the game right off the bat.  Absolute suspense killer.

6. Base Building - doesn't have to be Sons of the Forest or Rust, just have scattered places that we can fix-up/upgrade to add bed, stash, FT>>>, personal workbench, etc.  like the secret Korek Charm Dev Room.  
Let us fix-up a flat or pad.  have like 2 or 3 per district or something. 

7. FULL HUD CUSTOMIZATION - Guys, no HUD...MEANS NO HUD...not the Chase sequence level 1-4, not the Enemy Awareness Meters that circle the damn screen when they're about to see me, no HUD...NO HUD MEANS NO HUD...Immersion guys, immersion.
I don't need or want it, let the player choose how they want to experience their play-through.
Every single individual HUD option should be able to be FULLY customized.

8. FULL CONTROLLER CUSTOMIZATION...FULL...EVERY BUTTON...EVEN CIRCUMSTANTIAL (assassins creed can do it, so can you)  The M&K / Controller is the medium between us and fantasy world you're providing. It's important that feels perfect for the player.

Dying Light 1 was better hands down. The nights were actually scary,  Why take guns out of the game? This one I played 95 hours and was on the verge of completing it when i was patched OUT of the game.  Now it only crashes on load.  Was told my motherboard was no longer compatible.  Of course no refund because i played too long.  THANKS TECHLAND JERKS
reviews.developer_response:
Hey Dave, can you tell me a bit more about this issue with motherboard? What's the model? 

I'm sending you an invite in case you'd prefer to discuss it via DMs.

reviews.review:
Why the hell is the tutorial over an hour long? I really don't think you need an hour long tutorial for a game released in 2022. 

The gameplay is alright but gets dull after a couple of hours. There is no real danger at all, it takes a year for the chase level to increase for volatiles to chase you and you could just stick to rooftops the whole time and you'll never die. Even if you get swarmed, as long as your have the regeneration booster and some other ones, you could literally face tank everything and kill everything.
I feel like the gear system needs more work, the stats seem so minuscule that it doesn't make a difference. The only thing that does make a difference is your weapon. 
The skill tree also needs work, it doesn't seem to have enough impact nor really influence how you play. Especially when you get to the end of the health skill tree, it's an attack skill that you have to attack from above on an unaware enemy which doesn't happen often.
They have all of these places of interest like the recent Assassin's Creed games and it's just incredibly annoying with all the markers and it takes the fun out of randomly exploring.
The looting system is a huge pain, why do I need to hold down a button to loot every zombie but when they despawn, I can just press it once instead to loot the bag?
The enemies are not challenging at all, there is almost no variety between the zombies, humans, or bosses. 
I can make grenades and bombs but ammo and guns aren't a thing in this world?


The parkour is alright but also gets a bit dull after a while. Throughout the story, they give you these puzzles where you basically just look for yellow marks to climb. There are several story missions which you just have to spend several minutes climbing something and it's super annoying. There are also windmills which you have to climb to activate them as well as climbing around in underground metro stations for fast travel points. There are puzzles where you have to connect power sources with a power cable and basically you just look around and connect them, not challenging at all, just tedious and boring.
Later on, they have a bigger map and introduce paragliders, grappling hook, and fast travel which makes parkour obsolete. I just end up paragliding everywhere.

The story is just garbage. The ending is terrible. Your choices don't mean too much in the end, the world isn't impacted in a huge way. Thank god you can skip lines of dialogue for the cutscenes, you can just start speed reading everything. I seriously don't like any of the characters at all, even Aiden is a boring MC. 
I have played some of the side quests but most of them are also boring. There was a quest where you had to do a time trial of parkouring THREE TIMES. 

The co-op is fine and I like how they allow a player to TP all the players to an event however, no progression transfers over so if you want to play alone and you weren't the host, you have to redo everything.
give me 6 hours to beat dying light 2... and i will spend the first 4 figuring out why the game runs at 5 fps

Great Game much improved after the patch's, it still has its flaws but still a decent sequel. Still like the original and dlc more tho, esp its zombie vs human ratio, DL2 focus's abit too much on the human side in some parts for my liking for a Zombie game.

Talking of flaws, choose to let x "live" and y die because y was so damn obnoxious to the point I had to skip y's dialog in many many places. I would have wanted to choose to let y live because it was logical but the way y's personality was written ugh i'd be tempted to save a hamster's life over y's life.
Dying light 2. Stay Broken
reviews.developer_response:
Hey Snork, that was a bit snorky *badum tss*

But seriously, would you mind sharing a bit more about these issues you've been having with the game? I might be able to help or at least forward your feedback to the rest of the team.

I'm sending you an invite in case you'd prefer to discuss it via DMs.

reviews.review:
Dying light 1. 150 hours

Dyinglight 2. 50 hours 

dont have to say more do i.

Dying Light 2 is great but very floaty and inconsistent in how it portrays decline of civilization. If youre looking for dying light one in a new engine youd be close to getting it but my grievances are
-floaty
-grapple isnt the same as from dl1
-no weapon repair
-easier nights 
-majority of quests are fetch quests with lack of insentive other than reward

despite all of this i still recommend this as after going back to dl1. I miss the buggy and grappling hook and the lack of guns and other mechanics makes it feel like a downgrade however i can still see the remnants of the former game shine through in the dlc where it pays homage (albeit kinda lazy and cheesy). If you like any of 
-zombie survival with mainly physical weapons
-parkour
-a good selection of weapon mods 
-crafting weapons (similar to dl1 but not as great)
-hang glider (which imo is really great)
-dark zones where you can find higher level zombies during the day but at night its easier as the high level zombies roam the streets
-Chases now make the zombies feel like a controlled faction who can work together
-Choices that kind of matter to story progression 
and more i cannot think of in my sleep addled state. some of these positives may seem negative and they are since dying light 2 is not the game that dl1 was but as its own game its a parkour focused zombie survival game that has a handful of unique npcs that make you wish to meet them outside the safe zone and kill them to take their stuff but that wouldnt matter since some enemy weapons do not drop and the spear can only be thrown by you but enemies can use it as a weapon. Rant over. Game fine but not the best it can be. 7/10 if dl1 was a 10/10

What is this? The story writing... The voice acting... The fighting mechanics... The parcour mechanics... Holy shit! I almost never write a review on any game, but this... This is pure garbage. I picked this up at 50% off and I still feel ripped off!
Trash game, crashes a lot, not optimized well, more like talking simulator 2, way too boring compared to Dying light 1, just god awful in general

Turd sandwich of a game
Immersion non existent
Combat system a joke
Night time easy, just a timer whoa
Night time chase is just gta stars
Oh you want a refund nope it's 2 hours of tutorial so you can't get your money back

Dying light is a dead game I regret buying it, it's a game worth about 15 dollars don't pay anymore for it 

TRAAAAAASSSSSHHHHHHHHHHHH
This game crashes and freezes way too much. Had to give up nearly 30 hours in because the game literally would crash loading me in
reviews.developer_response:
Hey Kachina, can you tell me a bit more about these crashes? I might be able to help or at least forward your feedback to the rest of the team.

I'm sending you an invite in case you'd prefer to discuss it via DMs.

reviews.review:
TL;DR The story was mid, the endings are mid, Aiden as a character sucks, the quests have no likeable characters, the parkour did not feel that great, night time was basically day, combat was decent.

Play Dying Light 1 instead.

Dying Light 1's motto was "Good Night, Good Luck", which sets the expectation that night time will be dangerous and stayed relevant for basically the whole game.

Dying Light 2's motto "Stay Human" becomes irrelevant outside of the first few hours and any story points after that was not impactful. The mechanic of managing your time in dark areas becomes useless after the first subway mission since you get flooded with uv/time restoring items, and even when the bar 0s out you only take damage over time before completely turning (death). After that mission I never had to pay attention to it again.

In my opinion, the only real good point about this game was the combat. The way weapons and blueprints are upgraded/modded, having i-frames while dodging, and the overall hack-and-slash experience was decent. Too bad drop kicking anything other than volatiles and goons is basically meta as it one shots, while max-modded weapons inconsistently do so. Also, the devs are periodically pushing out events that gives players things to do after beating the story so the game is very much still alive.

Unfortunately, the story is the weakest part of this game and is what makes me not want to replay this game in either New Game+ or a new save. Your actions that shape the world do not matter outside of 2 or 3 important story decisions leading to character conflicts/deaths, but the city itself barely changes. In a Dying 2 Know interview uploaded by IGN, Aiden was described as a rich, deep character, but none of that is reflected in the story. 

Aiden is a glorified errand boy who replies to every request with a "ugh fine I'll do it" and is pushed around the whole time. Every transition from a cutscene or dialogue into a fight is through Aiden getting punched in the face every single time. Pilgrims are supposed to be people who go through hardships and danger every day in the wilderness and we later learn Aiden is supposed to be stronger than others, yet all we see is him being a pushover at every encounter.
There is also a situation later where a companion is injured, but both Aiden and them, 2 seasoned survivors, somehow do not have any bandages/medical supplies and do not think to get some from a warehouse full of it basically next door. A lame plot device to have Aiden continue the mission solo.

The "twist" at the end of the story also feels forced with barely any build up to it and basically gaslights the player's entire experience up until now, followed by an extremely lackluster final boss. Instead of Aiden being sucker punched to transition into the fight, we the player do.

The final boss has something like 3 attacks, 2 of which are easily dodgeable AOEs and basic melee swings. They also run away at set situations to force some parkour gameplay, but in my playthrough I shot them with a pk crossbow after they jumped and they teleported back to the first area stuck in T-pose for a minute while I sandbagged. I had to use melee on my range build so that I didn't accidentally cheese the boss fight.

After the final mission, it reverts back to before that ever happens and you don't get to feel the consequences of your actions. You also don't have the option to do the mission again and can only continue playing sandbox or do new game +.

According to the roadmap, the June 2023 update supposedly addresses issues of the parkour feeling janky and enhances the night, but below are my experiences those before the update.

The parkour was floaty and I felt like I constantly had issues with snapping ledge grabs, even with ledge grab assist off. If you didn't play with that off, trying to climb down any hole or ledge is a nightmare with Aiden constantly re-grabbing the ledge when you drop or jump. It also snaps onto ledges when you don't want it to, and doesn't snap sometimes when you want it to such as climbing up a lipped edge.

In the early game, trying jump up a ledge at max jump height (with the hold spacebar for higher jump perk), it was inconsistent whether you would actually grab the ledge or not. I've had to do the same jump 3-4 times before Aiden would actually grab onto the ledge. There are Agility perks you can get later that resolve this issue, but the original issue was not due to Aiden being inexperienced or weakened like Dying Light 1's early game parkour, but simply things not working when they should.

Even later on when you do unlock every agility perk, there are issues with some activating when you don't want it to such as jumping from pole to pole (atop the hospital), but the character wall runs instead of grabbing onto the pole. Some input based actions like Slide also don't work half the time - could be user error though.

Doing things at night felt no different than the day. Every night was a full moon and flashlights had infinite battery, so it ended up being a darker "day". You also don't see co-op partner flashlights, which was a strange change.

Volatiles were extremely rare, only appearing when you go into dark zones during the day or by causing a level 4 chase which you have to intentionally trigger. If you do run into any, they are usually alone and camped around a flare so you are never in danger of being ambushed by one, and even if you do they are pretty weak. Unless you get swarmed, it was never difficult to get around during the night. Aside from 2-3 fast infected spawning from holes occasionally while you travel and the streets being flooded with slow infected and howlers, nothing really changed.

Also, why do we even have to mash a button every time we want to open small containers like baskets and low tier chests?

I decided to finally get dying light 2 a year after it's release. I decided to finally give it a try. I heard this game got a lot of criticism with it's story. I do somewhat agree I was really confused with it's approach and how it delivered a lot of the characters, choices, and outcomes. but I think when compared to the first dying light it isn't as bad as people say it is. I think the story is supposed to put you in this whole situation knowing nothing in a zombie disaster. Years after the whole thing happened you step into it knowing absolutely nothing. I think that's what the developers wanted for the player anyways. Later in the story I began to sort of look at the whole game differently. Dying light 2 almost feels like it's supposed to be some society put into medieval times. A place named villedor with survivors wearing chainmail, cloth sewn together, and leather vests wielding weapons. It's definitely different from the first game where it's based during the beginning of the outbreak when you play as kyle knowing everything while in this game aiden you know nothing only your goal. definitely am going to have to give it a second playthrough to try and understand more. But the gameplay and the combat is the most satisfying and fun I've had in a while. parkour is very nice too and an improvement. I hope this game gets more flavor as the time goes.

They sold out to Epic. Epic wont let you play with Steam because it needs it's datamining hooks into your account. Just generates an unhelpful error.

The developers and publishers should make playing this game easier, not make you hate the product that so many people worked hard on. 

I am up for playing yet another mid level zombie game. But it's a shame the players arent prioritized. I'd be playing right now with a friend if that was the case.

The people who worked on this game should want to do better. So do better
An extremely disappointing sequel that removes what the first game did best, and innovates on it poorly
reviews.developer_response:
Hey Cybersapien, thanks for playing!

Can you tell me a bit more about what you said in the review? I'd love to forward that feedback to the rest of the team :)

I'm sending you an invite in case you'd prefer to discuss it via DMs.

reviews.review:
Whatever you do, don't get this game if you liked the first one.

I bought it because my sons and I had a really good time playing the first one together in co-op multiplayer and we were all looking forward to more fun with this one.

However, after just 2 hours of trying this out, I realized that this game was very broken.  

Let's start with the movement and parkour.

Gone is any real sense of rapid movement.  You just sort of shuffle along as your 'run' but when you make a jump, while leisurely shuffling along, you make 25 foot jumps with room to spare.  

Then there are the plot devices and other mechanics de-tuning.  
When you swing your baseball bat at your foes, it swings in slow motion, almost as if it's deciding on whether or not it will hit the target.  
Then there are the totally predictable plot devices.like the abundance of infected overruns almost from the very beginning of the game. Like where the companion NPC is fiddling with picking a lock of a door all the while the infected are trying to overrun the location.  
Then there's the broken elevator gag, where the NPC jumps down while warning you about how unstable the elevator is.  But of course he gets off with no problem.  You however, are not so lucky.  you jump down and instead of immediately getting off the 'unstable' elevator, you stand there and wait the full 10-15 seconds till it very predictable falls, taking you with it.

And it was after that second very cliche'd and overused plot situation, that I decided I had had enough, and opted for s refund.

So don't waste your rime if you like likd the first one.

Dying Lite 2: Da Not-So-Brightenin' - like a broken leg dat won't heal. Parkour's slower than a snoozin' sloth on Ambien. Story's as excitin' as watchin' grass grow. Controls are sticky as molasses, tripin' ovr every ledge. Plot's bland as a soggy cracker, characters as shallow as a kiddie pool. Dialogue sounds like monkeys on typewriters. It's painful, mate. Dying Lite 2's a letdown. Save ur cash, buy marbles instead. More fun guaranteed. Trust me, u'll thank me l8r.
Mia.

The positive review that your wished to have is no longer available.

Fix your bloody game's networking issue. Can't play with my friends when coop is the only redeeming factor of this disappointment of a sequel.

applist.name: Travellers Rest
applist.detailed_description:
*NOTE: As the game is in early access not all of these features are implemented, check the early access description for details.

Travellers Rest is a tavern management game where you can brew your own beer, run a farm, and build relationships. You are an innkeeper, on a journey to transform a run-down tavern into a bustling social space. Based in a cheerful fantasy setting, Travellers Rest is a place to meet people, explore new places and uncover ancient magic. Along your journey you’ll discover new things to brew, farm, cook, and build to create your perfect fantasy tavern.


Crafting and progression

Brew beers, distil spirits, and make wines. Create the perfect crisp lager or the wildest sour. Travellers Rest will allow you to discover and craft a whole array of food, drink, and items. Along this journey you'll gain experience to level-up and further customise your character. Spend your points in six technology trees relating to nature, building, cooking, brewing, socialising, and magic!


Tavern

Build and manage your own fantasy tavern! Fully customise it with furniture, cosmetics, decorations, and entertainment for your guests. Increase your tavern reputation over time to earn rewards and unlock more options to make your dream tavern.


Management

Plan and manage your tavern to meet customer demands. Prepare for the weekend rush or a big visitor, such as a famous bard or royalty. Create specific food and drink for the current season or the latest craze.
applist.about_the_game:
*NOTE: As the game is in early access not all of these features are implemented, check the early access description for details.

Travellers Rest is a tavern management game where you can brew your own beer, run a farm, and build relationships. You are an innkeeper, on a journey to transform a run-down tavern into a bustling social space. Based in a cheerful fantasy setting, Travellers Rest is a place to meet people, explore new places and uncover ancient magic. Along your journey you’ll discover new things to brew, farm, cook, and build to create your perfect fantasy tavern.


Crafting and progression

Brew beers, distil spirits, and make wines. Create the perfect crisp lager or the wildest sour. Travellers Rest will allow you to discover and craft a whole array of food, drink, and items. Along this journey you'll gain experience to level-up and further customise your character. Spend your points in six technology trees relating to nature, building, cooking, brewing, socialising, and magic!


Tavern

Build and manage your own fantasy tavern! Fully customise it with furniture, cosmetics, decorations, and entertainment for your guests. Increase your tavern reputation over time to earn rewards and unlock more options to make your dream tavern.


Management

Plan and manage your tavern to meet customer demands. Prepare for the weekend rush or a big visitor, such as a famous bard or royalty. Create specific food and drink for the current season or the latest craze.

reviews.review:
Yes adjacent. Yes maybe, but I want to talk about some issues that need to be fixed.

I'm at tavern Rank 11 out of 12, so the last thing to go is Distilling and I'll have literally gained everything in the game (your new unlocks conclude at 12) and I've done most of the achievements aside from literally unachievable things. Some issues arose in my playthrough.

First, if you edit the original hotel room or the adjacent room, nobody will ever show up to rent it again. I had two guests, and that is all I'll ever have. I think this might have come from putting a cabinet in the rented room? It's unclear.

Second, editing rooms takes way too many resources. You need wood planks, which come from wood, nails, which are iron ingots smelted into iron bars at a furnace and then shaped into nails in an oven, and if you want a door you also need some sort of rock oobleck that is stones shaped into polished stone and then combined with unpolished stone. It's really unviable to make rooms over the course of what would be a reasonable playthrough, and honestly, the extra space should just be bought with money to encourage players to make interesting taverns instead of just sticking with what they have,

Unlocks are a slow trickle, and things like cheese making and distilling require skill point investments along with massive level ups. I think you should either unlock them over time or put exp into them, not both. Again, this encourages you to put all your resources into one valuable recipe instead of diversifying.

The gameplay sort of ancors you at the tavern right now, and it's hard to leave because you're lacking a bouncer and a chef. If you could train an AI employee to cook and brew, or to push away the jerks who try to mess with the bar, it would be way easier to leave. I think as the game adds social systems, it's going to need to be more mindful about the fact that the inn is *a* place, not *the* place.

Iron and coal look startlingly similar.

Text has no speed settings, and right now that's fine because there's very little dialogue and one actual shopkeep who sells very little necessary stuff, but in the future, that's going to be kind of a pain.

You should either be able to customize and name bar employees, maybe even improving their skills, or they should be named NPCs with relationships. I'm too attached to the two idiots that actually work for me (and the maid who showed up twice). I need something concrete to grasp there.

Celebrity visitors look like normal visitors and don't do anything special.


All that out of the way, I sunk 14 hours into an early access game, so there's definitely something there. It just needs more updates- more people to talk to, more places to go, more things to do besides bartending, and more recipes that make leaving the bar more worthwhile than just ordering crap in the mail and selling it.

Still, decent game, and a goofy fun thing to play with friends.
u can smack angry customers away with ur mop

I bought this game recently cos I was feeling the Stardew/ACNL itch, and honestly it was exactly what I wanted!

The overall feel of the game is really cosy, plus it's relaxing but still fast-paced enough to be engaging. The combination of crafting / buying items feels just right, and allows for some really neat customisation I'm excited to see expanded upon. 

If you're after something chill and comforting, this is a really good game for a decent price! Plus you get to hit rude customers with a broom which is honestly all I need in an escapist fantasy tbh

Like many other reviewers I've been feeling the Graveyard Keeper/Stardew Valley itch and when Traveller's rest came on sale for about 10 bucks I decided to finally give it a go.
After playing for about 90' and knowing the game is in "Early Release" I felt "huh it must've released in the past year or so". Nope, Jul 2020!
Despite sharing many elements with the aforementioned games like the same annoying mechanic where unless you’re in bed by 3am you pass out with consequences the game feels incredibly unpolished and unfinished. At least on the Steam Deck the controls are clunky (digging and tilling is an absolute hassle of trying to place and orient your character), the tutorial messages stick even after actions have been completed, and overall the game feels entirely not ready despite it being 3yrs after its release. 
The amount of content feels threadbare outside the main game loop, the story is non-existent, and while the game allows the player to make it as fast-paced as they like operating your tavern can be quite stressful as the game feels unbalanced and prone to hectic moments (0 to everyone ordering at once while all tables and floors turn into a pigsty). 
All in all the game has a lot of potential but has been very slow in adding new content. Judging however from the game’s roadmap under here (https://trello.com/b/CYmkOXl4/travellers-rest-roadmap) it seems that it’s been actively worked on and might become far better in the future. That being said the “main story” being classified as “very-long term” is not encouraging.

Dear devs, great job on creating such an entertaining game, despite it being in early access. However, there is a missing element which would add realism and overall experience - rain. Rain is an element that has the power to transform a games environment and enhance overall exp.

Cause when rain falls from the sky, it brings a sense of peace and wonder why
The gentle pitter-patter on the ground, creates a soothing and peaceful sound

The raindrops dance on leaves and trees, nature's symphony, like a symphony of peace
The earth is soaked with verdant hues, a tranquil canvas that nature imbues

I love the freshness that rain brings, it washes away my blues and things
Every drop quenches the thirst, and revives the earth to its fullest worth

In rain, I find the essence of life, its purity washes away all strife
It's a reminder of how blessings abound, as every raindrop falls silently on the ground

So I cherish the rain and its serenade, its gentle touch and refreshment cascade
I am grateful for every single drop that falls, for rain, my heart constantly calls.

Pls add rain, i really love rain:)

Awesome Tavern Sim. You can really go as hard as you want when it comes to roleplay and realism, as you can create named items and actively make many of the same "dish" to create an estalished menue, or even small things like opening at set times. Its a relaxing game, but still requires a small bit of grinding to maintain high standards. For example, you can hire 
 a bartender and a table boy to help keep things running smoothly, but you, as the owner, has to be present and active while you are open, calming disruptive patrons. It feels beautifully in depth and hands-on, especially the multiple steps and processes to create certain beverages, food items, and building. 

I am eagerly-and perhaps obsessively, waiting on the upcoming update. I am super excited to see the game expand, especially adding new dishes, features, and NPCs. I can see this game becoming a superb mix of Kinseed and Stardew Valley, while being a totally unique experience that can stand on its own. Definitely worth the asking price.
I would describe this as a very wide puddle.  It looks girthy, but it's not very deep.

The concept is great, it's just so fucking tedious. Crafting is super tedious. You have to go out and mine every day or you feel like you missed out on the resources for that day. Clearing land is tedious, farming is tedious. Do you know what you have to do to get one patch of grass ready to plant a seed? Hit it with a scythe, then hit it with a shovel, then hit it with a hoe, go into your inventory, put seeds onto your hotbar, then stand next to the spot and hit F. Seriously, devs look into your # of clicks management. This was for ONE square, now imagine doing this for a whole field. These types of games are especially vulnerable to burnout. The more steps you make for everything exponentially adds to the tedium and eventual uninstalling. There should be little carrot-on-a-stick automation options that unlock earlier and more often to prevent this. You have to babysit your only source of income for 6 levels, while also trying to squeeze crafting and cooking in to just get the option to hire staff. All while we have the time crunch of the ticking clock. (Don't forget to drop everything you're doing to light the fire at 7pm or you'll lose half a level of reputation.) Also, why allow me to unlock bread with no clear instructions about where or how tf you get the food prep table? This game is so close to being one of my gems, but the clunkiness, especially at the beginning is crippling my attempts to load it back up and get into the new content.

As someone who likes Stardew Valley, this game is similar and different. I really enjoy the relaxing nature of the game and if you do like Stardew too then i'm sure you'll like this.
Also you can hit annoying customers with your mop so bonus points.

The game itself is fine. Its just very similiar to games like stardew valley or graveyard digger. Lots of normal crafting and quite the same game loop overall with managing the pub. 

Its very repeptetive to manage the pub.

I discovered this game not that long ago. It certainly has potential and it is a nice relaxing game after a hard day at work. Really appreciate the constant updates and the love from the developers of the game. Give this game a try if you are into cozy relaxing games.

I know I'm a dumdum writing a complain for early access game with just 1.4 hours of play time, but here's my thought. I focused only on the tavern since it's the core offered by the description itself, not farm or mine.

There's just soo little interaction that can be done in the tavern itself. Accept order - clean, that's it. The customers aren't even look alive, just an average soulless NPCs. I thought there would be at least adventurers with sword, wizard, or an adventurer party since it's has fantasy tag, not just medieval alone. Once or twice (pretty rare, it's like gacha for UR item) you'll encounter enraged NPC but it isn't interesting either. Slow sprint also isn't my cup of tea but I won't complain about that if there's more to do. I don't really know for the mid-late game but for the starter, it's pretty boring.

Again, I might be stoopeed for putting my expectation too high for an early access game. But for me, it's just the wrong time to buy.

This game has some massive potential and could be amazingly fun, but at this moment it's not there.

The inn-keep portion of it is actually very fun and portrays the job in a busy yet fun manner. This part of the game gets a 10/10 for me while you run it alone. When you add employees it becomes significantly less fun. The employees do nothing to stay ahead of the rush and complete tasks re-actively instead of pro-actively. This directly reflects real life, but I enjoy playing video games to get away from that. For example, when I bar-tend, I keep a few drinks pre-poured as I go. This means when multiple patrons rush the bar, I have no problem and rarely ever a line. Also as soon as patrons leave the bar I move out into the dining area and wipe down tables so I rarely ever have one get actually get dirty. I could handle 6 large tables like that without incident and rarely actually having to rush (I was even able to dart to my kitchen between rushes to cook food). Now, if I step that up to 8 tables with TWO employees, both just stand around waiting for something to happen which normally results in 3-4 tables getting dirty at the same time and a constant full line at the bar. I actually haven't seen a penalty yet with customer reactions, but this drives me insane. Also, the employees just handle the bar and tables ONLY. You can't walk 6 ft from the bar before a sound goes off to drag you back. You'd want to hire employees so you can take care of other tasks, but everything becomes stressful because when you hire employees you end up running back and forth like a madman to get stuff done as the employees stand there doing minimum work and getting paid 12 SILVER AN HOUR. You can't set a schedule either. You can't just open the bar later and take care of things early in the morning because you can't schedule your employees. They arrive bright and early at 7 am and will stand around charging you 12 Silver an hour DOING NOTHING. If you send them home, that's it, they're not coming back until tomorrow and your stuck with all your tables made for a 2 person minimum team.

The crafting system is pretty confusing too, which I should be used to with anything survival-ish. Chop down trees, mine stone, then go to multiple different crafting benches to take the material through each change until you have a final product... This part I could deal with. However, the game gives you the option of either crafting things or buying with extra money. There's a ton of crafting benches though, some can be made, some can only be bought and very little is actually explained. I can't tell you which are which and I've read through the level up screen and recipe screen like a field-guide. I end up buying everything which is incredibly wasteful, but feels less wasteful than closing the bar for a week to figure out what goes where. I will note though, the kitchen/food prep part actually makes a lot of sense. It's just everything outside being divided into so many different work areas that is very briefly explained. This needs a better setup. I'll also mention expansion is just insanely expensive. The materials aren't so bad, but it's a full gold for every block added. It would be nice if we had the option to close shop and just do it ourselves, but nope... You're going to have to spend 9-20ish gold to add a room, even though you're required to also provide all the materials.

The recipes unlocks are very out of order as well. A lot of what you unlock, you can't actually make due to a later unlock. For example, you can unlock a burger fairly early on, but the recipe calls for cheese which you cannot unlock until DOUBLE your levels later. You also can't buy cheese. You're stuck with a useless recipe until later in game. Even as I write this I wonder if there's not another location/shop/way to make cheese when you first unlock it, but as my last point said the crafting/buying process is far too confusing.

TL/DR
There are some good points to this game such as the atmosphere. There are also far too many stressful points to the game such as the entire employee system and the crafting/buying system. When I play a game like this (or Stardew Valley for example) I would like to sit back and relax and smile. I would like freedom to explore and know my hard work setting up a bar will continue automatically while I'm out doing other things. WHAT I DON'T WANT is being stuck to that bar because I can't trust automation and high paid employees to do basic things like tasking pro-actively or turning on a fire when it gets cold. I also don't want to combine a crafting simulator with a bar simulator. Pick one please. By the title I would guess it's a bar simulator, so make the crafting side simpler. Currently this game is too stressful and complex to really enjoy or suggest. I hope it will get better with updates though.

I'm not far in but so far its a fun game! Chill and just a way to kill a few hours! Really cannot wait to see what this game brings in the future, the style is adorable!

Not really much of a story, but I really hope that changes in the future! There is a bit of lore though if you are into that! The only real complaint though is the furniture crafting, its quite tedious and is just a long process to get even one or two tables. Personally, I feel like it should be simplified but that's just me. I can get used to it, for sure! But i'd rather be doing farming, exploring and making food/drinks to serve to customers as well as just build than having to spend multiple in game days just mining and chopping trees then waiting multiple ingame hours to get all the supplies crafted.

Overall though, i'd rate this game in its current state a 7.5/10. 
[Will probably update my review with more playtime + as the game updates]

If you enjoy Stardew Valley, then this game is for you. I have fell in love with this game. It is still in early access at the moment, but the features that I currently have are amazing. I hope more quests come out because I love that feature but I also love that it has gameplay outside of it. It finally hits that itch where I wanted to play a game similar to FarmVille and Stardew Valley. It is a must have - honest to god best $ 11 i have spent in a while.

TL;DR: could be a great game, but unfinished AF.

I know, it's early access - but it's been early access since 2020 and for it being in development for 3 years there's just neither enough content nor much polish for the existing one.

Most of the game elements seem to have been a "yeah cool idea, let's just dump that into the game and work out the details later". Just to name a few:

* Technology tree: same concept as in graveyard keeper. You earn red, green and blue XP points by crafting various stuff, which you can dump into various perks in four categories: "Brewing" - allows you to unlock about 20 different kind of beers. I am not a beer enthusiast so I have no idea how meaningful those upgrades are. One of the upgrade chain is "Porter -> Amber -> Brown -> Dark". What does that mean? Is Porter bad because it's the first one? What even IS a Porter beer? I have no idea. Is dark beer better than brown beer or why is brown a prerequisite? It doesn't matter either way because all four sell for the exact same amount. They just have a different base ingredient. This might be a nice touch if you actually know a lot about beers but somehow I can't imagine that most people who play games like this do. "Farming" - about 12 perks, each unlocking new seeds for you to order at the mailbox. That's it. "Cooking" - Unlocks some more food recipes. "Crafting" - unlocks the blueprints for more and more crafting benches and decorative stuff. You could basically skip this tree alltogether since every crafting station and most other stuff can be ordered through the mailbox. Most of the time dumping points anywhere feels like absolutely nothing.

* Character Skill tree: you can complete the tutorial quests or daily orders where you have to deliver food or drinks with certain ingredients in it to gain a bit of character XP. You can then spend that XP to get a flat %-bonus to something. 2% faster running, 5% faster table wiping, -2% mailbox prices, etc. - again, super underwhelming and mostly not worth the effort, since XP seems to be all you get from completing orders. Better sell the food and drinks in your tavern.

* Crafting system: every crafting bench basically works like a Factorio assembling machine. You dump in the ingredients, select what you want to create and then your anvil, wood chopping block or stone worker table just magically creates all the stuff by themselves. Simply come back later and collect. If you REALLY want to get into crafting, prepare to spend the first half of every day running the same route static around the map, farming ore nodes. Especially coal. Each and every recipe is super fuel hungry and you have to feed your crafting stations with fuel beforehand. Even the anvil for some reason. If you DON'T feel like getting into all that, just order your stuff from the mailbox and you can completely ignore this part of the game.

* Tavern guests: they come in, wait for their order, sit down, eat, drink, leave. Sometimes speech bubbles pop up above their heads which seem to pull text from a total of six lines or so. Can't tell you how often I've heard the line "She was a fine, fine girl, me pig Stella was." by now. Sometimes people get angry for absolutely no reason and you have X amount of time to speak to them, before they flip their shit and run around the restaurant, insulting others. If you speak to them in time you have a 50/50 chance for them to either calm down or enraging anyway, at which point you just whack them with your broom once and they leave. So this random guy who sits alone in the corner staring at the wall while eating suddenly goes "Yer looking at me?", enrages and runs around to T-Pose behind other patrons. Overall guests just feel like soulless robots.

* Brewing and cooking: just brew and cook whatever is the easiest and gives the most money. For beer there's not much difference. Most of them sell for the exact same amount. Just brew whatever. Food and other drinks seem to have a bit more variety, even tho the recipes are all over the place. Wanna brew some tea? Put in the base ingredients (tea leafs) and then simply dump in an apple, some strawberries and a whole watermelon. Voila, tea!

* Room renting: at some point you can spend obscene amounts of money and resources to expand your inn, build more rooms and rent them out to guests who wish to stay the night. Can't say much about that, I had one room rented out once, decided the money and reputation from it isn't really worth the effort since time invested in the bar pays off a lot more and never touched that side gig again. Noone complained, since guests only ask for a room if there's currently a burning candle in it.

* Moving: you can simply toggle the sprint button and let it stay active forever. No penalty for permanently going fast.

* Gathering: ore veins are limited and have fixed locations. If they're in your way of building something, bad luck, you can't remove them. Build somewhere else! Mining them leaves an empty looking rock formation behind which magically refills itself with coal/copper/iron the next. Same with fruit trees, fixed locations. Farm them every few days for free apples, pears, oranges or even mangos or citrus fruits! What a fantastic climate.


There's more, but I'm out of steam for this review.
Okayish game if you are bored and can get it very cheap but as I said at this state it's super super unfinished. 
A mix of Graveyard Keeper and Stardew Valley with ~10% the content of those games.
i can hit people with my broom!
smashing customers with a broom just like what my grandmother did to me when i was 8 years old 🤘

My girlfriend just dumped me and this game is just what the doctor ordered.

Seriously, though, very much enjoying it right off the bat. It might be early access but the initial tutorials etc. are very clear and easy to follow and I never felt lost - and I am not very familiar with these kinds of games. If you are stressed and want to chill this is a great cozy choice so far. I'll update this review after I'm farther in.
if you like stardew you'll like this

applist.name: Watch Dogs®: Legion
applist.detailed_description:
Comparative Grid


Ultimate Edition



Get the most complete Watch Dogs experience with the Ultimate Edition including the base game, season pass, and the Ultimate Pack. Season pass includes a major expansion, extra missions, four iconic heroes, and immediate access to the Watch Dogs®: Complete edition! Ultimate pack includes 3 unique characters, additional masks, and 4-week VIP status.

Build your resistance to take back a near-future London facing its downfall.

Recruit and play as anyone from London. Everyone you see has a unique backstory, personality, and skills.
Hack armed drones and take down enemies using an Augmented Reality Cloak.
Explore a massive open world featuring London’s many iconic landmarks and fun side activities.


Gold Edition



The Gold Edition includes the Season Pass: one expansion with two episodes, extra missions, four heroes and the Original Watch Dogs Complete edition!

Build a resistance from virtually anyone you see as you hack, infiltrate, and fight to take back a near-future London that is facing its downfall. Welcome to the Resistance.

Recruit and play as anyone in the city. Everyone you see has a unique backstory, personality, and skill set.

Explore a massive urban open world featuring London’s many iconic landmarks and fun side activities.


Deluxe Edition

Enhance your Watch Dogs®: Legion experience with the Deluxe Pack.

This pack includes:
- The London Dissident Pack
- Lynx Operative
- 1 Week of VIP Pass

Build a resistance from virtually anyone you see as you hack, infiltrate, and fight to take back a near-future London that is facing its downfall. Welcome to the Resistance.

Recruit and play as anyone in the city. Everyone you see has a unique backstory, personality, and skill set.

Take the resistance one step further and fight with your friends in new missions in Online mode.


About the Game

Build a resistance made from anyone in the world to take back a near-future London that is facing its downfall.

Recipient of over 65 E3 awards and nominations.

Recruit and play as anyone from London. Everyone you see has a unique backstory, personality, and skill set for unique situations.

Hack armed drones, deploy spider-bots, and take down enemies using an Augmented Reality Cloak.
Explore a massive urban open world featuring London’s many iconic landmarks and fun side activities.
Team up with your friends as you complete co-op missions and unique game modes.
Upgrade to the Gold Edition or Ultimate Edition for access to the season pass and more!

reviews.review:
Oh Jesus...

This game had such a promising concept and honestly, a really cool gameworld, but it just fell short in almost every way. 

Watch Dogs Legion isn't a terrible game, and it isn't even a bad game. It's just... a game. It's underwhelming. The game features most of the same mechanics as Watch_Dogs 2, but doesn't apply them in an interesting way. It bothers me because I don't know how to describe why. It just feels really unsatisfying. The whole time I was playing, I kept thinking about Watch_Dogs 2 and how much fun it was. Sure, it was an incredibly stupid game about stupid people who do stupid things for stupid reasons, but it was really good. The map felt fun to explore and the missions and side-activities were (mostly) fun. It's so charmingly dated, as well. It's an unintentionally hilarious time capsule of mid-2010s American culture.

Watch Dogs Legion, on the other hand, is just missing something. The game takes place in an alternate near-future Britain which has isolated itself from the rest of the world, and has found itself under the control of a nasty PMC that has enforced a totalitarian surveillance state. The premise is actually a cool concept for a video game setting and reminds me of similar dystopian works like V For Vendetta and Children of Men, which are both about an isolationist, authoritarian Britain. However, the game doesn't really DO anything with it. 

One of the game's main problems is the lack of a main protagonist. Instead, you play as a series of randomly-generated DedSec operatives who your other randomly-generated DedSec operatives can recruit into the group, like some kind of hacking themed MLM. Each of these operatives has their own skills and special abilities. For instance, I had a hypnotist who could use her skills to make enemies turn on each other. You really can recruit anyone, regardless of their skills. Hell, you could make a DedSec cell that consisted entirely of pensioners if you wanted. I had a spy in my squad who I made look like the unholy child of Austin Powers and Jarvis Cocker. 

Unfortunately, the execution of the mechanic didn't really do it for me. It made the game's story feel really unfocused and impersonal. The game in general, had almost no interesting or memorable characters. The only character who I remember in any detail is the game's "mission control" AI, Bagley, but only because he's so incredibly annoying. There was one storyline surrounding one of the game's main villains and how she creates her corporation's AIs. That was kind of interesting, but felt kind of out of place in a game set in a relatively grounded near-future sci-fi setting. It was more like something out of Shadowrun or Cyberpunk 2077/2013/20whatever.

All-in-all, I can't recommend Watch Dogs: Legion. If you want the same game, but better, just buy Watch_Dogs 2.

Bought at full price on launch because I loved watch dogs 2! Refunded within 30 minutes after writing the saddest email to Ubisoft. Saw it on sale for only a handful of doubloons on steam, figured I may as well try it and see if they fixed anything.

They didn't, the world is still bland and dead, the only character is an annoying British AI and the rest are copy paste interactions with no script. Just a generic statement and a generic response as 90% of the interactions. This is because you can "play as any character! any at all!" which in turn means all of them are completely lifeless. What was the point of this? Who likes this? This feels like so much extra work than a much more satisfying single character or even small crew of characters to switch from. Am I missing something? Why would they do this?

Okay, so the story, characters and writing sucks. There are plenty of games like that that are still great, maybe I'm just disappointed it's not what I expected and the things I enjoyed in the last games aren't here?

Well, the gameplay sucks too. Every mission feels like it was randomly generated, and all of them can be solved by flying on a cargo drone. I have no clue which missions I did were randomly generated and which were actual main storyline scripted.

Would refund a second time, but sadly I was too optimistic and decided to give it an actual chance of a few hours. Genuinely might be the laziest game I've ever seen, and worst of all everyone speaks British.

Watch Dogs: Legion... That's a tough one. This game is a bit of a wildcard if you ask me. What is good in this game is really really good, but there are some things that could hold people back. I'm glad Ubisoft was willing to take risks and be pretty creative when it comes to this game, but when trying something new, things are bound to go wrong in some aspect. Here is a list of pros and cons I created:

Pros:
- The fact that you can recruit anyone is pretty cool in my opinion, and the developers made some pretty solid choices on what they consider as "skilled recruits," like spies, street artists, anarchists, construction workers, DJs, and a few more. I personally think the list is great and offers a diverse amount of approaches to many missions.
- The story is decent. I know for a fact that not everyone likes the story, but I'm personally fine with it. Long story short, you play as the Dedsec: London organization, which gets framed for a huge bombing. Now, you have to step in and recruit operatives while taking down many corrupt organizations and figure out who was actually responsible for it. It's definitely not a narrative masterpiece, but it's enough to keep you entertained.
- There are a countless amount of ways to take on missions in the game. You could sneak in by stealth, shoot up the place, or just get a drone or spiderbot to do most of your dirty work. Many playstyles to choose from.
- Drones and spiderbots are in my opinion a pretty fun addition to the game and add some complexity to it. Some can be used to infiltrate a base, or just go on a rampage if you really want to.

Cons:
- The characters, both playable and not, don't really have all that much to them in terms of personality. Even if you just recruit a few people, you are most likely going to run into the same voices and "personalities." I also find it a bit weird how the character who has the most personality is not a human being, but a computer, which is pretty ironic. The acting is also... okay, I guess... and that is only talking about the npcs. The people you can recruit were voiced by a mix of human and A.I., which is not the way to go.
- Watch Dogs 1 and 2 had some really cool features, like the smartphone. It's very sad to see features like these not return to legion. While I do understand that legion is supposed to be different, I think the game would have been better if those features stayed, as they were really good. 
- Guns and combat feel like a downgrade, not really in terms of gameplay, but it's the fact that you can't have a good arsenal unless you find a professional hitman or buy Aiden Pearce. You can only buy 4 guns that are shared with all operatives. If they added more guns to the shop, especially lethal ones, then this wouldn't be a problem.
- I have run into a few bugs, most notably framerate drops, which could mess someone up in gameplay especially me.
- The game's map does not have much to it. Most of it is just city buildings. I do understand that it's based off of an actual city, but I wish they had a portion outside of London where it's more trees, less buildings, and more creative road designs. 

My final thoughts: The game is overall pretty solid in my opinion. it is no stranger to issues, but I suppose everything has its ups and downs, and many people have different tastes, and that should especially be considered as this game is unlike the other 2 games in the series. I'm glad, however, that Ubisoft was willing to take risks and try something new, and I personally like the game. If you're looking for a dystopian-style open world game with a decent story and a series of diverse playstyles and playable characters, then this will most likely be the game for you. This game is absolutely not worth full price however, so if you are thinking about buying it, wait until it goes on sale. I bought it when it first released on steam for 12 dollars, and I think it was 12 dollars pretty well spent, and I spent about 48 dollars in total for the game and all the DLCs, and I had a blast! Thank you for reading this review and I hope you find it helpful.
