TL;DR: it was a good watch-dogs game, but felt repetetive after a (quite early) point and the non-sale price is way too overpriced for this experience; i only recommen to play this game if the previous games were also enjoyable

The Good:
-  Bagley is great
- Bloodline DLC was a great experience, especially with the hybrid spider drone (combined bot and drone)
- This game has some really good missions like the [spoiler]"broken spiderbot"[/spoiler] or [spoiler]"heavy military drone going around and destroying things"[/spoiler] or [spoiler]"race mission switching between car and drone and boat"[/spoiler] 
- Controls of the spiderbot / drone were way better compared to previous games implementations

The Annoyances:
- The benchmark option just never worked correctly (just getting a black screen, while somehow being able to play the game with a preset save)
- Loading takes quite a long time when the game is not on a SSD (whereas things like modern Assasins Creed games load quite fast, on the same hardware)
- The Final / Ending mission had way too many loading screens (switching characters, going in / out of buildings)
- Ubisoft connect just randomly stops working
- Unlike previous games, this game does not have a feature where when the player is in a chase to activate relevant actions (like pushing up the pillars behind the player when something is near or messing the traffic-lights)
- The "Team" section in the interface (to switch characters) was running VERY slowly, like at most ~5 fps after having got more than ~10 characters, whereas the game itself ran fine (between 30 to 75 fps, depending on location)
- The game has way too many tech (upgrade) points, i am someone who completed the map before the story (including tech points), i had everything unlocked before even getting the last tech-point from the map; and then the missions themself were also giving even more tech points, which could not be spent anymore
- There were missions which required the player to go to a specific location without any Quest Marker OR some kind of indicator on how near the player is
- Cars that were not Police cars felt quite weird to control (though that may just be my feeling)
- The Bloodline final boss was quite hard, compared to all stories before; especially because you could not change the load-out when respawning
- Relic descriptions were way longer than the text-box was able to display and was also not scrollable
- More than once a character had just been "yeeted" of a cargo drone, seemingly without any reason (like high velocity into a direction that was not up or down)

Other notes:
- This is the first game in the series where i didnt see anything related to the character "T Bone"
- The non-Sale price (of ~99.99€ for the Gold Edition, to include the bloodline dlc) is in my opinion way too much, especially when they contain useless things like another version of Watch Dogs 1 (because i own it already) or VIP status; also considering that the game is way older than the steam release
- VIP status just amounted to: Higher EXP gain, less cooldown after a character "died"
- Multiplayer was literally unplayable in Proton
- Many operators is a great concept, but in my playthrough it was quite the annoyance to have to switch often or having to recruit specific ones and having so many loadingscreens
- Sadly the game was not available on steam on actual release date, unlike the previous entries in the series
- When having a Cargo-Drone, some missions can be cheesed by just staying outside of the "aggression zone" while doing the mission with the spiderbot (though there was one mission which required triggering the aggression, even though the actual objective was completed, like it said "Get to safety" but it never triggered however far i way away, and going back and triggering the aggression and then going outside completed the mission then)
- Map traversal was way easier with a Cargo Drone than a car
- Some Story missions made it seems like the player had an actual choice on how to affect the world, but those did not affect much at all
- The Bloodline DLC story was in my opinion better than the Main story
- The Game has things like context clues (dont remember the actual name) with text and audio, but the bloodline also added pictures to that

Played on:
- Manjaro (Kernel 6.1.7) with KDE Plasma + Wayland + Pipewire
- Proton Experimental
- GPU: AMD Vega 64
- CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 5800X

applist.name: PAYDAY 2
applist.detailed_description:
PAYDAY 2 is an action-packed, four-player co-op shooter that once again lets gamers don the masks of the original PAYDAY crew - Dallas, Hoxton, Wolf and Chains - as they descend on Washington DC for an epic crime spree.

The CRIMENET network offers a huge range of dynamic contracts, and players are free to choose anything from small-time convenience store hits or kidnappings, to big league cyber-crime or emptying out major bank vaults for that epic PAYDAY. While in DC, why not participate in the local community, and run a few political errands?

Up to four friends co-operate on the hits, and as the crew progresses the jobs become bigger, better and more rewarding. Along with earning more money and becoming a legendary criminal comes a character customization and crafting system that lets crews build and customize their own guns and gear.

Key Features

  • Rob Banks, Get Paid – Players must choose their crew carefully, because when the job goes down they will need the right mix of skills on their side.
  • CRIMENET – The dynamic contract database lets gamers pick and choose from available jobs by connecting with local contacts such as Vlad the Ukrainian, shady politician "The Elephant", and South American drug trafficker Hector, all with their own agenda and best interests in mind.
  • PAYDAY Gunplay and Mechanics on a New Level – Firing weapons and zip tying civilians never felt so good.
  • Dynamic Scenarios – No heist ever plays out the same way twice. Every single scenario has random geometry or even rare events.
  • Choose Your Skills – As players progress they can invest in any of five special Skill Trees: Mastermind, Enforcer, Ghost, Technician and Fugitive. Each features a deep customization tree of associated skills and equipment to master, and they can be mixed and matched to create the ultimate heister.
  • More Masks than Ever – PAYDAY 2 features a completely new mask system, giving players the ability to craft their own unique mask with a pattern and color of their choice, resulting in millions of different combinations.
  • Weapons and Modifications – A brand new arsenal for the serious heister, covering everything from sniper and assault rifles to compact PDWs and SMGs. Once you've settled for a favorite, you can modify it with optics, suppressors, fore grips, reticles, barrels, frames, stocks and more, all of which will affect the performance of your weapon. There are also purely aesthetic enhancements - why not go for the drug lord look with polished walnut grips for your nine?
  • Play It Your Way – Each job allows for multiple approaches, such as slow and stealthy ambushes or running in guns blazing. Hit the target any way you want, each approach will provide a different experience.
  • A Long History of Additional Content – More than 70 updates since release, including new heists, characters, weapons and other gameplay features like driving cars and forklifts.

[h1]"Payday 2: Where Grand Heists and Bullet Ballets Meet Unforgettable Chaos"[/h1]

[b]Step into the adrenaline-fueled world of Payday 2, where a symphony of heists, teamwork, and glorious chaos awaits. This game is a wild ride that will keep you on the edge of your seat and craving for more criminal escapades.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2968856428

From the moment you slip on your iconic masks and assemble your crew of misfit criminals, Payday 2 catapults you into a whirlwind of high-stakes robberies and thrilling shootouts. The level of customization and strategy available is mind-boggling. You can meticulously plan your heists or throw caution to the wind and embrace the glorious madness of improvisation.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2958103843

One of the most remarkable aspects of Payday 2 is its impeccable attention to detail. The environments are richly designed, immersing you in intricately crafted levels that feel like real-life locations. Whether you're infiltrating a heavily guarded bank, liberating a high-security museum exhibit, or rescuing hostages in a bustling urban area, each scenario presents its own unique challenges and surprises.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2960751154

But what truly sets Payday 2 apart is the game's ability to make you feel like a true action movie protagonist. The intense firefights are a visual spectacle, with bullets whizzing past, explosions shaking the surroundings, and the sound design amplifying the adrenaline rush. The sheer variety of weapons and equipment at your disposal allows for creative approaches, ensuring that no two heists play out the same way.


Beyond the exhilarating gameplay, Payday 2 shines in its emphasis on cooperation. Coordinating with your teammates, synchronizing your actions, and pulling off a perfectly timed heist brings an unmatched sense of satisfaction. Whether you're reviving a fallen comrade, delivering a crucial bag of loot, or holding off a relentless SWAT assault, teamwork is the key to success.

While Payday 2 excels in many areas, it's not without a few blemishes. The AI teammates, while competent, could benefit from some additional polish to enhance their decision-making abilities. Furthermore, occasional technical hiccups can momentarily disrupt the immersive experience, but they rarely detract from the overall enjoyment.

[b][u]In conclusion[/u], Payday 2 is a heart-pounding, action-packed masterpiece that delivers an unparalleled heist experience. With its meticulous attention to detail, intense gameplay, and a strong emphasis on cooperation, it's a game that will keep you coming back for one more perfect score. So gather your crew, load your weapons, and prepare for a thrilling journey into the realm of high-risk criminality. Just remember, in Payday 2, chaos and triumph often go hand in hand.[/b]

POSTED: APRIL 8
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game used to be actually fun, but long time ago everything in PAYDAY 2 became good/bad in terms of balance. There are overpowered perk-decks, there are useless weapons, dodge/crit meta, armor's now almost has no meaning to use, tons of DLCs and they don't stop coming. Play with Restoration Mod or install 37.1 version instead, two great ways to make the game really entertaining and balanced at the same time.

Unfortunately, the state of this game as it stands is horrendous. You can get the game on sale generally for $2.49 to $0.99, but that's about all it's worth, as a large amount of the games content is locked behind about 50 DLCs that each usually cost half of the games' off-sale value. 

The gameplay holds up okay until about the mayhem difficulty, but past that, the gameplay heavily diminishes from there. The game starts becoming heavily reliant on having an extremely well optimized setup, which has next to zero room for customization, which in-turn heavily dampens your potential enjoyment of the game. Why are the higher difficulties so bad? Because they literally just multiply the enemies health and damage, even more so on the death sentence difficulty. Once you get to that point, you take such a ridiculous amount of damage that you might as well not have a health and armor bar unless you're running the one type of build that works, that being armor gating (which, to do reasonably effectively, needs a DLC perk deck). There's only really 4 viable weapon loadouts that work at that point too, using one of two specific LMGs (both locked behind DLC), using one of two specific flamethrowers (one of which is locked behind DLC), using a dual wield auto shotgun, or using an RPG (locked behind DLC). The last 3 are not viable for many crucial situations due to one reason or another, so you're [i] really [/i] just out of luck as a non-DLC player.

There are many more reasons why I cannot entirely recommend this game:

The expectation of having a 4-player friend group, which a number of achievements (and gameplay-effecting rewards) require to complete. Bots are so frequently insufficient in a lot of ways that make other achievements virtually impossible, as well.

Like mentioned above, most of the interesting and fun weapons, perk decks, and skills are outright not viable in harder difficulties. I am essentially told I'm not allowed to have fun as a slow juggernaut with an M60 because my armor gets turned into swiss cheese anyway and the M60 has such a low DPS that literally every other LMG outclasses it.

Tactical combat just does not exist. Enemies will simply suicide rush into you with zero care and have no group tactics. They themselves will also do what would NEVER happen if this were even semi-realistic, like tazing you even if there are dozens of civilians around to potentially be shot, or gassing buildings with civilians in them. On higher difficulties, this becomes more apparent where enemies will run around a corner into the open (even with multiple guns trained on their every move) and near-instantly down you.

Don't get me wrong, though, I quite enjoyed my first 200 hours of the game, and could say it was worth it despite the amount of money I sank on DLC. I also wanted to collect all of the achievements at some point, but I now realize my goal is extremely unrealistic without a well-coordinated group of four and only one viable setup that will get really stale quite quickly.

I am really looking forward to and hoping that Payday 3 has improvements in all of these areas. I will gladly pay $70 upfront for it even if the only things that are properly addressed is the issues with balancing (both with the game difficulty and with your setup) and with DLC. Only time will tell, I suppose, and at least that time is soon.

applist.name: Green Hell
applist.detailed_description:
Forever Skies


Experience Green Hell in VR

https://store.steampowered.com/app/1782330/Green_Hell_VR/


Join our Discord server


About the Game

GREEN HELL is an Open World Survival Simulator set in the uncharted unique setting of the Amazonian rainforest.

You are left alone in the jungle without any food or equipment, trying to survive and find your way out. Clinging to life, the player is set on a journey of durability as the effects of solitude wear heavy not only on the body but also the mind. How long can you survive against the dangers of the unknown?

On this journey, you won’t get any help from the outside world. Equipped only with your bare hands you’ll have to learn actual survival techniques to build shelters, make tools, and craft weapons in order to hunt and defend yourself. Constantly threatened by the jungle you’ll fight with both wild animals and tropical sicknesses. Players will also have to face the traps set by your own mind and fears that crawl in the darkness of the endless jungle.

STORY
You are thrown deep into the emerald and impenetrable Amazonian rain forest. The green hell. Your goal is to survive in the depths of a nightmarish environment using truly intuitive means to escape. Having only a radio at your disposal you will follow the familiar voice of a loved one through this endless and inhospitable jungle, unveiling bit by bit how you got there in the first place. What you discover will be worse than what you fought so hard against to survive.

THE QUESTION
Where can the human mind wander?

GAME PILLARS

REALISTIC SURVIVAL SIM
• Use of true survival techniques (including starting fires, camp building, animal traps construction)
• Sourcing and composing objects allowing survival (including weapons and tools)
• Food sourcing (hunting, cropping)
• Wound, disease and other injuries treatment, depending on the situation

PSYCHOLOGICAL THRILLER
Green Hell's story emphasizes psychological aspects of survival in extreme conditions. The player faces a ruthless situation, isolated, and fighting to survive another day. The players battle will not only be against the environment as you fight to keep your sanity. Will you succeed or fall into the depths of your mind? To unveil the truth the player will have to fight the hardest battle they will ever fight - the fight against themselves, their weaknesses and fears.

AMAZONIAN RAINFOREST SETTING
Amazonian rainforest is the richest natural environment in the world. Exotically breathtaking, spectacular, multicolored, full of tones and sounds but mortal, deadly, uncompromising for the ignorant.
• Part of the Amazonian rainforest as a map of the world for the setting
• The richness of plants and multitude of animal species (mammals, reptiles, birds, and insects)
• Simulation of animals natural occurrence and behavior
• Dynamically changing environment due to the weather

UNIQUE MECHANICS
Survival in such extreme conditions requires willpower - without it we are sentenced only to madness and death. In green Hell, your wellbeing, both physical and psychological, are strictly related. Body inspection mode allows the player to diagnose themselves and heal their body. In this mode, we can also remove all kinds of parasites that decided to make a home out of your body.
Psychophysical parameters of the player include:
• psychological condition
• physical condition

UNIQUE FEATURES
• Setting: deadly yet beautiful Amazonian rainforest
• Body inspection mode
• A multitude of fauna and flora and the dangers awaiting the player
• Environment and situation impact on the player’s psychology
• Impact of environment changes to the ecosystem
• An addictive story
• Dynamically changing environment
applist.about_the_game:
GREEN HELL is an Open World Survival Simulator set in the uncharted unique setting of the Amazonian rainforest.

You are left alone in the jungle without any food or equipment, trying to survive and find your way out. Clinging to life, the player is set on a journey of durability as the effects of solitude wear heavy not only on the body but also the mind. How long can you survive against the dangers of the unknown?

On this journey, you won’t get any help from the outside world. Equipped only with your bare hands you’ll have to learn actual survival techniques to build shelters, make tools, and craft weapons in order to hunt and defend yourself. Constantly threatened by the jungle you’ll fight with both wild animals and tropical sicknesses. Players will also have to face the traps set by your own mind and fears that crawl in the darkness of the endless jungle.

STORY
You are thrown deep into the emerald and impenetrable Amazonian rain forest. The green hell. Your goal is to survive in the depths of a nightmarish environment using truly intuitive means to escape. Having only a radio at your disposal you will follow the familiar voice of a loved one through this endless and inhospitable jungle, unveiling bit by bit how you got there in the first place. What you discover will be worse than what you fought so hard against to survive.

THE QUESTION
Where can the human mind wander?

GAME PILLARS

REALISTIC SURVIVAL SIM
• Use of true survival techniques (including starting fires, camp building, animal traps construction)

content_descriptors.notes: The game has mild levels of violence. The player needs to hunt for survival and fight with the enemy tribes. The player's character may consume human flesh when in extreme hunger, although it's not required nor he's encouraged to do so, as it leads to negative psychological effects. The game is depicting various diseases that will have impact on characters body. Some of their symptoms may be found disturbing. The player may also enter a hallucinating state after eating various hallucinogenic plants and mushrooms scattered around the jungle.

reviews.review:
For those wondering how different this game is from the forest, here's a perspective from someone who owns both games.

The main difference is that green hell isn't a power fantasy like the forest. In the forest you can blow up mutants and cannibals with molotovs and bombs. Or use fire arrows or flares to light enemies on fire. You can also upgrade you weapons with stuff like human teeth and bird feathers to give them a stat buff. Green hell is less combat focused. You get different tiers of tools and weapons, with stone being basic tier and metal being the best tier. That's about it, you can't blow up jaguars or natives with bombs or light them up with flares.

Green hell does have tribal native people, but they are much less of a nuisance. They don't spawn often and even if they do, they won't send waves of tribals near your location. They spawn, and if they spot you and you kill them all, it won't escalate any further like things do in the forest. There are only two main types of tribal people, archers and spearmen, no Virginia mutants or cave mutants. Again, it's less focused on combat.

Enemies in the forest are all human based. In green hell, there's more variety, you get jaguars, mountain lions, caiman and other hostile animals. And these animals don't fuck around and an unprepared encounter can easily spell death. A leaf bandage will do fine against scratches but it won't do anything against a deep jaguar laceration. It depends on if you have the knowledge to treat the laceration, better yet, kill any animals before they can even harm you. That said, it takes knowledge and skill, since you all you have are spears and bow/arrows, no molotovs or bombs.

Food and water is also much deeper in green hell. You have different nutrients such as proteins, fats and carbohydrates, so eating a piece of meat won't replenish your carbohydrates, it's less like the forest where you can likely survive off a single food source. And this mechanic isn't here just for the sake of variety, failing to satisfy any one of these nutrients can lead to reduced health and stamina, which can further affect your ability to survive.

This is a good segue into stamina. Stamina in green hell is also very important, it doesn't just affect your movement and combat. If your stamina and energy fall too low, you'll pass out on the spot. This will then lead to parasitic worms living underneath your skin, rapidly draining your sanity, which if left untreated can spell another death. So to stop yourself from passing out and getting worms, you need to sleep regularly on a bed. Stamina also dictates if you can light a fire, unlike the forest, you don't have a Bic lighter with infinite fuel, you need to start a fire with a drill firestarter, which uses a substantial amount of stamina and energy. If you don't have a fire, you can't purify and boil water, or cook any raw meat you have. Foods in green hell expire quickly if you don't cook or eat them.

Next is the sound design. Green hell's sound design doesn't just sound good, it is also very very crucial to survival. In the jungle, there's an overgrowth of bushes and trees, so it's very easy to miss any threats that are around you, such as rattlesnakes, giant ass spiders, tribal people and Jaguars. The only reliable way to identify these threats is by the distinct sound in which they make. Hear a snake rattling? Stop moving any closer and go around the source of the sound. Hear the low growl of a jaguar inching closer? Get ready for an encounter. Hear the singing of tribal people? Crouch down and avoid alerting them. Because more times than not, you won't be able to see these threats. In the forest, you can turn off sound completely and still stay alive, but in green hell, turning off sound will get yourself killed by various threats.

Lastly, I want to talk about difficulty. So far I've built up green hell to be this hardcore survival game, whether it is 100% realistic or not is still debatable with sometimes questionable AI patterns, but in its core, green hell is a hardcore survival game. That said, it's actually very customizable in its difficulty. Don't want to get bit by snakes and spiders? You can actually turn it off, don't want to deal with tribal people? You can turn it off as well. Don't want to deal with sanity, there's another option for that as well. It's much more customizable than the forest. You can go in blind and get killed over and over again. But like any hardcore game, it can be very rewarding. If you want to challenge yourself or just want to play like an Amazonian tourist, you can customize the difficulty to your own liking.

Pretty solid survival game all things considered IMO. If you enjoy the show "Alone", this game is the closest i've played to that. You will probably die quite a bit at first while you learn the ropes. 

What this game does different than other survival games:
- The inventory system in the game limits how much you can carry quite a lot, especially in building items such as logs, mud bricks, large stones, etc. 
- The inventory system means that most bases will be built near a water source for ease of access to bricks and most bases won't be as large as you see in other games similar to this like Rust, Ark, etc. It will take you many in game nights to build what people would call a "2x2" on Rust.
- Food is difficult to stockpile due to lack of inventory "space". Having renewable food sources is tougher to get than most survival games. Fish do that quite well.
- Hydration is way tougher to manage in this game. You can't make a fire if you are tired. You also can't make a fire  if its raining unless its under a shelter you've built (or found). 
- Sleep is interesting. When it hits zero, you pass out, and will wake up with some new "friends" living under your skin. 
- I found myself building many "outpost" or "FOB" type bases which have: Always near water source, a roof so I can make a fire in rain, and a sleeping mat. Spread these among the map and it's really easy to explore.

Cons:
- Sadly all combat boils down to "hit them in the head" be it natives or some animal. As long as you aren't overwhelmed most engagements are very simple if you hit the HEAD. I think hitting the body should do way more damage
- IMO Leeches being impossible to prevent or at least lessen the occurrences gets rather annoying the more you play but maybe it is realistic

It's a pretty steep learning curve. With little to guide you on survival, it's quite tough just to stay alive for 1 whole day at the start. I dropped the game when I first started. But with a few tries, and learning from some mistakes, it got a lot better.

One of the big selling points for me, also, is that it isn't crazy dark at nightfall. Yes, it's darker, but the moonlight is often bright enough for you to move around, so you're not totally screwed in the wee hours.

Would not recommend if you don't wanna spend a few hours just getting the hang of the game mechanic. Would recommend for a pretty decent survival game with an actual story that isn't too creepy (like the Forest).

Here's how I can explain the difficulty level of the game to you. I can survive in Turkey, but I can't survive in this game.
Everything is very detailed, carbohydrate, fat, protein, water must be kept in balance. I can't keep them in balance in my normal life. The game is good, you need to use your brain I guess that's why I was eliminated lol
Great Game, Lots of Content now with Spirits of Amazonia!

The first game ever to give me severe motion sickness. It's a known issue with this game, and I've been waiting almost 5 years for them to fix it. There's still no setting for motion blur or head bob. Movement is still sluggish with a noticeable delay. What a joke.

This game takes literally forever to do the simplest things, not everyone has the massive amounts of time just to build one tree platform much less an actual house or full building with walls and roof. If you have a job or outside life, then this game is not for you, It makes you sink hours and hours of time into it with very little reward, literally anything you do will take forever.
amazing story. i could not recommend this game enough.

I admit, this is one of the more difficult survive games, and the learning curve can be steep. Don't give up, run the story and take your time.

Inventory management is a pain; you need to manage weight as well as how much you can carry. Weapon and combat is a little akward; some weapons are far more effective for combat, but less effective for anything else. Crafting can sometimes be frustrating; as most patterns are stored in your book, sometimes learning them or remembering what goes where can be a pain. Or trying to place certain items when building structures is very limiting sometimes.

However, in terms of overall gameplay, story or just having fun with friends this is by far one of the most fun games I've played that's survival, crafting and hunting.

Just watch out for the cats.

10 minutes into the jungle I got burned by the heat, leeches on my legs, starving, hideous voices threatening me, got hunted by jaguar and hostile tribal, parasites in stomach, ate raw snails and unknown fungus, got food poisoning, fell asleep while admiring the beautiful scene and died. 10/ 10.
This is very realistic its a pretty difficult game but its also very fun just also difficult so if u play expect a difficult experience
I did not expect that I would level up my fists to the max by punching dead bodies for an hour straight.
Good game, but the story is a little short.

Loved playing through green hell. In my opinion, the food/drink/leech/worm/insanity/venom all being "too frequent and too unforgivable" is right on point. I would expect to have these same issues if I were dropped in the middle of the rain forest. This forces you to think ahead, and be prepared for what can go wrong in the rest of the game. However, while I understand the need in story mode to not let us cut bigger trees to make bases, I would love to see this in survival mode, where we can clear land of bigger trees to just build and survive.

And I thought the forest was an unfinished game! Boy o' boy, the forest shines bright like a diamond compared to this one!

Bugged saves, flying objects, and animals stuck on everything. Just to mention a few. 

Odd choice for you to lose a random assortment of stuff when you die. Feels bad, should have either went with loosing nothing or loosing your tools. Or somewhere in between, it doesn't feel good for RNG to take your things. Hell I would prefer to loose everything over that RNG. 

It's unfortunate because there is a lot of good things with this game but it's just as unfinished and buggy as the forest. Sad
No fun
capybara

This is more disappointing than anticipating your paycheck to drop into your bank account, just to find out that you mis-calculated your auto pay date and it wont come until after the weekend and have to cancel going to the bar with your buddies because you're now both sad and poor. 

The crafting system makes about as much sense as stephen hawking trying to communicate through exclusively sign language
The game play itself is about as smooth as a fully grown male gorilla forcefully penetrating you
Combined with the ps2 graphics this game is about as smooth as a freshly sharpened knife
The fact that this game has mostly positive review blows my mind harder than a Thai women I met in the redlight district which i later found out was just a very pretty man and am too embarassed to tell anyone about. 

buy this at your own risk, it is not like the forest, it's like the severely inbred uncle cousin brother daddy to the forest.
Good game,Good storyline

applist.name: Borderlands 3
applist.detailed_description:
Borderlands 3 Ultimate Edition

Borderlands 3 Ultimate Edition is the quintessential Borderlands 3 experience, featuring the base game plus all 6 content add-ons and the full collection of bonus cosmetic packs!


Borderlands 3 Super Deluxe Edition

Continue your Borderlands 3 adventure with the Season Pass!

This content is included with purchase of the Borderlands 3 Super Deluxe Edition, Borderlands 3 Ultimate Edition, and Borderlands 3 Collector's Edition.

The Season Pass includes:

  • Moxxi’s Heist of the Handsome Jackpot campaign add-on.
  • Guns, Love, and Tentacles campaign add-on.
  • Bounty of Blood campaign add-on.
  • Psycho Krieg and the Fantastic Fustercluck campaign add-on.
  • All 4 Multiverse Final Form Cosmetic Packs.
  • A Butt Stallion weapon skin, weapon trinket and grenade mod.


About the Game


The original shooter-looter returns, packing bazillions of guns and an all-new mayhem-fueled adventure! Blast through new worlds and enemies as one of four brand new Vault Hunters – the ultimate treasure-seeking badasses of the Borderlands, each with deep skill trees, abilities, and customization. Play solo or join with friends to take on insane enemies, score loads of loot and save your home from the most ruthless cult leaders in the galaxy.

A MAYHEM-FUELED THRILL RIDE

Stop the fanatical Calypso Twins from uniting the bandit clans and claiming the galaxy’s ultimate power. Only you, a thrill-seeking Vault Hunter, have the arsenal and allies to take them down.

YOUR VAULT HUNTER, YOUR PLAYSTYLE

Become one of four extraordinary Vault Hunters, each with unique abilities, playstyles, deep skill trees, and tons of personalization options. All Vault Hunters are capable of awesome mayhem alone, but together they are unstoppable.

LOCK, LOAD, AND LOOT

With bazillions of guns and gadgets, every fight is an opportunity to score new gear. Firearms with self-propelling bullet shields? Check. Rifles that spawn fire-spewing volcanoes? Obviously. Guns that grow legs and chase down enemies while hurling verbal insults? Yeah, got that too.

NEW BORDERLANDS

Discover new worlds beyond Pandora, each featuring unique environments to explore and enemies to destroy. Tear through hostile deserts, battle your way across war-torn cityscapes, navigate deadly bayous, and more!

QUICK & SEAMLESS CO-OP ACTION

Play with anyone at any time with online co-op, regardless of your level or mission progress.

reviews.review:
Best Borderlands in terms of Gameplay, Gunplay, Vault Hunters, and Loot

Worst Borderlands in terms of Story and some of the DLC

Here's how to maximise your Borderlands 3 experience:

- Go into the settings and mute all dialogue
- Skip all cutscenes
- Make sure your subtitles are turned off
- Tab out to Spotify and start your favourite podcast
- Tab back into the game and enjoy!

This is the only way to truly experience all that this game has to offer!

The writing in this game is atrocious! All dialogues, story, and random interactions are just dumb and annoying. Borderlands used to be funny - this ain't it. 
A good thing about this game is that you can still run around and mindlessly shoot everything. 
Bottom line - it's an OK game to kill some time.
no one reads these anyway so il just say im gay
All you need to know is Good Gameplay, and Gunplay, with Bad story-telling and writing. Just keep in mind the shooting looting aspect of this game, and [b]DON'T TAKE THIS GAME TOO SERIOUSLY!!![/b}

Gameplay - 9/10
Story - that’s some cringe ass writing
Just watch K6 or Joltzdude on yt. You'll see.

This game is just wasted potential. Gameplay-wise, it's the best in the series arguably but story wise, it's a huge trainwreck. People mostly blame the bad story because of the character Ava. And I can see that. She was going to be much better than what was given to us according to the director's cut but she ended up being this annoying brat who blames everything she did onto other people like a whiny asshole. Just play Borderlands 2. It doesn't have the great gameplay this game introduces but it has a much MUCH better story, amazing characters (shoutous to my girl, Gaige) and the existence of Handsome Jack.
Its kind of cringy, bl2 was better.

The game gone too far from its roots , theres much less dark humour  and the game lost its charm because of it. My opinion game  has too much  shiny shooting ammo everythings too bright and  you barely can see what your doing.  But the worst part is  when you buy  a full  ULTRA EXTREME DELUXE VERSION FOR FULL PRICE and after  a year  SEASON PASS 2 - a total cash grab  DLC  which  is  wery wery shity  and totaly not worth your money ,since iam an achievement hunter i was forced to buy this crap like allot of ppl did i guess. Thats why i give a big negative review.
Story is complete raging garbage. Real dumpster fire. Game play is pretty good though.

It's hard to understand what these developers were thinking, or what kind of strange pressure they were under. The core mechanics and gameplay found here are solid and entertaining, and that is usually the hardest part to nail in a game. However, everything around that core is a chore.

I am playing Borderlands 3 with multiple mods that remove dialogue and speed up animations, and the game still plays out incredibly slowly. There is a lot of starting and stopping, all the time, and then you have to sit through a lot of exposition from some uninportant side character, with nothing much to do because progression is tied to these monologues. Story in a game that is basically about upgrading loot should be skippable, but no... even with mods you still need to sit through the animations and so on.

If you add that to the fact that the difficulty is quite low overall, certainly lower than the two games before it, you end up with a great game being held back by the developers' obsession with the idea that they are great storytellers and that somehow this is the main point of the game. All the praise heaped upon Borderlands 2's story must be at fault here, but that was a juvenile story to begin with, propped up by interesting characters.

I can't say I recommend it, even though that parts that you are actually allowed to play are very fun. It often just feels like the game is wasting your time.
It's fun :D

As mentioned by others, the cringe caused by the dialogues in this game are so severe you could end up injured. Otherwise it's a decent shooter. Good amount of weapons and build variety to enjoy. The areas are what you'd expect from the franchise, well designed and fun to explore. The unique aesthetic is still there with colorful visuals.

However if you are expecting anything like the first or second game regarding the story and characters, you will be disappointed for sure. So I only recommend this for the other aspects. 

As always, they keep the horrible cash grab approach. So be patient and get either the base game or the ultimate edition during a discount, it will worth your money! It might be a local issue but for me the the deluxe edition with less content is more expensive than the ultimate..
Poor optimization
dont get a game u will enjoy suffer with boredom
it's certainly a game of all time

Possibly the most annoying cast (with very few exceptions) and least-interesting Vault Dwellers to play I have ever experienced in a Borderlands game so far. But hey, that's just Borderlands being Borderlands. This has nothing to do with my not recommending the game to others!

I do not recommend this game because of the CONSTANT AND RELENTLESS reminders and offers to buy the DLC you are stricken with as the game goes on. All throughout the hub ship and sometimes other places as well you'll see quest markers letting you know you have a new quest available - except you can only accept the quest(s) if you own the DLC. Well, this means the quest markers never go away!

Okay, so you try to remember the markers are part of a DLC and won't ever go away and just do your best to ignore them, right? Wrong. Passing by some of these DLC quest markers makes you receive an immediate radio message from the "main story protagonist" of said DLC letting you know they want to talk to you. This happens every time you return to the main hub and pass by it again. Some of them are placed near often-revisited NPCs and resources like the item vault so you can't avoid hearing them.

The whole thing just feels super scummy and predatory and I don't feel right supporting such practices.

Borderlands 3 exceeds all the other previous games in terms of gameplay like a vast range of cool weapons that all do different things while also giving some Quality of life changes like being able to grapple onto ledges, slide etc. However, the story was absolutely terrible. Overall, I say pick this one up when it's on sale.

The Story is pretty bad if you compared it with BL2, but without that comparison i think it's still fairly good.

The game-play tho is in my opinion this games biggest strength. 
The guns feel amazing and the skills are satisfying and fun to use.
Combat in general is extremely fun.

My only complaints are currently the distribution of loot and the difficulty.
I feel like you get way too much legendary gear, to the point where all other tiers of loot just kinda obsolete.
Don't get me wrong, I love all the cool unique yellow shiny stuff but it also makes it a lot less special to get what is supposed to be rare gear. So tuning it down a little bit would be good i think.

My second point is the difficulty, the game is really easy if you do just about any of the side quests.
Having an inventory full of powerful legendary guns doesn't help this.
If you are like me and do all side missions before continuing the story, you will likely melt bosses in seconds with the only thing stopping you being their (very annoying) invincibility phases

applist.name: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege
applist.detailed_description:
Edition Comparison


Deluxe Edition



The Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege Deluxe Edition includes the full game and 16 operators from Years 1 and 2.


Operator Edition



The Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege Operator Edition includes the full game and all 46 operators from Years 1–7.


Ultimate Edition



The Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege Ultimate Edition includes the full game, all 46 operators from Years 1–7, and more.


Technical Test Server



This is the Technical Test Server client for Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege. This platform will be used to test new features in a controlled environment that allows the development team to iterate without impacting the live game.

o Please note :
- The T.T.S. client is built off of several different builds at various stages of development, and may not represent the overall quality of the game.
- Features seen on the T.T.S. might never make it in the final game: various components are still in conceptual stages and might be discarded throughout the development process. Certain ideas that were postponed or cancelled might also be found in the T.T.S. as a result.
- You need to own a version of the game (Standard, Gold, Complete or Starter Edition) to unlock this product
- The TTS will only function during specific timeframes.


About the Game

“One of the best first-person shooters ever made. 10\10” – GameSpot

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six® Siege is an elite, realistic, tactical team-based shooter where superior planning and execution triumph. It features 5v5 attack vs. defense gameplay and intense close-quarters combat in destructible environments.


Engage in a brand-new style of assault using an unrivaled level of destruction and gadgetry.
On defense, coordinate with your team to transform your environments into strongholds. Trap, fortify and create defensive systems to prevent being breached by the enemy.
On attack, lead your team through narrow corridors, barricaded doorways and reinforced walls. Combine tactical maps, observation drones, rappelling and more to plan, attack and defuse every situation.


Choose from dozens of highly trained, Special Forces operators from around the world. Deploy the latest technology to track enemy movement. Shatter walls to open new lines of fire. Breach ceilings and floors to create new access points. Employ every weapon and gadget from your deadly arsenal to locate, manipulate and destroy your enemies and the environment around them.


Experience new strategies and tactics as Rainbow Six Siege evolves over time. Change the rules of Siege with every update that includes new operators, weapons, gadgets and maps. Evolve alongside the ever-changing landscape with your friends and become the most experienced and dangerous operators out there.


Compete against others from around the world in ranked match play. Grab your best squad and join the competitive community in weekly tournaments or watch the best professional teams battle it out in the Rainbow Six Siege Pro League.

reviews.review: I hate this game.
The more I play this game the more I hate myself.
definitely one of the games of all time

Absolute nightmare. Teammates will make you angry, game breaking bugs still occur at times, matchmaking is a mess, and a lot of the maps are not good.
Also the most unique competitive fps games ever made, and when it clicks it's one of the best. Do not solo queue though because it will make you want to jump off a roof.

　二つ

Eat my nuts Ubisoft, you are so grossly disconnected from your community. It is a true shame to watch a game that you enjoyed and loved be slowly butchered by a company that only exists to slowly drain the wallets of their fan base. I sternly believe that Ubisoft purposefully brings out stupid updates and changes to slowly kill the community so that they can let the game die and move on to other projects, while also doing crossover events to steal the money of their dedicated player base. I think ubisoft is just ashamed to come outright and say that they don't want to support or update the game anymore, and just wish to slowly kill the game along with its community.

Ubisoft, long ago, ever since they switched dev teams, have lost sight of what siege was supposed to be. Siege is unique, the original path of the game was to have it be a sort of in-between your average arcade shooter and your slow tactical shooters like Ready or Not. However, over the last several years, I feel as though this concept has been lost on Ubisoft, they even try to vilify the part of the community which disagrees by creating the character Deimos. This brings me to the story, why the hell is there one. The lore of the game was that Rainbow Six was a multi-national counter terrorist agency designed to eliminate the most dangerous of terrorist threats. Great, stellar, that is all we needed. Nighthaven was a decent concept, but it was executed so poorly. I think it would have been great to add a PMC group to the team, seems great, but then you give them ungodly advanced levels of technology, rivaling and even surpassing entire nations, that then for some reason creeps into the lore of certain gadgets. It was so unnecessary to do this, I just don't understand why it was done at all. An actual story was and is being developed, and I can't understand why, they bring in a character named Deimos who they say is the villain, yet his only flaw is his moral compass. He is objectively right about rainbow six as a whole, it being a joke and no longer the intimidating counter terrorist organization it once was. Early on in their development of the story, they transition the leader of Rainbow from some lady to some British guy named Harry. This was the start of the fall for siege, as it signified the start of this random ass story building that they wanted to do. 

Now a bad story may not necessarily mean the gameplay is bad... except it fucking blows ass. Ubisoft, in the same way they ruin the story, they bring out certain changes to slowly ruin the game. Sledge is a prime example, he was a good operator, in no way broken, he wasn't even very highly picked, yet they took away his smg 11 and made him a 1 armor, and then to add insult to injury they took away his acog later on. What was the point of this, he was never broken or over picked, he was pretty well balanced, and now he is just a worse pick than buck or ash. While not all balance changes are as bad as this, the vast majority of changes that Ubisoft decides to bring out are just bad for balancing. They also have a tendency to nerf things rather than to buff them, or if they do buff operators, they don't make an impactful change. This leads to all ops becoming worse and therefore not as fun, rather than uplifting other ops and making those more fun. The last set of changes have been things such as the UI or kill indicator. They had no reason to change any of these, especially the ubisoft overlay which barely even works and somehow still buggy despite being years after release. The kill indicator is no longer quite as satisfying and snappy as it once was, which makes kills feel less rewarding and not as fun. Continuing, the UI is just a mess. It is confusing, especially for new players, and was so unnecessary. It also plays more into the concept of this game becoming more arcady and "cartoony". Lastly, and likely one of the worst changes so far, is the ranked 2.0 system. For some reason, people fail to understand how it works, so the rundown is basically that there are two mmrs that a player has, a hidden and visible, the hidden is what actually pits players against each other, the the visible just exists as its own thing? Like who verified that this was a working system, why in gods name did they try to be innovative on a system that was tried and tested? The hidden mmr system just doesn't seem to work, pitting what would be ranked 1.0 plats against ranked 1.0 champs. Leading to imbalanced, irritating, or boring games, along with poor balancing. The visible mmr also serves no purpose, as it is criminally easy to hit higher ranks, leading to a more than 1000% increase in the amount of Champions. Why does it exist, why are players not given a ranked based off who they play with, why is it based off how well they play against their specific skill level? It leaves no incentives to improve and only the incentive to play and hit champ. The fact that a person with a 12% win loss can hit champ is disgusting. The best of the best of players are the ones meant to be hitting the highest rank in the game, yet for some unholy reason, they just invite morons into the group. If I remember correctly, take this with a pinch of salt, I believe their justification for this was to "reward players not just based off skill but also how much they play". They essentially removed the ranked part of the definition of ranked. If I played chess for 16 hours a day for the rest of my life, but remain among the worst players of the game, why in gods name should I be given the title Grandmaster when I would not be able to compete against any other legit Grandmaster? It makes no sense to reward people for play time, and grant them something that they do not deserve. The incentive to play in ranked 1.0 was to improve so that you could hit the higher rank. Without the need to improve, it leaves the community overall worse. Maybe the devs brought it out so they could finally hit a rank past gold.

No words, not even an entire essay, could describe my dissatisfaction with Ubisoft and how they have handled this game. They have failed the community, the gameplay, and somehow, the core concept of the game itself. It would take an utter buffoon to see what is happening and think to themselves, "this is perfectly fine". Take a lesson from any competitive shooter and stop focusing on your casual community. I think the view point of focusing on it to just be completely wrong. While it may bring temporary life into the game, most casual players don't really care about the game and can leave on a whim. Focusing on the ranked community, particularly those at the top bracket to ensure the longevity of a game as those are the people who tend to be the most passionate about the game. Further, the devs of this game either don't really play the game or suck ass at it, so they aren't even good at understanding balance changes. For a lot of games, the devs are actually pretty good at the game, this is because they built the game so they understand it. I would think the devs for Siege, now being the one's making it, would also understand it. Of course not that would be smart and reasonable.

I will sadly, and much to my own chagrin, keep playing the game. This is because there is no other game around like it, and frankly,  this is the only reason the game is still around. Everyone shits on EA for their crappy economy decisions in their games, yet for a lot of the games, they improve and fix this issue, and even in the case of the sports clones, it is easy to just avoid their copys. Just look at battlefront 2, it is a stellar game now but it did release to some controversy. Yet Ubisoft, rather than trying to improve their game, reward the worse parts of the community, and sacrificing everyone who actually cares about the game. They are as arrogant and foolish as Narcissus, since both Ubisoft and he fell in love with themselves.
BRAIN DAMAGE

i have to say, i'm deeply disappointed with the direction rainbow six siege has taken, especially since the release of ela. the game used to rely on strategy, communication, and careful planning. but with ela, the delicate balance that made siege stand out among other shooters has been disturbed, turning it into something more like a standard run-and-gun title.

but my biggest gripe, the real knife to the heart, is the mishandling of the character "havoc." havoc was teased in the game's e3 trailer, portrayed as this intriguing, menacing character who was supposed to bring an exciting twist to the game. the trailer did an excellent job of building hype around havoc - the character's design, menacing aura, and what appeared to be a unique gameplay mechanic.

the trailer painted a vivid picture of havoc as a new villain, a ruthless operator, who seemed to be bringing a new level of intensity and danger to siege. it suggested that his arrival would significantly shake up the game's dynamics, posing new challenges and creating fresh strategies for players to explore.

however, this was all a pipe dream. despite all the hype, despite all the anticipation built up, havoc is nowhere to be found in the actual game. it's a classic case of false advertising and has left many fans, including me, feeling betrayed. we were promised something exciting, something groundbreaking, but what we got was a no-show.

and if the mishandling of havoc wasn't enough, the writing has also gone down the drain, exemplified by the addition of "dokkaebi." her bio intro is just cringeworthy: "her fingers dance across the keyboard, the light of the lcd screen underscoring her smirk." it's a cheesy line that feels out of place and makes her character feel shallow and uninspired. it's not the level of writing one would expect from a game with the pedigree of rainbow six siege.

it's hard not to feel misled and deceived. the absence of havoc in the game is like a promising movie trailer with no actual film to follow. it's like being served a mouthwatering menu with no food to eat. it's not just about one character - it's about broken promises and shattered expectations.

the game has deviated from its roots, focusing on quick action and flashy gimmicks rather than on deep, tactical gameplay. the introduction of ela, the misleading portrayal of havoc, and the cringe-worthy writing for dokkaebi have made siege lose its identity, and it's a real shame.

in conclusion, if you loved rainbow six siege for its strategic depth, teamwork, and engaging characters, you might want to give it a miss for now. unless the developers make a U-turn and steer the game back to its roots, it's hard to see this title reclaiming its former glory. so until then, i can't recommend this game.

applist.name: Slayers X: Terminal Aftermath: Vengance of the Slayer
applist.detailed_description:
.. welcome to.... THE STEEL SEWER. The biggest motherflippin secret base in the galaxy.


  • We are X Slayers... It is we who fight The Psyko Sindikate.
  • We pledge to defend the people of earth even though they're beep-holes to us and don't even deserve it.

Why? Because the Psyko Sindikate are freakin sick evil turds and are using the Hackblood (yes... they are stealing our powers... idiots) to bring evil enemies to life & take over the world and enslaven humanity.

WE. ARE. X SLAYERS.
We study the secrets of the Hackblood and it pulses through our veins.
We lie in wait, biting our time for the right moment to strike the Psykos.... while blasting original music by Seepage & Psyko Syndicate


Weather by
  • S-Blade,
  • Double Pistols,
  • Glass Blaster,
  • Explosive Sludge Launcher,
  • X100 Rapid Mutilator,
  • Triple Helix Missile Launcher,
  • or Hackblood Power




, we will hunt them down and get them wherever they hide.... they can hide anywhere like...
  • my room
  • the sewer
  • the playground
  • the dollar$haver store
  • the laundrymat
  • professor pizza
  • inside a computer
  • at the south boise july 4th fair
  • and more...

back in 1998 me and my friend Chase were making this game... and guess what... Chase found it again. he burnt it onto a CD-ROM and now we're going to finish it and put it on-line. i got out of computers in the mean time because I had to get a real job at a Dollar$aver (I even have a kid... how did htat happen BWL!!!?) so i forgot how to program but Chase is going to do it, he went to college for it. i still have my notebook with all of the designs and guess what.... its still flipping incredable. get ready for the greatest game in the world......

Alright, so imagine the kind of shooter that a teenager living in Boise, Idaho would imagine and plan while pretending to pay attention in class around the year 1997 after just having watched hackers and played Duke Nukem 3D. This is that with all of the maturity, campiness and "no mom, I promise I didn't swear!" that you would expect.

In any other context this would've been considered a terrible mod at best, but the fact that they saw their childhood dream through to reality - it's fuckin beautiful. And it's helped by the fact that everything, every mechanic is solid.

applist.name: Captain of Industry
applist.detailed_description:
JOIN OUR DISCORD


About the Game

Your journey will start on an abandoned island with a small crew of loyal workers. In order to survive, you will need to mine raw materials from the earth, grow food, build factories, manufacture products, construct vehicles, research new technologies, explore your surroundings, and trade with other islands. If you do things right, you'll work your way up towards an industrial superpower and you can even start a space program! But this is no easy task and you will be put to the test to keep your settlement alive.

Manufacture products


Start simple - smelt iron, mix concrete, create construction parts, and grow food. Soon you will be able to expand into crude oil processing, electronics, solar panels, data centers, and even rockets. There are over 150 unique products to explore and work with!

Build vehicles and transport products


Logistics systems ensure that trucks will automatically deliver products where they are most needed. You can configure the logistics to make it more efficient. Don’t forget to build enough trucks or upgrade existing ones to keep things moving!

Build conveyor belts and pipes


Use conveyor belts and pipes to route products efficiently and relieve stress on truck-based logistics. The transport system supports vertical stacking and auto-pathing for easy placement. Balancers and sorters also help organize your assembly lines by providing priority and sorting functionalities.

Mine raw resources on fully dynamic terrain


Find the natural riches of your land and use them to expand your empire. Mine coal, iron, copper, gold, or pump underground oil and water! Make open-pit mines to extract valuable ores from underground, or just dump excess rocks into the ocean to create a new land to build on! Remember that no mountain is tall enough for your fleet of excavators!

Additionally, the dynamic terrain system allows you to create access to various levels of elevation throughout your island. Dig or dump terrain to create slopes between hard to reach places so that you can have the most efficient path for your vehicles.

Farm your land


You need to feed your people by growing simple crops such as potatoes. Later, you will be able to grow more advanced crops such as wheat or soybeans and process them to make more kinds of food and products. You can also produce fertilizers and use greenhouses to keep up with the food demands.

Grow your settlement and provide for your people


To staff your factories, farms, and vehicles, you need people, and lots of them. Build housing and provide essentials to your citizens such as food, water, electricity, healthcare, and household goods. Population will grow on its own depending on their health and happiness, but you can also recruit and rescue populations on the world map to help aid your island.

Build complex oil and chemical refineries


Break crude oil down into different usable fractions using multiple refining stages. With the ability to stack pipes you can create compact and scalable plants that can make all the oil-based products you will need for your growing empire.

Research new technologies


Research is a must have! Unlock new buildings and materials and make your factory more efficient. New technologies will change the course of your future. Your factory will grow more efficient and advanced with over 140 technologies to unlock.

Import and export resources to and from your island


Establish shipping lanes with cargo ships to fill the gaps in your production by bringing in various products such as crude oil, wood, or quartz. While the resources on your island may be limited, the world is not! Later you will be also able to establish shipping contracts with other islands for periodic exchange of goods.

Explore the world, trade with allies, fight pirates


Repair and upgrade your ship with better engines, armor, and weapons. Explore your surroundings, find refugees, allied settlements to trade with, discover more resources, and be ready for naval battles with pesky pirates!

Get to space!


Research and develop your way to space flight. Launch a rocket as a true test of your settlement’s accomplishments.

reviews.review:
I haven't written a review for this yet? Darn!
Short version: Recommended.

Longer version:
CoI is another entry into the genre of factory games, specifically the top down management ones (aka, you're an invisible force, not a guy/mech walking around in the factory you build). What sets this game apart from it's competitors is
 - realism-based industrial chains and processes
 - terraforming and open pit mining with actual terrain physics
 - a slow progression based around fine-tuning new recipes for higher efficiency with the limited resources you have (rather than plastering the map with copy pasted factories)
 - difficulty, by virtue of actually being able to lose (due to running into a logistical blackout, or simply being too wasteful and running out of a critical ressource before you managed to unlock an alternative)

In particular the grounded nature of it's setting makes the game oddly appealing: Sure, fighting hordes of alien with railway artillery can be entertaining, and there's a certain appeal to turning an entire planet into a ball of metal that pumps out Dyson Spheres... but somehow that can't beat actually planning out an open pit mine, and watching your excavators slowly chip away at the coal deposit, turning the 'untouched forested hill region with specks of coal' into 'massive crater stripped of any valuable ressources', whilst slowly progressing from truck-ferried loads of coal, to belt-fed steam turbines, to a self-sustained eco-paradise.

There's also a massive amount of control, notification, and QoL features. A common occurence in factory style games (to me, at least) is to go in, play, and then notice that some obvious feature you know from another game is missing. None of that in CoI, it's all there, and more. Be it blueprints, automated notifications for storage levels, precisely limited cargo transports... Really, the only thing missing might be a turing-complete digital automation system... but then again I also haven't yet run into a situation where I would actually need one.

And, as a final positive note: The developement team. There's a lot of EA titles that just dumple around and then there's an occasional 'update' with a few bugfixes so that the dev team can claim the game is totally still being developement and not just a resting cash grab. But with CoI, you get regular updates, plentiful devlogs (even going into technical depths that are incredibly fascinating as a programmer) and a constantly evolving gameplay.

So, overall, I'd argue this might very well be my absolute favorite of the factory game genre. Sure, it can't quite compete with the stunning asthethics of Satisfactory, and it doesn't bring the action and insane mod volume of Factorio, but when it comes down to just having solid factory gameplay, noone can outdo the Cap'n.
Score: 8/10
The graphics and soundscape are not exactly breathtaking, and the performance can start getting dice on larger factories (though the patch end of month might actually fix a lot of the latter), but everything else from core gameplay to polish is a solid recommendation to any genre fans. And also anyone interested in trying out the factory genre to begin with.

I want to get this out of the way: This game is actually an absolute blast. I love the industry aesthetic, I love the feeling of building a cool assembly line, I love watching my little guys go do their things while I ruin the atmosphere using enough coal power to make Captain Planet have a coronary. That's why it gets a thumbs up.

BUT

There needs to be some rebalancing -- in particular, with Bricks. I got to a point where I could not build *anything* without construction parts, which require bricks, which require dirt. Maybe I am an idiot, but I could not get dirt because my miners, despite my instructions, prioritized everything else. Then I hit a point where I looked up a solution! I found you can get concrete and use that in lieu of brick to get parts.

So I spent a while researching concrete, got it, and got ready to render bricks obsolete.

Wouldn't you know it, to build the stuff you need to process concrete, you need construction parts... which I couldn't get, because I needed B R I C K S.

I immediately closed the game.

I don't understand how I can create elaborate assembly lines and repair a ship and do all sorts of cool industrial magic and then can't even get a single ounce of dirt off the ground in a way that would let me work around this brick issue.

Maybe some day I will have the gumption to play this again and figure out how dirt and bricks work.

Today is not that day.
Combination of Factorio and Banished.
wish there was sandbox mode

[b]If you ever enjoyed any automation game and have not tried this one - go for it. An absolute gem of a game![/b]

I have played many hours in variety of Factorio-like games (be it Minecraft modpacks, Satisfactory, Dyson Sphere Program and suchlike), and this is by far my favourite title of this kind.
I would highlight three things:
1) Progression - In this factory new technologies require rethinking of the supply chains, gradually increasing complexity. This is very smooth and extremely satisfying.
2) Landscaping - your excavators dig the raw ores out of the ground, leaving in holes to fill in with rock and cover with topsoil to farm on. 
3) Visuals - this game goes for more gritty style, which is still immensely readable. Gradual transformation of the island into prosperous industrial landscape is very pleasing to the eye. The satisfaction of zooming out and flying over the island compares to the best moments of inspecting the largest bases in Factorio or Satisfactory or planet-size production facilities in DSP.

Overly fiddly and overly punishing. Explanations of mechanics are done at a very high, general level, leaving the details to you to get destroyed by. Didn't know you needed three extra spaces to make a conveyor go up or down? Didn't know they can't connect in certain places? Didn't know your potatoes and your vegetables need different types of conveyors? Don't know how to exactingly design mining areas so your excavators and trucks don't bad-AI themselves into a place they can't leave? Well, guess you're losing irreplaceable resources as you tear things down and rebuild them, and hope it doesn't mean your entire economy collapses because the bottleneck means you don't feed the unstoppable need for everything.

It's a fine game if you go in with the expectation that you're going to need to watch ten hours of youtube videos explaining how to do things, and that you're going to throw away three or four six-hour sessions as unrecoverable disasters.
Factorio with citizens. Works really well.

The Dark Souls of automation games. 100%.

It's not about volume of machines, but more about careful planning and understanding of what needs what, where it comes from, and where it needs to go. Automation is extremely expensive. Pipes that carry liquid are cheap, but conveyor belts require Tier 2 construction equipment. Building a sustainable setup for T2 construction equipment takes about 5-6 hours played at normal speed with frequent pauses. You mess up and miss one construction material? You are now in the black-hole of construction as literally your entire base is now solely dependent on a single resource that is being carried, one truck at a time, to its destination. 

If that sounds fun to you, get this game. It's a hell of a challenge but as mentioned by other reviews, it's fantastic to watch your base grow and the terraforming take place.

The starts always fun but somewhere the recipes become so complex it starts to lose steam for me.
Started like 5 games, had fun with it, but finished none.
Its no factorio, you cant simply rebuild your eg forges somewhere else, theres so much logistic attached to everything that moving/rebuilding is a pain.
With the example of forges you would have to run 5 additional pipes/belts: coal, ore/scrap, iron product, waste and exaust(for scrubbing). And thats just for one product, then you should also add steel in there which requires all of the above + oxygen and water.

Maybe I should simply use more Trucks? But the network seems easily overwhelmed sometimes.
I dont know ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

So far so good, enjoying the game, updates looking good.

I hope there will be more of an end game in the future though, for us that enjoy playing the same map for hundreds of hours.

An absolutely amazing game about building a growing logistics chain of factories, foundries and mines in order to keep up with what the workers requires and demands, the game comes with an awesome soundtrack that also just clicks so pleasingly with the game-play itself. 

One second you could be looking at your growing chain of spaghetti conveyor belts and pipes before [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p3NON-SuUuw]Eureka[/url] starts playing as you realize you could shift some of the spaghetti creation around a bit in order to make a new path for your growing fleet of vehicles, or maybe fit a new building in the newly created space. 

The games method of building and gathering various resources is as satisfying to watch as watching the imps from the dungeon keeper game do their thing to build a new room, except here you get to watch your growing fleet navigate their way around your factory in order to deliver resources to the new building you just placed down or deliver resources to a foundry or perhaps even to that storage area you have on the opposite of the island. 

That's also something I love about this game, you're merely the architect/foreman of this growing factory, you place down the blueprints of where stuff is supposed to go while designating a new area to be deforested before you then designate another area to be flattened out, mined or even filled in, then you get to sit back and watch as your minions make your factory come to life before your eyes, not once do you ever directly tell a vehicle to go to some specific area, you merely delegate what they're supposed to do and they find their own way there. 

Amusingly the thing I love the most about the game, is also the thing that made me struggle the most in the start, I was never really told...or even bothered to read...how you control the vehicle fleet and was instantly befuddled by the lack of any kind of waypoint system, the day afterwards I found out how to make them actually do stuff after I designated the abandoned factory for disassembly and watched the fleet suddenly spring to life, the knowledge clicked and things snowballed from there!

I'd write a long review listing all the things that are great about this game, but I don't have time. Factory must grow.

All I can say is that I've played many games of this kind and this is one of the best, only slightly outshined by the very best such as Factorio, Satisfactory and DSP.
Its never ending really.

This game looks good now, and runs a lot better.

Starting to shape up guys watch some reviews and consider buying, it's really good.
Great factory game
